revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-09 04:50:08.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unnecessary shutdown argument to _destroy()

Xen requires the VM power state be not running before it can be
destroyed. Xen also requires the VM power state to be running
to shutdown a VM. The shutdown argument was available to ensure
that a shutdown was not attempted when the VM was not running.

Since commit f5b051bbd0858294157f911ecbb04542fadbb38d, the
_shutdown() method checks the power state and determines if it
should issue the shutdown command or not. As a result, the
shutdown argument is unnecessary and always calling the
_shutdown() method will ensure the VM is in the proper state
for the destroy to succeed.

Change-Id: I9bc6007598da4ac69e8d463be9af51deaf5d6535
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unnecessary shutdown argument to _destroy()

Xen requires the VM power state be not running before it can be
destroyed. Xen also requires the VM power state to be running
to shutdown a VM. The shutdown argument was available to ensure
that a shutdown was not attempted when the VM was not running.

Since commit f5b051bbd0858294157f911ecbb04542fadbb38d, the
_shutdown() method checks the power state and determines if it
should issue the shutdown command or not. As a result, the
shutdown argument is unnecessary and always calling the
_shutdown() method will ensure the VM is in the proper state
for the destroy to succeed.

Change-Id: I9bc6007598da4ac69e8d463be9af51deaf5d6535

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-05-09 12:31:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

After this change, we can run network on multi nodes, each network per node.
1. run nova-manage network create networka xxxxx/yy on hosta
2. run nova-manage network create networkb xxxx1/yy on hostb

problem is sometimes the nova-network has to resend message to another host. Hope nova-compute can send message to correct target host directly.

Is it possible? Since we have host in network record, I think we can use it as a hint for nova-compute. An alternative is that we expand our scheduler feature to select nova-network host.

Just some of my thoughts.
Thanks'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-09 16:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Use ConfigOpts.find_file() to locate policy.json

Use cfg's new helper method to find policy config file. The basic
behavior is "look alongside the config file" with a fall back to
the standard default config paths.

Change-Id: Ic2a7187378eab9c9066118132465280993778a5e

Improve the sample keystone.conf

Make sure all the available options are include in the file, add
some more documentation and, rather than set any of the defaults,
just include them as comments.

commit_message:
Use ConfigOpts.find_file() to locate catalog template

Fixes bug #983734

Use cfg's new helper method to find the catalog template file. The basic
behavior is "look alongside the config file" with a fall back to the
standard default config paths.

Change-Id: Ia25fefafaa2c387d0207d630e5613389be364628

subject: Add Trusted Computing Pool support
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-08 20:40:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I like this approach much better than the last one.  I haven't done a full review yet but I have a comment and a question right away.

Question:

Since nova supports filters shipped separately from the code, do you see any advantage to these filters being in nova itself vs shipping them as an external library?

Comments:

You have a whole bunch of tabs your files.  Those should be fixed.
If you put 'implements blueprint trusted-computing-pools' it will link them."}, {'account_id': 1981, 'date': '2012-05-08 22:42:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

1)  Tabs are bad?  Oh well, I'll reformat the patch and resubmitt, since this will change just about every line in the patch I'll just self-NAK and re-submit.

2)  I think there is still value in having this as a standard filter. It makes it easier for the user to utilize trusted computing pools as they are `just part of the system'.  Plus it adds reliability since any changes to the scheudler will have to be reflected in this filter as it is part of the testing."}, {'account_id': 1981, 'date': '2012-05-09 00:24:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

New version of the patch coming soon.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-05-09 14:20:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

You can also just do a "git commit --amend" on your changeset and git review update it. It keeps the conversation on the same thread.

Also there should be a style unit test in the tree, make sure to run all the unit tests prior to submit.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-08 20:01:12.000000000', 'message': "Add Trusted Computing Pool support

Add a scheduling filter that filters based upon the trustedness of
a node.  A request is sent to the attestation service to disover the
trustedness of the target node and, only if it matches the `trust' key/value
pair in the `extra_specs' for the instance type, then the instance
can be started on that node.

To setup an attestation server go to the Open Attestation Project at:

        https://github.com/OpenAttestation/OpenAttestation

Also add tests for the new filter that checks the three conditions:

1)  Schedule works with no trust in the extra specs
2)  Schedule works with correct trust value in the extra specs
3)  Schedule fails will incorrect trust value in the extra specs

Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Fred Yang <fred.yang@intel.com>

Change-Id: I13a1353484ec65be9215d66a84d9db5ee0934f3e
"}]
commit_message:
Add Trusted Computing Pool support

Add a scheduling filter that filters based upon the trustedness of
a node.  A request is sent to the attestation service to disover the
trustedness of the target node and, only if it matches the `trust' key/value
pair in the `extra_specs' for the instance type, then the instance
can be started on that node.

To setup an attestation server go to the Open Attestation Project at:

        https://github.com/OpenAttestation/OpenAttestation

Also add tests for the new filter that checks the three conditions:

1)  Schedule works with no trust in the extra specs
2)  Schedule works with correct trust value in the extra specs
3)  Schedule fails will incorrect trust value in the extra specs

Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Fred Yang <fred.yang@intel.com>

Change-Id: I13a1353484ec65be9215d66a84d9db5ee0934f3e

commit_message:
Cleanup authtoken examples

* remove auth_uri - do not need when set auth_port, auth_host, auth_protocol
* remove servce_*  variables - not needed in new keystone
* update associated documentation

subject: Do not allow blank adminPass attribute on set password
messages:
[{'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-04-30 17:12:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This is a change to the external API. The docs do not say that an empty password is not allowed, only that 

"The specified password must meet the complexity requirements set by your OpenStack Compute provider"'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-30 17:22:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

David: this change is disallowing a blank password, not enabling it. This patch is getting us closer to being spec-compliant (and it's already in master, this is a backport to stable/essex)"}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-04-30 17:31:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Brian, I understood that. The question is the policy for stable branches which I am trying to understand. This is an API change and not a security hole so I didn't think fixing it was important enough for a stable branch change. I don't know where the spec for this is, only the documentation. It seemed to me that since this change could break existing code that it was not justified."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-30 17:39:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

What's most important is to respect the spec. I don't care what the implementation was in stable/essex, but clients should be coding to the spec."}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-04-30 18:00:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-30 18:30:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3723/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2340/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1999/ : ABORTED 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3733/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-01 10:22:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

I think David asks a fair question which we should answer properly

i.e. this is a change in the API, why are we ok with that while the stable branch policy forbids API changes?

Brian - your argument is that the current behaviour is just a bug because it doesn't match what's in the spec? Could you point out where in the spec we require a non-empty password? 

(Honest question - it's probably there, I just can't find it)

Aside from the spec, maybe the argument is that setting an empty password is obviously dumb or just doesn't work and there's little or no chance any existing client is relying on the behaviour? In that case, I'd be totally fine with this going into stable"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-01 14:17:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok, so I should have done some more investigation in the first place, but here's what I came up with:

1) The spec does not actually require non-blank passwords in the three cases the attribute is accepted: create, rebuild, and changePassword. I made an assumption based on the bug report, which was a mistake

2) The handling of blank passwords isn't handled consistently in our implementation of the v2 API spec. Server create and changePassword both reject blank passwords (differently based on content-type of request) while a rebuild seems to allow blank passwords.

I would suggest we allow this branch to land then file/fix a bug in Nova to make everything more consistent and land all that as well."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:03:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Mark, I'll let you make the call here on whether this patch lands here or not."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:11:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

From IRC, it sounds like we've a bit more work to do on master to get consistent behaviour. I'd prefer not to have unnecessary churn on stable, so let's revisit when the we've got the consistency work finished on master"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-09 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-09 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-15 16:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Wow, this is a lot of code.  As cool as it is, and as nice as it is to have integration testing for the scheduler, this may be too much to go in prior to Folsom'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-15 17:00:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hmm, yeah, but it is a test only (and 1 or 2 little bug fixes)'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-15 17:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-15 17:30:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Last patch was to fix a test problem where I wasn't resetting the utc override and busting subsequent tests."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-15 18:03:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (7 inline comments)

Most of my inline comments are femtonits or questions.  Also, is tools/simulator/etc/sample_config.json supposed to be empty?  What is the purpose of that file?'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-15 18:10:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Might this belong in Tempest?'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-15 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

re: tempest ... no. Totally different thing.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-15 19:04:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sorry, keyboard got away from me. Let me qualify that.

The way I envision this being used is as a utility during tuning/scheduler filter/weight development. You adjust your tunings or algorithms, run the tests and look at the results. The HTML is just a faster way to see what the logs are telling you. I don't see this as being a real time or daily use thing. 

Eventually we could actually make the tests fail on bad allocations, but that's not there currently (and detecting them is a tricky problem.)

Hope that clarifies things a little better?"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-15 19:25:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

Good points ... will patch.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-15 20:19:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-15 21:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

One more thing, though; tools/simulator/etc/sample_config.json is an empty file.  Is it supposed to be?  What goes in here?'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-17 01:01:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

There will be a follow up branch that will have the customization stuff in there and that uses the .json file. It's just a placeholder for now."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-17 02:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I see.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-21 14:46:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:16:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Pretty funky stuff. The charts are cool. Nice work.

One odd thing about it this is that it's not a really test (i.e. we're not asserting success or failure, although I guess we're exercising the code), but instead a profiling/simulation tool for developers working on the scheduler.

My instinct is to try and keep stuff like this separate from Nova itself. Is there any way we could keep the fake scheduler and host manager in nova (in nova.scheduler rather than nova.tests), add some real tests to nova.tests which use this to make success/failure assertions and create a separate side project for generating reports from more complex simulations?

That way, I think we'd end up with a) less stuff in Nova, b) more useful tests and c) an easier to use, run, hack on simulation tool.

Interested to hear what others think. I don't see any issues with the code other than those already pointed out."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Keeping it short and sweet, I agree with Mark :)'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:00:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thanks.

That's the road I started down with this branch, but I found I was spending way too much time doing much of the same stuff that nova already does in setting up the tests: setting a fake db up with the latest migrations, getting all the defaults in place, getting mox in place so I could stub out the appropriate things, etc etc. 

I think, to rip it out would really result in a large chunk of code that would have to maintained to track with nova. Unless someone can point me to a clean place to splice?

The tests just seemed like the best place to build from. The only real bulk is the new ./tools/simulator directory.

The way I run it is simple:
./run_tests.sh nova.tests.scheduler.test_simulator

bang. done. Hacking is pretty easy. 

$0.02 ... and open to discussion :)"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:01:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

also, as for it being a test, it will still puke on anything other than a NoValidHost exception, which I could consider an integration test.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-03-26 14:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-10 11:44:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

How do I get this out from "abandoned"? I was waiting for Folsom to start.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-04-10 12:51:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Resurrect, Lazarus.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-10 14:53:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Restored

Finished waiting for folsom.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-10 18:18:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

In-line is some thoughts'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-10 18:35:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-10 18:39:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-10 18:58:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-23 15:43:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-23 17:40:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-24 12:15:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-15 16:41:58.000000000', 'message': 'Simulator integration test for Distributed Scheduler

This is the start of an integration test suite for the scheduler.
It will simulate a series of temporal events such as:
- requesting an instance to be created
- bringing that instance from BUILDING to RUNNING
- simulating the keep alive pings on the host services

Currently, the simulator will provision instances of random
flavors until there is a failure. The results will the be dumped
to .../tools/simulator/output/simulator.log and, if jinja2 is installed,
HTML reports will be generated as in:
http://darksecretsoftware.com/static/lines.html
and
http://darksecretsoftware.com/static/gauges.html

This is an interim branch. The next step is to make the configuration
of the simulator possible so you have use your own allotment strategies
and custom/in-house filters/schedulers.

Change-Id: I6a55d2eddb54d9a58b5cdfad7a79a7716dbe8754

commit_message:
Simulator integration test for Distributed Scheduler

This is the start of an integration test suite for the scheduler.

It will simulate a series of temporal events such as:
- requesting an instance to be created
- bringing that instance from BUILDING to RUNNING
- simulating the keep alive pings on the host services

Currently, the simulator will provision instances of random
flavors until there is a failure. The results will the be dumped
to .../tools/simulator/output/simulator.log and, if jinja2 is installed,
HTML reports will be generated as in:
http://darksecretsoftware.com/static/lines.html
and
http://darksecretsoftware.com/static/gauges.html

This is an interim branch. The next step is to make the configuration
of the simulator possible so you have use your own allotment strategies
and custom/in-house filters/schedulers.

Change-Id: I6a55d2eddb54d9a58b5cdfad7a79a7716dbe8754

Add multiprocess support for keystone serivces (public/admin).
For description of this blueprint, please visit:
blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/multiprocess-keystone-service">https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/multiprocess-keystone-service

2012-05-09 v2:
* unittest can now verify whether mutlprocess keystone works correctly.
* XXX Doesn't work with KVS backend.

2012-05-02 v1:
* Modification to wsgi.py/config.py in order to support multiprocess
(a.k.a. workers) for public/admin services. If multiprocess mode is enabled,
(i.e. flags 'SERVICE_workers' set to positive numbers), corresponding
service will run in specified number of process(es). There is also a
master_worker process spawned for managing all workers (handling signal
/termination).

Change-Id: Ib7503063383c9db273305079999606716999ba05
'}]
commit_message:
blueprint multiprocess-keystone-service

Add multiprocess support for keystone serivces (public/admin).
For description of this blueprint, please visit:
blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/multiprocess-keystone-service">https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/multiprocess-keystone-service

2012-05-09 v2:
* unittest can now verify whether mutlprocess keystone works correctly.
* XXX Doesn't work with KVS backend.

2012-05-02 v1:
* Modification to wsgi.py/config.py in order to support multiprocess
(a.k.a. workers) for public/admin services. If multiprocess mode is enabled,
(i.e. flags 'SERVICE_workers' set to positive numbers), corresponding
service will run in specified number of process(es). There is also a
master_worker process spawned for managing all workers (handling signal
/termination).

Change-Id: Ib7503063383c9db273305079999606716999ba05

TempURL/FormPOST is now at http://gholt.github.com/swift-tempurl/

For current users of TempURL/FormPOST, this will require installing the new
package and changing the "use" line of the tempurl and formpost conf section's
to:

[filter:tempurl]
use = egg:swifttempurl#tempurl

[filter:formpost]
use = egg:swifttempurl#formpost

And then 'swift-init proxy reload'.

Change-Id: I5bddf7f9e09ee07815530a41c46ff901fc21b447
'}]
commit_message:
Pulled out TempURL/FormPOST

TempURL/FormPOST is now at http://gholt.github.com/swift-tempurl/

For current users of TempURL/FormPOST, this will require installing the new
package and changing the "use" line of the tempurl and formpost conf section's
to:

[filter:tempurl]
use = egg:swifttempurl#tempurl

[filter:formpost]
use = egg:swifttempurl#formpost

And then 'swift-init proxy reload'.

Change-Id: I5bddf7f9e09ee07815530a41c46ff901fc21b447

This patch adds the `ignore_missing_network_data` flag which will log

Change-Id: Ie11bc9028790c2d1b3de1f4709a9e17a67e06f26

commit_message:
Do not fail on notify when quantum and melange are out of sync.

This patch adds the `ignore_missing_network_data` flag which will log
exceptions rather than raising them when generating usage exists
notifications.

Change-Id: Ie11bc9028790c2d1b3de1f4709a9e17a67e06f26

[{'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-04-25 19:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Emma, can you incorporate Paul's recommendation?  Then we can get this one pushed in. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 2135, 'date': '2012-05-01 06:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-05-02 19:24:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

One super nit on whitespace to make the gate tests pass and then lgtm"}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-05-03 09:08:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

There is a syntax error in the code, in fact several errors, I suspect that it was just copy-paste from Paul's suggestion, and not verified..."}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-05-03 09:40:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In addition:

        ips = {obj.instance_id: obj for obj in floating_ips}

This will not work, as we may have multiple IPs attached to a single instance. In that case this will return a dictionary with instanceid: ip, and we lose the subsequent ips for that instance.
Try this code:


        instances_dict = {obj.id: obj for obj in instances}

        for ip in floating_ips:

            ip.instance_name = instances_dict[ip.instance_id].name \
                if ip.instance_id in instances_dict else None

        return floating_ips'}, {'account_id': 2135, 'date': '2012-05-04 05:41:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2135, 'date': '2012-05-04 05:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-05-04 07:35:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The code now seems to work as expected. I'd like to point to the case when we have two instances with the same name - then attaching two IPs to them will display the same instance name in the table, but it's not clear to see which the actual instance is. I've worked on that in the "Associate IP" form - if we have similar instance names - then show the Id next to the name, to be able to distinguish the instances(see the dropdown for 'select an instance' in Associate IP form). Or we can always show the instance Id as a reference... I'd like to hear what other developers think of that.'}, {'account_id': 2135, 'date': '2012-05-05 22:04:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-05-06 14:20:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-05-07 17:40:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-05-08 18:40:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-08 18:49:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

[{'created': '2012-05-05 00:57:22.000000000', 'message': 'Pulled StaticWeb out to separate project

StaticWeb is now at http://gholt.github.com/swift-staticweb/

For current users of StaticWeb, this will require installing the new
package and changing the "use" line of the staticweb filter conf
section to:

use = egg:swiftstaticweb#middleware

And then 'swift-init proxy reload'.

Change-Id: Iab32adb5927698a667c5c6d6a572c44ca23414eb
'}]
commit_message:
Pulled StaticWeb out to separate project

StaticWeb is now at http://gholt.github.com/swift-staticweb/

For current users of StaticWeb, this will require installing the new
package and changing the "use" line of the staticweb filter conf
section to:

use = egg:swiftstaticweb#middleware

And then 'swift-init proxy reload'.

Change-Id: Iab32adb5927698a667c5c6d6a572c44ca23414eb

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-04 19:58:11.000000000', 'message': 'Remove state altering in live-migration code

 * Stops live migration from checking volume node because it
   will not be accessible if volumes are a separate service
 * Stops state modification of volumes during live migration
   because the volumes are not migrating
 * Partially implements blueprint volume-decoupling

Change-Id: I07bdbc660ff220e2079e643a002c4c6bb5df6db7
'}]
commit_message:
Remove state altering in live-migration code

 * Stops live migration from checking volume node because it
   will not be accessible if volumes are a separate service
 * Stops state modification of volumes during live migration
   because the volumes are not migrating
 * Partially implements blueprint volume-decoupling

Change-Id: I07bdbc660ff220e2079e643a002c4c6bb5df6db7

commit_message:
Find context arg by type rather than by name.

This requires changes to all the tests that were passing
in a string as a bogus context; that seems like an improvement.

Change-Id: Ib8fc83cbda25a1cfa8794b72dc13f666549ef892

commit_message:
Fix bug 983206 : _try_convert parsing string

* _try_convert in ec2utils.py didn't handle strings starting with "0x"
* Added tests to cover bug
* Add better float support
* remove unused complex number support

Change-Id: I382d36f4a8671bcceccfa1ebdbae89a9d2aca207

commit_message:
Minor fixup to keystone service endpoint setup.

Expected outputs were incorrect in two places:
- Missing a % in one case
- Wrong URLs in another case.
- Oh for cry aye aye fix bug 989516 :)

Also changed $(tenant_id) to %(tenant_id) in swift example

(cherry picked from commit 83b2d1cb6caf28f7b95c47e933a44436639d38f2)

Change-Id: I255091fa3b02921fbf9cf2ffde7e46bc8512acdf

commit_message:
Remove instance action logging mechanism

* Remove InstanceActions db model
* Remove relevant db api functions
* Add migration 93 which drops the instance_actions
* Remove server_action_list API extension
* Fixes bug 994846

Change-Id: Ibbd787183034314460f41c84b9ad152655739209

commit_message:
A previous patch decoupled the RPC drivers from the nova.flags, breaking instance audit usage in the process.
This configures the xvpvncproxy to configure the RPC drivers properly with FLAGS so that xvpvncproxy can run.

Change-Id: I71d27a06060120448bd3401ee91566dbc3b6a289

commit_message:
Disallow image uploads in v2 API when data exists

When data has already been uploaded for an image (determined by the existence
of a location attribute), reject any subsequent requests to upload data with
a 409 HTTP error code.

* Related to bp api-v2-image-upload

Change-Id: I0c4d2ebf548862ecb9c760bac9e96348f8377567

subject: Fixes LP #992640 - Volumes sometimes not cleaned
messages:
[{'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-05-04 14:06:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

IMO tempest tests should not just assume that failing api calls are due to insufficient resources. They might just be broken and this test would start being skipped instead of failing in that case. I think it would be better to demand that at least one volume can be created before skipping of attempts to create more fail. 

In theory this issue also affects every test that tries to allocate a resource. We have been assuming that the test target needs to have enough to run tempest."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:34:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

thx for the review David. I'll give it another go and see if I can address your concerns.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-06 19:17:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-06 19:18:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

David, ok, please see updated message -- that only raises a SkipTest IFF one or more volumes were created but all three needed volumes were not created.'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-05-06 21:30:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks, Jay. Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-05-07 12:59:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-05-08 12:53:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-08 12:54:12.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-08 12:54:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-pep8/141/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-merge/181/ : SUCCESS'}]

  the needed 3 1G volumes for the test

"}, {'created': '2012-05-06 19:17:30.000000000', 'message': "Fixes LP #992640 - Volumes sometimes not cleaned

commit_message:
Fixes LP #992640 - Volumes sometimes not cleaned

* Adds some error handling to the volume list test case
  that properly handles the (fairly common) case for when
  Nova's volume group backing file size is too small to create
  the needed 3 1G volumes for the test

Change-Id: Ice367b73303d74c529351d7bd4d9a4e9b1348e07

subject: Use users keystone credentials when using s3 connection
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-30 20:28:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm not convinced this is the right approach.  While we are able to grab the users secret key using the token he provided, I think this is a side effect of the current implementation of keystone.

If we want to solve this properly, I would suggest that we switch to talking to swift via the openstack api, where we can pass along the existing key.  Unfortunately this breaks n-objectstore and places a requirement on using swift to back image registration."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-08 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

commit_message:
Dismissing alerts when a new modal is opened.

This makes it more relatively clear what messages correspond to
what actions.

Fixes Bug #993678

commit_message:
Implement v2 API image tags

* Add image_tags table and new db methods to manage it
* Add appropriate API resource classes
* Implements bp api-v2-image-tags

subject: Implement key pair quotas.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 144, 'name': 'justinsb', 'email': 'justin@fathomdb.com', 'username': 'justin-fathomdb'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-24 16:27:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

All looks really great, but I'd really prefer a much higher default quota than 10.  100 would probably be enough.  500 would be such that we wouldn't have to worry about it.

In PlatformLayer (everything as a service) each service has its own SSH key, per tenant.  It's also very modular, with lots of services, so even a simple stack deployment could rapidly eat up 20 keys.  Then, assume that users might have a few keys, or might even be using something other than PlatformLayer with similar characteristics, and this could become problematic fast.

I don't really know what SSH key upload gets us other than convenience (e.g. when using Horizon).  Perhaps the real answer is that code callers (which don't need the convenience) should just be able to specify the public key directly, rather than registering it first?  Or maybe I should register a key and then immediately delete it once I've created my machine?"}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-24 16:28:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Actually, changing my vote to +0, as it's such a nitpick on such an excellent contribution that it doesn't deserve the negativity of a -1 :-)"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-24 17:17:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Two nits inline... but great work on the tests, Dan. :)"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-24 18:43:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-24 18:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Justin: I bumped the default quota limit to 100.

Jay: Good catches. I corrected the user_id/project_id issue and the variable name too.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-24 19:29:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-04-24 07:03:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Lots of debate in the bug. Will punt on reviewing this for stable until it's in master."}, {'account_id': 1395, 'date': '2012-04-24 19:51:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-04-25 11:53:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Fixes what looks like a pretty serious issue (image corruption when glance is behind a reverse proxy)

And it looks to be particularly important in the case of diablo because it's only broken on essex/folsom where sendfile support isn't supported

Already on master, looks risky but I think that's outweighed by the benefit"}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:48:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-04 20:58:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Can someone verify that this fixes the issue in diablo? I'm also not convinced we need to backport this, as it isn't security-related."}, {'account_id': 1395, 'date': '2012-05-07 10:49:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It definitely fixes the problem. We currently have this patch in our tree. It's not a security fix, granted, but the fact that it silently corrupts data when you do something perfectly reasonable (put glance behind a load-balancer) makes me consider it a strong backport candidate. :)"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-07 17:50:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Omit Content-Length on chunked transfer

Content-Length and Transfer-Encoding conflict according to the HTTP
spec. This fixes bug 981332.

[ This is backported from 223fbee49a55691504623fa691bbb3e48048d5f3 ]

Change-Id: I62f2bcabd9712361dd8837e39a577c4add052d0f

commit_message:
Fix a race with rpc.register_opts in service.py.

Fixes an issue in service.py where rpc.register_opts may not
get called before wait() accesses FLAGS... which can cause
NoneType exceptions with some versions of nova.conf.

Fixes LP Bug #995328.

Change-Id: Ib177c2a082a4cf1c22935c1e6fdf3ba714a33aca

commit_message:
Let OVSQuantumTunnelAgent sync with database

In daemon_loop, db.commit() is required to fetch
updated network status. Without this, ports are
stick to DEAD_VLAN_TAG.

Change-Id: I1a951d60eb75384676309e8db29ea7baa48055bc

messages:
[{'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-07 08:07:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

PrettyTable is still version 0.5 in Ubuntu, but will sync with the new 0.6 (already in Debian) in the next days. This fix can be let hold until then.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-07 14:15:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Could you add the version details to the commit message? i.e. that 0.5 was the version we used before and 0.6 broke the API

Was the get_string() API available in 0.5? If not, you need to add ">=0.6" to tools/pip-requires

Or even better, use get_string() if available and and fallback to printt() if not'}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-07 14:18:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok. I'll update patches with all this suggestions"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-07 15:13:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Also note you'll probably need to add yourself to AUTHORS."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-07 15:42:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

0.5 has get_string() too (in fact, printt was a wrapper around get_string).'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-07 15:57:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah, ok - if get_string() was in 0.5 and there isn't a release before that ... coolness

Would just like more detail in the commit message"}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-07 16:06:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Updated to new prettytable api. Fixes bug 995818

In 0.6, printt() (wrapper to get_string) has been removed.
Updated to use get_string(), backward available since 0.2 release.

Change-Id: Ica292757ec3de5004f27afbc5c8ee11d839421df

The common hunk looks appropriate, but I don't know about the unit test; seems to me that openstack-common code should be thoroughly tested in openstack-common and we shouldn't be as concerned about adding tests in the client projects.  That said, this is really just a nit, so +2"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-07 17:49:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Yeah, I don't want tests for common code in Glance."}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-05-07 23:27:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Monty included the patch to glance/openstack/common/setup.py in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7159. As we don't need the other part, tests, i'm abonding this ticket.

Kevin, Brian: Thank you!"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-07 02:55:17.000000000', 'message': 'Truly handle mailmap entries for all combinations.

Bug: 994957

Mailmap might contain mapping with full name. This commit fixes
it to handle these combinations:
  Foo ZZ <email@foo.com> Bar YY <email@bar.com>
  Foo <email@foo.com> Bar <email@bar.com>
  <email@foo.com> <email@bar.com>

This is inline with mailmap convention described here:
  http://man.github.com/git/git-shortlog.html

* glance/openstack/common/setup.py
  parse_mailmap(): Pull out canonical and alias email addresses.

* glance/tests/unit/test_setup.py
  New test script to cover various combinations in mailmap.

Change-Id: Ie5baba52d21db7c4608a5f7b272060797e68519e
'}]
commit_message:
Truly handle mailmap entries for all combinations.

Bug: 994957

Mailmap might contain mapping with full name. This commit fixes
it to handle these combinations:
  Foo ZZ <email@foo.com> Bar YY <email@bar.com>
  Foo <email@foo.com> Bar <email@bar.com>
  <email@foo.com> <email@bar.com>

This is inline with mailmap convention described here:
  http://man.github.com/git/git-shortlog.html

* glance/openstack/common/setup.py
  parse_mailmap(): Pull out canonical and alias email addresses.

* glance/tests/unit/test_setup.py
  New test script to cover various combinations in mailmap.

subject: Added condition requirement to simplejson
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-30 14:44:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

We don't test the command-line interface at this point, but I think we should. Once write those tests, this change is going to prevent the py2.6 tests from getting the necessary argparse dependency - we don't use setup.py to build the dev environment. I'd rather just install the extra argparse dep on top of py2.7 until we have a better solution for this. 

Go ahead with the simplejson portion of this patch, though. You need to run pep8 and add yourself to Authors."}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-04-30 15:21:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-30 18:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Return 204 from DELETE /v2/images/<image_id>

Fix bug 995224

The v2 API design and normal RESTful idiom would suggest that a
204 No Content status is more appropriate than 200 OK.

Change-Id: Ic5ae3ffa22eafdec0f780d16cceb8ce45c84c854

Update noauth caching pipeline to use unauth-ctx.

unauthenticated-context.

Fixes LP Bug #995323.

commit_message:
Fixes lp978896 -- Session fixation security fix

Rotates session tokens on logout, and properly clears sessions
to prevent data leakage.

Change-Id: I7c4c6fd3e1827d28fceb47b2c5b4c7e2eb4a7963

commit_message:
Allow sitepackages on jenkins.

Since our overall environment on the jenkins slaves is controlled,
it's safe to allow site-packages. BUT - more importantly, it's the
only way to get python-libvirt to be accessed.

Change-Id: I1181127a134afdfc1de58d0ab819395bb8995647

commit_message:
Use ConfigOpts.find_file() for policy and paste

Use cfg's new helper method to find the PasteDeploy and policy config
files. The basic behavior is "look alongside the config file" with a
fall back to the standard default config paths.

In the fairly obscure case where no --config-file is found we use an
explicit default paste file taking to account the fact that all the
glance apps have their paste config in a single file.

Add some new debug logging to make it easier to see which config files
are being loaded.

Fixes bug 992319

Change-Id: I978c4a8cb6ec6d12aaf746af511ccb572c34b7ee

messages:
[{'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-07 08:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

PrettyTable is still version 0.5 in Ubuntu, but will sync with the new 0.6 (already in Debian) in the next days. This fix can be let hold until then.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-07 14:15:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Could you add the version details to the commit message? i.e. that 0.5 was the version we used before and 0.6 broke the API

Was the get_string() API available in 0.5? If not, you need to add ">=0.6" to tools/pip-requires

Or even better, use get_string() if available and and fallback to printt() if not'}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-07 16:51:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-07 21:13:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
Updated to new prettytable api. Fixes bug 995811

In 0.6, printt() (wrapper to get_string) has been removed.
Updated to use get_string(), backward available since 0.2 release.

Change-Id: Ib7b3a9ddb9f759487164287ed8dc5c6246ab7600

subject: Added an internal client.
messages:
[{'account_id': 597, 'date': '2012-03-26 17:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there a reason why expiring_objects_account is not a paramter to InternalClient()? Does not seem to me this flexibility is used.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-03-26 20:13:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Pete, what do you mean?  Are you asking why an account isn't passed to the constructor of InternalClient?"}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-03-27 02:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2012-04-03 04:15:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (10 inline comments)

looks good. some small comments'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-05 04:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-09 16:14:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

_get_metadata() probably shouldn't filter on metadata_key (or default to ''). There is metadata that can be set that doesn't have a specific prefix. (eg X-Object-Manifest, X-Versions-Location, CORS headers set in the object server). This should be similarly exposed in the account/containe/object metadata calls.

_set_metadata should return the response from self.make_request. also create_container, delete_container, delete_object, and upload_object. similar for set_*_metadata.

_iter_items should accept optional start and end markers. imagine storing log files by year/day/month/hour and only needing the last X hours or only needing logs between hours X and Y. That's hard without start and end markers. This should be similarly exposed in the iter_containers and iter_object methods.

why expose acceptable_statuses in container_exists()? it seems confusing. same with upload_object()

iter_object_lines should have a comment explaining the magic numbers passed to zlib.decompressobj."}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-09 21:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-09 22:06:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The acceptable_statuses is fine for the _* methods, but it seems confusing on the public ones. Why have it as a parameter for those?

Also, you set a named parameter to {} in a few places. That's a Bad Thing (tm)."}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-10 14:59:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-10 15:04:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-10 15:25:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-12 19:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-12 19:31:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-12 19:33:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Force prettytable==0.5

prettytable 0.6 was released recently and removed the printt() method.
All non-pinned prettytable projects (all of them) are now broken.  This
forces a pre-loaded prettytable 0.5 package in order to allow the real
fix (removing printt() calls) to proceed.

Change-Id: Iacf24b8474f12b28090329496720767281181d7e

commit_message:
Encapsulate common sdist actions into a cmdclass.

The pattern of running generate_authors and write_git_changelog
at sdist time is (and should be) repeated in all project's setup.py.
Instead of copying the creation of the two classes and injection
of them into a cmdclass dict, we can do it here and have it
be consistent.

Related to bug 986462.

Change-Id: I0b7b44d58685551482f874b2a6091dec29e6bed6

[{'created': '2012-05-07 15:05:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed bug introduced by new PrettyTable version

The new version of PrettyTable (0.6) removes the printt calls into
another type of setup.  This breaks all new Keystone instalations,
I decided to change it to 0.5 instead of changing the implementation
because most distributions come shipped with 0.5 for RPMs/DEBs.

Change-Id: Icfb9e041216a09f698994e8336ba172efe4c942c
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed bug introduced by new PrettyTable version

The new version of PrettyTable (0.6) removes the printt calls into
another type of setup.  This breaks all new Keystone instalations,
I decided to change it to 0.5 instead of changing the implementation
because most distributions come shipped with 0.5 for RPMs/DEBs.

Change-Id: Icfb9e041216a09f698994e8336ba172efe4c942c

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 144, 'name': 'justinsb', 'email': 'justin@fathomdb.com', 'username': 'justin-fathomdb'}, {'_account_id': 438, 'name': 'dizz', 'email': 'andy@edmonds.be', 'username': 'andy-edmonds'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-10 16:36:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(27 inline comments)

Please see in-line comments; there are a ton of problems that need to be corrected.  Note that I stopped reviewing when I got to about nova/api/occi/extensions/openstack.py.  Also note that I have not made an attempt to comment on every single problem; when you correct a problem I have pointed out, make sure you also check all the rest of your code for the same or similar problems and correct them all."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-10 16:39:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, can you update your commit message? See http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritWorkflow for more details on how to format the commit message.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-10 18:53:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

What does OCCI do for OpenStack?

Within a few months there will be more public clouds using the OpenStack API than are using any other cloud API.  The OpenStack API _is_ the cross-cloud standard.  If you want to influence the direction of the cross-cloud standard, please propose discussions, blueprints & patches to the OpenStack API.

I do understand why OCCI wants into OpenStack though!  I'm sure Amazon will want to contribute a 100% compatible EC2 implementation before too long as well, but I'll -1 that as well!"}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-11 21:24:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-11 21:31:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (27 inline comments)

Kevin, as requested. Also I've gone through the rest of the code based on your initial comments and the HACKING file.
Johannes, commit message as requested."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-11 21:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The summary of your commit is "Signed-off-by: Andy Edmonds <andy@edmonds.be>"; this conveys no useful information to us.  I suspect that's the largest part of what Johannes was asking be updated.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-11 22:14:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (8 inline comments)

And, having had a chance to skim your changes, there are several more problems to address.  Please be aware that this is exactly what I describe it as: a skim, not a full in-depth review, not yet.  Oh, and you will need to add yourself to Authors.

I also recommend running the test suite prior to "git review"; a couple of the problems I've pointed out (including the lack of an Authors entry) would be pointed out by some of the tests in the test suite.  To run the test suite, the easiest thing to do is "./run_tests.sh".'}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-13 15:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-13 15:04:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (8 inline comments)

All requested changes done and throughout all other files.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-13 16:05:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(6 inline comments)

See inline.  Also, the unit tests failed for me:

    ======================================================================
    ERROR: Failure: ImportError (No module named occi)
    ----------------------------------------------------------------------
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/home/klmitch/devel/src/nova/.venv/lib/python2.6/site-packages/nose/loader.py", line 390, in loadTestsFromName
        addr.filename, addr.module)
      File "/home/klmitch/devel/src/nova/.venv/lib/python2.6/site-packages/nose/importer.py", line 39, in importFromPath
        return self.importFromDir(dir_path, fqname)
      File "/home/klmitch/devel/src/nova/.venv/lib/python2.6/site-packages/nose/importer.py", line 86, in importFromDir
        mod = load_module(part_fqname, fh, filename, desc)
      File "/home/klmitch/devel/src/nova/nova/tests/api/occi/__init__.py", line 19, in <module>
        from occi import core_model
    ImportError: No module named occi

Obviously, occi is not installed on my dev box, nor do I think it should be required to be, so it will be necessary to employ the appropriate skip decorators.  (This also argues for the occi interface not being in the list of default-start interfaces)

On the plus side, PEP8 looks clean, aside from a number of spurious errors (which I've already entered a bug report for) that have little to do with your patch.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-13 16:41:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not submit

I haven't seen much of a discussion around this and the blueprint you're working off of is not approved. We really need to weigh the pros and cons of supporting yet another API before this lands."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-13 17:13:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

OCCI sounds like it has some big names behind it, so I'm not opposed to supporting it if it brings significant adoption.  However, as Brian says, we should definitely discuss this e.g. at the Design Summit, and figure out whether & how to support it.  A good option might be to support it in a proxy layer, for example, writing to the OpenStack API; I can't see anyone objecting to a separate project that would do that, and it could be integrated in future if there is reason to do so.  But we simply need to learn more about OCCI & agree a way forward as a community."}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-13 19:05:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (6 inline comments)

Kevin: all requested changes done. I've placed skip functionality within the tests. Also I'll retract the changes to auto-starting the API.

Brian: I had sent an email to the main OS mailing list however it seems that it was bounced. I'll resend. In the mail, I wrote: By having this API exposed out of OpenStack, large projects such as FutureGrid [4], EGI FedCloud [5], FIware [6] and CompatibleOne [7] (as well as others some listed here [8]) can leverage OpenStack as an infrastructure platform and in so growing the OpenStack community even more! This also has the backing of recommendations from the UK [9] and German Governments [10]. Details of what it can do can be found in the OpenStack wiki [11]. This is work that has been carried out by Intel Labs Europe in the Cloud Service Lab and is partially funded by FIware [6] and echoes much of what Thierry Carrez wrote in his recent blog post [12]. 

Justin: I agree with you on getting more information to the OS community That's a possibly good idea however and more discussion will certainly throw more light on to it. Our want is for more adoption of OpenStack through OCCI.

All: Further, there are a number of people looking to utilise the unconference facilities at next week's design summit where further discussion can happen. It would be super if you  (and more :-)) could attend this, especially from the aspect of learning more.

[1]  http://www.occi-wg.org
[2]  https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/bexar-open-cloud-compute-interface
[3]  https://review.openstack.org/6410
[4]  http://www.future-grid.org
[5]  https://wiki.egi.eu/wiki/Fedcloud-tf:FederatedCloudsTaskForce
[6]  http://www.fi-ware.eu
[7]  http://www.compatibleone.org
[8]  http://occi-wg.org/community/implementations/
[9]  http://occi-wg.org/2011/02/21/occi-and-the-uk-government-cloud/
[10]  http://occi-wg.org/2012/03/18/german-government-recognises-occi-as-leading-the-cloud-standards-arena/
[11] http://wiki.openstack.org/occi
[12] http://fnords.wordpress.com/2012/04/04/ask-not-what-openstack-can-do-for-you/"}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-13 19:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-13 19:59:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

Thank you for the skip_if() decorators!  However, I realized there were some other import ordering problems still in your patch.  I've marked two instances, but please check through and make sure you address ones I've failed to see.

(Sorry to keep harping on HACKING.rst violations, here)

Also note that I won't +1 or +2 this patch until the discussion on the blueprint has concluded, but I will continue to try to review it as you upload new patch sets"}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-13 20:21:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

Thanks for pointing out the imports Kevin! I found and zapped a few more stragglers.'}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-13 20:21:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-13 21:51:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I'm going to save on commenting on this until after the summit when we can determine where extra apis should go."}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-13 21:55:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Vish: there's an unconference session being organised to introduce, discuss OCCI both for the interested and the sceptics :-) Can you tell me what session will discuss positioning of extra APIs?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-13 22:00:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Excellent!  Thanks for bearing with my nitpicking :)  Also, Smokestack seems to indicate that the unit tests run fine, now.  I'll give this another look after we decide what to do with APIs"}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-13 23:58:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks for your help so far Kevin! The 'nit-picking' was appreciated :-)"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-14 04:38:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

we've compressed the api discussion into this session:

http://summit.openstack.org/sessions/view/64

It is intially focused on the ec2_api but the main discussion will be on how we manage third party apis in relation to the core code base."}, {'account_id': 438, 'date': '2012-04-17 11:09:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks Vish!

Chaps, just a little reminder: as a number of you had questions during the last week, there'll be an unconference session on Wednesday where you can get more info. Details of it are in the unconference etherpad: http://etherpad.openstack.org/folsom-unconference-proposals

It would be great to have you there!

It is implemented using both the OpenStack service and WSGI frameworks. On
start it will serve its functionality over HTTP on port 8787 as described

commit_message:
Adds OCCI support.

Implements blueprint bexar-open-cloud-compute-interface.

This implements an OpenStack service that runs out of nova-api.
It is implemented using both the OpenStack service and WSGI frameworks. On
start it will serve its functionality over HTTP on port 8787 as described
in the OCCI specifications. It is compliant as per the set of OCCI
specifications (GFD.183, GFD.184 and GFD.185) and implements all mandatory
features. It also leverages the OCCI core model to expose OpenStack-specific
features in an OCCI fashion. There is further detail on its core and OpenStack
specific usage at http://wiki.openstack.org/occi. The implementation is
co-funded by Intel Labs Europe Cloud Services Lab and FI-ware.

Signed-off-by: Andy Edmonds <andy@edmonds.be>
Change-Id: I402cdee80b42c8b12f4c6e954187fa544f959b4f

commit_message:
Truly handle mailmap entries for all combinations.

Bug: 994957

Mailmap might contain mapping with full name. This commit fixes
it to handle these combinations:
  Foo ZZ <email@foo.com> Bar YY <email@bar.com>
  Foo <email@foo.com> Bar <email@bar.com>
  <email@foo.com> <email@bar.com>

This is inline with mailmap convention described here:
  http://man.github.com/git/git-shortlog.html

* openstack/common/setup.py
  parse_mailmap(): Pull out canonical and alias email addresses.

Change-Id: Iabe9612efecbd18f7a5b0725de7d2515ab24125d

[{'created': '2012-04-27 06:50:35.000000000', 'message': "fix errors in while creation of keypairs.

Description: nova keypair-delete <keypair_name> is not able to delete
keypairs which are having the special characteres('.','/','#') in that
name. so i made some changes in keypair.py file create() method which
is not allow the keypair name as following above characters.By putting
if conditon in the keypair.py file we can stop the creation of keypair
names consisting of above character.Previouly i commited same bug using
regular expression instead of if condition.This time i am using if
condition to avoid those special characters.

Fixes BUG 894808

Change-Id: I7830dcc9bc1de14c03da642ba71faf349e2743cf
"}]
commit_message:
fix errors in while creation of keypairs.

Description: nova keypair-delete <keypair_name> is not able to delete
keypairs which are having the special characteres('.','/','#') in that
name. so i made some changes in keypair.py file create() method which
is not allow the keypair name as following above characters.By putting
if conditon in the keypair.py file we can stop the creation of keypair
names consisting of above character.Previouly i commited same bug using
regular expression instead of if condition.This time i am using if
condition to avoid those special characters.

Fixes BUG 894808

Change-Id: I7830dcc9bc1de14c03da642ba71faf349e2743cf

subject: return the full response from FakeAppObject
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-26 05:04:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Abandon this review because it seems to be a duplicate of I18a6eac497b24338af4d82a568484b0fc9d97382 ?"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-26 15:15:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah okay, a backport. Different question then: Do we really need to backport a unit test change?'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:58:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Forgot to change my review rating, sorry. I had the question, but the answer wasn't really important to the approval. :)

(Also, I can't +2 this change for some reason; I assume because of the backport status)"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-27 08:28:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks, gholt.

For your question: We're currently following stable/essex with our packages and we would really prefer not having to create our own git repository with fixes, but rather continue to push everything upstream. Since testsuite fixes don't affect any users, only developers I think they're good candidates for backporting especially since after the stable release there will probably be a lot of other downstreams packaging openstack, in one form or another, and testing them on different systems where these bugs might pop-up."}, {'account_id': 2400, 'date': '2012-04-27 09:10:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This backport makes a difference between unit tests failing or passing with WebOb-1.1.1 (the bug mentions WebOb 1.2b3 but that has some unresolved failures).'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-27 13:48:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

I forwarded this up through the chain to the OpenStack powers-that-be to clarify things for us.

First question is: What's the process for backporting?

Second question is: What kind of things are backported?

The Swift project has historically made stable releases much more often than just once every six months -- usually once a month if my memory serves. If that is to continue, I would recommend we only backport security fixes since a new stable bugfix release is just waiting a month away at most (even sooner if it's a real thorn).

But, if OpenStack has decided to only make a stable release every six months, then it makes perfect sense to backport many bugfixes otherwise packagers and other folks might not be able to use the product until the next six month release.

I guess I'll change my review to 0 for now, until clarification comes back."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-27 17:09:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The Openstack guidelines for patches to stable branches is outlined at http://wiki.openstack.org/StableBranch

Based on that document, and taking into account that swift releases are frequent, prod-ready, and there is a migration path for them, I am marking this patch -1."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-05 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-05 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

Add Identity to ClientManager

* Make the Identity client in identity.client.make_client()
* Auth via ClientManager.identity
* Skip extra auth roundtrip in compute client

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3787/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-04 19:52:02.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-04 21:33:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This change looks fine, but I don't understand why it fixes it.  Here's a copy of a comment I just left on the bug:

"I've been running the tests a bunch, both individual tests and the whole test suite, and never saw a problem. :-(

I'm wondering why the line " FLAGS.register_opts(rpc.rpc_opts)" that comes just a few lines above the line you're adding didn't avoid this problem. The only difference is that this line would also call into whatever rpc_backend is configured and let it register anything it wants to, as well. Since fake_flags is loaded at this point, it's going to call into nova.rpc.impl_fake, which doesn't register anything...."'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-04 21:39:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Nevermind, I see what this fixes.  Sorry, carry on.  *puts a quarter in the broke-the-tests jar*'}]

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-01 19:34:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm really surprised you don't like using sudo NOPASSWD.

Regardless. This works for me. :)"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-01 20:00:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm trying to understand why changing run_as_root to False makes this work. Wouldn't that imply that the code doesn't need root to run successfully?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-01 20:14:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Looking a bit deeper, it appears to be because of _chown_console_log_for_instance in nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py. It calls chown with run_as_root=True.

Changing run_as_root to False works because it calls chown on a file already owned by the user.

Maybe stubbing out _chown_console_log_for_instance would make more sense?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-01 21:16:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

We already have a fake_libvirt_utils for stubbing out chown.

Can we either?

a) use fake_libvirt_utils (which has a definition of chown that just passes)

b) stub out libvirt.utils.chown

Stubbing out execute and changing run as root just seems dirty."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-01 21:24:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, it would be nice if we could change the config on the Jenkins systems to not allow tests that require sudo to pass. Would I open up a bug on openstack-ci about that?'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-01 22:47:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yea, then we also need to stub out:

_flush_libvirt_console for one of the tests.. because it also does a execute(...., run_as_root=True).'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-02 02:20:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

AFAICT. The reason this got through passed both Jenkins and SmokeStack unit tests initially is because we don't actually run *some* of the libvirt tests. We know this because the log files contain this for the libvirt console tests:

SKIP: Test requires libvirt

Johannes: FYI. In SmokeStack I actually alias 'sudo' to '/bin/false' so that tests which call sudo will fail. Because I'm running tests in a venv they didn't detect libvirt was installed however so it slipped through.

So the issue here is we need to get libvirt (and Qpid for that matter) installed such that those tests run..."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-02 02:22:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Vish: If we really don't want unit tests to 'shell out' w/ execute why don't we just stub it out globally.

To be honest I didn't realize this was the rule. Calling sudo is naughty... but when I wrote the initial unit tests I actually liked that the 'chown' and 'dd' operations were getting flexed."}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-05-02 12:19:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

We don't actually need libvirt for these tests to run. We need to make them use the fake libvirt I wrote. When I implemented it, it was complete enough to make the libvirt driver happy.

As for this change, I'm too in favour of using the functionality in libvirt.utils and relying on the fakes in fake_libvirt_utils for tests."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-02 21:02:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok, so then these tests need to completely change I guess.   Otherwise, I'll just be creating a stub for execute('dd') that reads a file... which seems kinda dumb and pointless when we could certainly test that the 'dd' is correct.  (I guess I'm re-stating Dan's point a bit)."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-02 21:05:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Can someone take this over?  I'll prob just abandon this and un-assign myself from the bug so someone else can fix the tests, I guess.  I don't have time to dig into the fake libvirt stuff, which I'm not familiar with.."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-03 00:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Chris, assign it to me. I Wrote the initial tests so I am familiar with it.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-03 05:24:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Done!  Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-03 14:12:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-03 14:14:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-03 14:16:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

comstud: Just posted patch 2.

I did a couple based on the comments so far:

1) These tests don't require libvirt... so I removed the skips.

2) I switched over to use fake_libvirt_utils. To do this I had to stub in a simple load_file function (which is required for the tests to pass).

3) I put in a fake _flush_libvirt_console function.

With these 3 changes the tests now run fine without making use of sudo.

Let me know if everyone is agreeable with this approach."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-03 22:12:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-03 22:46:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-04 00:32:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3848/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2390/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/2050/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3783/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-04 10:39:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Smokestack showed up the unit test failure and then, predictably, Jenkins hit it too :)

  ERROR: test_get_console_output (nova.tests.test_virt_drivers.LibvirtConnTestCase)
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/home/jenkins/workspace/gate-nova-unittests/nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py", line 43, in wrapped_func
      return f(self, *args, **kwargs)
    File "/home/jenkins/workspace/gate-nova-unittests/nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py", line 292, in test_get_console_output
      console_output = self.connection.get_console_output(instance_ref)
    File "/home/jenkins/workspace/gate-nova-unittests/nova/exception.py", line 114, in wrapped
      return f(*args, **kw)
    File "/home/jenkins/workspace/gate-nova-unittests/nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py", line 980, in get_console_output
      return libvirt_utils.load_file(path)
    File "/home/jenkins/workspace/gate-nova-unittests/nova/tests/fake_libvirt_utils.py", line 92, in load_file
      with open(path, 'r+') as fp:
  IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'dummy.log''}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 14:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 14:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Okay. I made one more slight adjustment to the fake_libvirt_utils.load_file so that it handles missing files (just like it did before!).

I feel like it might be better if the fake *matched* the real load_file function... but that would involve quite a bit more changes to get the existing test_virt_driver tests to properly write the console and rescue files within the test cases. We can do that... but I think its sufficient to get this in now and work on improving those tests in a separate commit.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-04 20:14:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

nice patch'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-04 20:38:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

nice'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-04 20:59:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3789/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-04 20:59:04.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Use fake_libvirt_utils for libvirt console tests.

Updates test_libvirt.py so that it users fake_libvirt_utils.

This resolves an issue where the previous tests required
sudo to properly execute.

Fixes LP Bug #992805.

Change-Id: I9354b8facf82fb861dc2fe6da5fca102d8a33fbf

commit_message:
Add instance_system_metadata modeling.

Implements blueprint instance-system-metadata.

Adds a new table to store system-owned metadata tied to an instance. The
intent is to provide a key/value store that compute plugins can use to
persist state.

Change-Id: Ic446fea0f9c8a652f2ac6d554f4f85021ce34fb8
