messages:
[{'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-04-24 13:31:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

While your change is fine, with my "end user" hat on, I tend to prefer to read ChangeLog files which have the "traditional" style, rather than raw version control logs. The GNULIB project has a very handy (GPLv3 licensed) standalone script you might like to consider using:

  http://git.savannah.gnu.org/gitweb/?p=gnulib.git;a=blob;f=build-aux/gitlog-to-changelog;hb=HEAD

It can be run thus:

# git log | ~/src/virt/libvirt/build-aux/gitlog-to-changelog 

  2012-03-27  Jenkins  <jenkins@review.openstack.org>

        Merge "Support owner paramater to glance add"

  2012-03-27  Eoghan Glynn  <eglynn@redhat.com>

        Support owner paramater to glance add
        Fixes bug 962998

        Allow the owner to specified as a first class image attribute
        when creating a new image via the CLI, as it is currently for
        image update.

        Also added a simple fakeauth pipeline to allow the user, tenant
        and admin status of API requests to be easily controlled by
        functional tests.

        Change-Id: I0f83d55d4a96ad3632fb238ad1758ec3f00ed3fd

  2012-03-26  Jenkins  <jenkins@review.openstack.org>

        Merge "Adding versioned namespaces in test dir"
  ...snip...'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-04-24 14:00:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

There is a write_git_changelog() in openstack.common that should be used for this.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-01 02:00:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The only path forward here is to use the function in glance.openstack.common.setup... Chuck, do you feel comfortable doing that?'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-05-01 20:11:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:32:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Inline comments... also the vcsversion stuff is needed...

Simpler thing is just for me to push up a fixed version here -- sorry, I should have just done that originally.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:46:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-05-03 13:44:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2012-05-03 00:25:49.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed inconsistent end_marker

The listing of containers was inclusive whereas the listing of
objects was exclusive. I searched and searched and only found
end_marker usage with listings of objects so I changed the listings
of containers to match that.

Change-Id: Ia8eb66a7ceaef28c698e2d4e19dd5dfd9197a911
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed inconsistent end_marker

The listing of containers was inclusive whereas the listing of
objects was exclusive. I searched and searched and only found
end_marker usage with listings of objects so I changed the listings
of containers to match that.

Change-Id: Ia8eb66a7ceaef28c698e2d4e19dd5dfd9197a911

subject: Default auto-increment for int primary key columns
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is the kind of stuff I was worried about :('}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

FTR. Python migrate should automatically setup the autoincrement option if the column is a primary key for MySQL. For PostgreSQL it should use a sequence.

Here is what I get using the compacted migration:


mysql> desc s3_images;
+------------+-------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| Field      | Type        | Null | Key | Default | Extra          |
+------------+-------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| created_at | datetime    | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| updated_at | datetime    | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| deleted_at | datetime    | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| deleted    | tinyint(1)  | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| id         | int(11)     | NO   | PRI | NULL    | auto_increment |
| uuid       | varchar(36) | NO   |     | NULL    |                |
+------------+-------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:24:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Eoghan,

As we just talked on IRC... The compressed migrations make better use of the python-migrate defaults.

This certainly doesn't hurt anything but it isn't required."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:25:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Eoghan, what database are you using and what version of sqlalchemy-migrate are you using?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Yeah. I'm gonna say we don't need this. We rely on autoincrement for a good number of our tables.

In the old migration scripts the only few of the tables listed it explicitly however (with s3_images being one of them). We don't need this option.

In my oppinion, if we want to add it to be explicit we should instead add it to all the tables.

Honestly, As I was doing the compression I was considering that we might even start a HACKING or "best practices" guide for our migrations. We've had some stylistic differences which seems to lead to confusion.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:57:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Dan

So I guess the converse logic should apply, i.e. the explicit autoincrement=True flag should be removed from the int primary key sqlalchemy.Columns where its currently set?

e.g. aggregates.id, block_device_mapping.id etc.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:03:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Eoghan,

Exactly. We should standardize on doing it one way or the other. Obviously I missed a couple so cleaning those up would be fine.

To be clear (so people aren't alarmed) the existence or absence of them doesn't hurt anything or make an actual difference in the generated MySQL/PostgreSQL schemas."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:04:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To clarify my last comment. The "existence or absence of them" only applies if the column is also a primary_key.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:22:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:23:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Changed patch to remove unnecessary explicit setting of the autoincrement flag on integer primary key columns.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:29:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Until there is a migration best practices, can you add a quick comment about auto increment being the default for primary key integer columns? It'll save some confusion and research for people looking at this in the future."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:33:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Eoghan,

Nice. Thanks for standardizing things!'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Comment added as requested.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 16:50:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Nice. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-04 17:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3852/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2392/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/2052/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3785/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-04 17:07:33.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

'}, {'created': '2012-05-04 16:43:41.000000000', 'message': 'Default auto-increment for int primary key columns

Consistently rely on the default auto-increment flag for integral
primary key columns (rather than being explicit in some cases and
implicit elsewhere).

Change-Id: I5da89b286b199b0ddb709ca882699e9419ec68e0
'}]
commit_message:
Default auto-increment for int primary key columns

Consistently rely on the default auto-increment flag for integral
primary key columns (rather than being explicit in some cases and
implicit elsewhere).

Change-Id: I5da89b286b199b0ddb709ca882699e9419ec68e0

commit_message:
Fix "help" command and implement "list server" and "show server"

blueprint client-manager
blueprint nova-client
bug 992841

Move the authentication logic into a new ClientManager class so that only commands that need to authenticate will trigger that code.
Implement "list server" and "show server" commands as examples of using the ClientManager, Lister, and ShowOne classes.

Change-Id: I9845b70b33bae4b193dbe41871bf0ca8e286a727

commit_message:
Fix test_mysql_innodb

If the default table engine in MySQL wasn't set to be InnoDB,
then the sqlalchemy migration version table would cause
'test_mysql_innodb' to fail.

Change-Id: I38787d4c3e3f2896fdc349d6f7817d3ef78cc2a5

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-04 03:36:57.000000000', 'message': "Added associated_projects.rst

In the interest of keeping the core Swift code repository less
complex, but still offering a quick way to find associated projects
that enhance or use Swift, I've added this new Associated Projects
page prominently to the Swift documentation.

This will allow much less barrier to entry on enhancing Swift as
other projects can work independently and will only need to wait on
the core Swift project for approval of minimal tweaks to the core
Swift code base.

It will also allow an easy central place to find cool associated
projects that otherwise might go unnoticed or even duplicated.

The plan is to move non-essential projects that are currently
embedded in the Swift repository out into their own projects with
links to them on this new page. This would include items such as
(just what I can think of right now): bin/swift command line tool and
clients, swift-bench, swift-dispersion, TempURL, FormPost, StaticWeb,
Rate Limiting, Swift3, Domain Remap, and CNAME Lookup.

After all that is done, those projects will be able to move forward
much more quickly and new developers for Swift itself will have much
less to learn and get confused about.

Change-Id: Ib8447d8bd480f0a3d8f0413137ccdba73a11dd91
"}]
commit_message:
Added associated_projects.rst

In the interest of keeping the core Swift code repository less
complex, but still offering a quick way to find associated projects
that enhance or use Swift, I've added this new Associated Projects
page prominently to the Swift documentation.

This will allow much less barrier to entry on enhancing Swift as
other projects can work independently and will only need to wait on
the core Swift project for approval of minimal tweaks to the core
Swift code base.

It will also allow an easy central place to find cool associated
projects that otherwise might go unnoticed or even duplicated.

The plan is to move non-essential projects that are currently
embedded in the Swift repository out into their own projects with
links to them on this new page. This would include items such as
(just what I can think of right now): bin/swift command line tool and
clients, swift-bench, swift-dispersion, TempURL, FormPost, StaticWeb,
Rate Limiting, Swift3, Domain Remap, and CNAME Lookup.

After all that is done, those projects will be able to move forward
much more quickly and new developers for Swift itself will have much
less to learn and get confused about.

Change-Id: Ib8447d8bd480f0a3d8f0413137ccdba73a11dd91

subject: Compact pre-Folsom database migrations.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 1711, 'name': 'Yun Mao', 'email': 'yunmao@gmail.com', 'username': 'yunmao'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:46:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-30 16:36:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

How do we know for sure that removing all of the MySQL and SQLite specific migration scripts will result in the same behavior?"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-30 16:40:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Johannes,

I'm working on a script tool which I will post on a wiki page to diff the old migrations vs. the new migrations.

Once I get that done I'll update this merge proposal and change it from WIP (work in progress)."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:30:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-05-02 12:42:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

1. I also wonder about the engine specific code. How is it that that is suddenly no longer necessary?

2. The way we do this stuff in Debian style packaging (when certain quirks need to be applied during upgrades), is that we drop the migration code when it's no longer needed for any supported migration path.

In more concrete terms: Migration script 080 (picked at random) is needed for people who:

 * want to upgrade from Diablo to Essex
or
 * want to upgrade from a pre-release of Essex to Essex final.

For anyone wanting to upgrade from Essex and onwards, it serves no purpose as a separate migration.

As such, I believe this compaction should happen *post*-release, not at RC time (which was suggested on the mailing list). This leaves us with the entire release cycle to test new migration code thoroughly.

In summary: If you can either
a. convincingly argue that engine specific code is no longer necessary
and/or
b. provide ways to test this (and future migration code) on at least PostgreSQL, MySQL and SQLite,

then I'm happy with this change, and would support similar compactions early in the G-cycle as well.

Good job. I can only imagine how little fun it was to go through all those migration scripts and summarize them like this (documenting your methodology in the commit message for future reference would be awesome, btw)."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-02 18:51:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-02 19:21:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:22:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:25:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Okay. I've made some notes on my testing process here:

http://wiki.openstack.org/database_migration_testing

As things currently stand MySQL and PostgreSQL are *exactly* the same with and without the compacted migration. Sqlite has a few differences... indexes for example. Test are passing however and I'm not sure its worth fine tuning indexes on a database that... well arguably isn't going to be use in production anyway.

Let me know your thoughts. I'd like to get this in sooner rather than later."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:36:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for the testing notes.  I'm ok with sqlite having small differences in indexes. I don't think anyone is using sqlite for anything other then testing anyway."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:41:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm happy to see the work to confirm the schema is migrated correctly, but I think we also need to confirm that data is migrated correctly as well."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:51:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: No score

So it hit me that since this merged migration is only for new installs and is the first step, so the only data will be the instance_types defaults.

Can you explain why the MySQL character set is commented out for many of the tables? Is this because it was inconsistently used before?

Also, your note about dns_domains says "this is wrong" but yet the testing showed it to be identical. Do you know what's up with that?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:51:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Johannes,

I'm not sure how you would test what you are calling a "data migration". This change set will only effect *new* database installations (from scratch/no data, etc)

Any existing installations are guaranteed to be at migration level 082 (essex) meaning they won't be touched by code in the 082 migration in this branch.

If I'm missing something let me know and I'm happy to test it however.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-03 01:50:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Hi Johannes,

I documented the issue with dns_domains in this ticket:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/993663

Essentially that table is the *only* table in the Nova Essex schema that requires the 'utf8' charset w/ MySQL. It can't be converted to UTF8 due to the fact that its primary key is so large.

I left the mysql_charset comments in place because that is how we should actually be creating MySQL tables to begin with. Looping over the tables and converting them after the fact is unfortunately both convoluted... but seems to be the most concise way to shim that table into the mostly utf8 MySQL schema.

During the Folsom release cycle hopefully we can fix this... then the next time we compact things it should go away.

I'll update this patchset with links to LP tickets for future reference."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-03 01:58:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-03 14:18:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for the hard work and explanations in getting this ready.

I'm personally fine with the differences in SQLite since it shouldn't be used in production (out of scope of this patch, but is that documented anywhere?)"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:39:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

nice work Dan!
+2 so it's ready for approval."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-03 18:00:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Sort of wish we didn't have to do this, e.g that there was support for a `schema.rb` style coalesced-schema.

But since that isn't in the cards for the time being, this is major step-forward.

Awesome job Dan!"}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-05-03 19:17:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

You might want to consider to remove nova/tests/db/nova.austin.sqlite as well while we are on the db topic. It looks like it's useless to me."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-03 21:00:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3835/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2387/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/2047/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3780/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-03 21:00:11.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:16:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Dan, do you know why the schema diff ended up missing the auto increment for the s3_images table?

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7120/'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Python migrate should automatically set this up if it is a primary key. From my testing auto_increment is still set:


mysql> desc s3_images;
+------------+-------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| Field      | Type        | Null | Key | Default | Extra          |
+------------+-------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| created_at | datetime    | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| updated_at | datetime    | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| deleted_at | datetime    | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| deleted    | tinyint(1)  | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| id         | int(11)     | NO   | PRI | NULL    | auto_increment |
| uuid       | varchar(36) | NO   |     | NULL    |                |
+------------+-------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+'}]

commit_message:
Compact pre-Folsom database migrations.

Compacts the pre-Folsom database migrations into
a single migration (082_essex.py).

Pre-Folsom users will need to upgrade to Essex before
running any Folsom migrations.

Implements blueprint db-migration-cleanup.

Testing notes available at:

http://wiki.openstack.org/database_migration_testing

Change-Id: I64c06a3adcf83d6d723c4c11001544ba97668413

Few inline comments...

Also, I'm getting these when my devstack environment doesn't have Quantum installed. Might be better to skip the tests if Quantum is not an endpoint returned in Keystone:

 ======================================================================

    raise exceptions.EndpointNotFound(service)
EndpointNotFound: Endpoint not found
Details: network'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-03-27 03:02:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Can do. I would hope people would look before leaping on what tests they run, but staying on the safe side never hurts'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-03-28 03:25:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm looking through this and I can't think of an immediate non-hackish way of skipping the Quantum tests if Quantum isn't installed. The only straightforward approach that comes to mind is catching an exception of creation of it's clients fail. To do this cleanly, it seems like we would have to handle this earlier than the test level, which might require some significant changes to how the tests are run. Do you have any suggestions?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-28 13:58:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Daryl!

Yeah, I know that it can seem hacky. Check out how I did the same for the Glance tests. Basically, there's a check in the main test file (tempest/tests/image/test_images.py that first checks for an ImportError with the Glance client and sets a module-level variable:

 GLANCE_INSTALLED = False
 try:
     from glance import client
     from glance.common import exception
     GLANCE_INSTALLED = True
 except ImportError:
     pass

And then in the test setup:

    @classmethod
    def setUpClass(cls):
        if not GLANCE_INSTALLED:
            raise SkipTest('Glance not installed')

This seems to work OK...

-jay"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Daryl: I want this change, and I appreciate the effort you put into doing it.  Going forward things can be done differently, but all the hard work you've put in is not wasted effort.  Getting tempest tests running for quantum is huge!  

I can understand if you're simply fed up.  I've personally had more than a few reviews die for lack of agreement on whether the approach is right, and it was extremely frustrating.  If you've reached your limit, please say so and someone else can take over responsibility for landing this change."}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2012-05-04 04:20:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'd second Maru's views. Great work on this branch Daryl, and if you're tied up, is it ok if we take this up? We have a bunch of Quantum and Quantum-client dependent tests to submit for review. :)"}]

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/270/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Overall, looks great.  One thing to note is that this introduces new mandatory parameters to the config files for the OVS plugin and the Bridge plugin, meaning if people update their code but have existing config files, the code will puke.  Avoiding this would be nice, particularly as it will happen for everyone using devstack.  

Nova's config system has the property that all config options have a default embedding in the code, which avoids this.   We don't have quite the same capability here, as such defaults would be scattered throughout the file.  

Thoughts on this?"}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

Thanks for doing this Gary, great work, thanks! One comment inline.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/280/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I believe master for ovs + linux bridge plugins are broken without this patch due to the (AttributeError: 'Logger' object has no attribute 'basicConfig') issue, and this branch fixes it.  Since it seems like remaining concerns are stylistic, Maru approves, and my tests are passing, I'm going to push :) 

If other style concerns exist, we can address them in a subsequent patch.  Thanks."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(13 inline comments)

Good work.

I would like to see extraction of the db reconnection code into a separate class rather than adding yet more functionality to the already cluttered daemon-loop functions.  The class could then be shared between the OVS Agent and TunnelAgent and the LinuxBridge Agent.  (DRY and separation of concerns)"}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (8 inline comments)

garyk: Minor nits to fix, but I think it's good overall.  

As per your email to the list, if the agents are to continue in their present form (debatable), access to a central db, including error handling and connection management, should be factored out of the agents, done properly, and shared."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Very minor nit - please perform int conversion of the polling and reconnect intervals as part of configuration.  Otherwise, looks good."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(3 inline comments)

Minor nits (suggestions really) but otherwise looks good.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

+1 to gongysh's recommendations.  I was ignoring HACKING compliance until that change had landed, but now that it has we all need to be more diligent in our reviews."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

garyk:

While it may be a good principle to trap errors as close as possible to where they occur, religiously adhering to principles isn't always a good idea.  In this case, mixing error handling state and data in the return values hurts clarity and maintainability, and I would like to see either a reversion to the previous usage of instance-level state or a switch to an approach such that no handling is done at all in the subordinate functions and specific db errors (not just Exception) are trapped in a global try/except in daemon_loop.  

I apologize for the mixed messages i.e. indicating that I agreed with all of gongysh's suggesions, when I clearly hadn't considered the implications, and I appreciate your willingness to get this patch into shape.  :)"}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

LGTM.  The code under review will be rewritten in the short term, so I suggest that other reviewers focus on substance rather than style.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(9 inline comments)

Sorry, I think we can make it better. Please see comments"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (6 inline comments)

Thanks for the jobs. But I think we can be better. I suggest we submit one more patch.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (2 inline comments)

close to my ideal. Thanks for redoing! I will give +1 if all the comments get fixed.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Just some nits: 
1.Dict's format if in multi-line:
  my_dictionary = {
      "image": {
          "name": "Just a Snapshot",
          "size": 2749573,
          "properties": {
               "user_id": 12,

          },
          "things": [
              "thing_one",
              "thing_two",
          ],
          "status": "ACTIVE",
      },
  }
2. unit test for our new feature'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

It can work, but the side effect and the inconsistency of dealing with resetting db_connected field are not comfortable to me.

commit_message:
blueprint agent-db-ha
bug 985470
bug 985646

The fixes enable the OVS and linuxbridge agenets to "keep alive" when the host running the server/plugin is down.

Fixes after comments. Better logging

Fixes after comments - added reconnect interval + cleanup

Fixes after comments - simplify code + ovs intervals moved to configuration file

Fixes after comments - move int conversion to configuration

Fixes after comments - if one of the polling interval or reconnect interval are not
defined in the relevant ini files then a default value is used.

Fixes after comments and merges with HACKING.rst fixes

Fixes after port binding comments

Fixes after comments from gongysh

Fixes after comments - align comments in agent ini files

commit_message:
Basic functionality of v2 /images resource

* Implement create, upate, and delete actions for images
* Adds a basic functional test
* Add all /images url routes
* Implements bp api-v2-images

Change-Id: Ib9b16c443730943557f555b4aa9ce63840ff8e17

messages:
[{'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-04-24 20:42:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(5 inline comments)

Most of this diff looks very good, but there are just a couple of small problems with it.

The first problem is just the spelling of swift.common.http.HTTPInsuffcientStorage; "Insuff_i_cient" needs another "i' in there. That's the only reason I've given a -1 here.

There's another few things that I've addressed in inline comments that I think would improve readability a little, but they're just my opinion. If you strongly prefer them the way they are, I will not object to keeping them that way.'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-04-25 02:23:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-04-25 04:26:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-04-25 07:25:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

We're losing information in some cases.

I think it's a great idea to stop using HTTP codes directly, but I think the error message should customisable (507 is insufficient storage, but if the reason is a disk is not mounted... we can't afford losing that detail!)."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-04-25 16:26:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:34:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-05-02 16:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

What is the policy on i18n for error messages? Should the messages from the new exceptions be wrapped in _()?'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-03 23:57:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

It's entirely possible that error messages should have i18n, but this diff didn't introduce any new error messages, just moved some around a bit.

It doesn't make anything worse on the i18n front and is a good change otherwise; I'll take it."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-03 23:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

commit_message:
Move image checksums into a generic file.

This will allow us to store other information about an image on a
single compute node. This is required for prefetching to be
implemented.

Change-Id: Ic65b04cc1ef2101a1ac588595b943b813abdd50d

commit_message:
Sync to newer openstack-common

Changes since last sync are:

 - cfg:
    * Support for directory source of config files
    * Provide file extension when when looking for files
    * Some refactoring of the cfg cache
    * Add caching to openstack.common.cfg

 - setup:
    * Handle authors existed before VCS was around.

Change-Id: If3f0515a911a315dc1329b99299fdbc3592fce24

subject: Convert Volume and Snapshot IDs to use UUID
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 838, 'name': 'Nirmal Ranganathan', 'email': 'rnirmal@gmail.com', 'username': 'rnirmal'}, {'_account_id': 917, 'name': 'Chuck Thier', 'email': 'cthier@gmail.com', 'username': 'cthier'}, {'_account_id': 1179, 'name': 'Clay Gerrard', 'email': 'clay.gerrard@gmail.com', 'username': 'clay-gerrard'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2243, 'name': 'John Griffith', 'email': 'john.griffith8@gmail.com', 'username': 'john-griffith'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-13 02:47:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-13 05:07:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (8 inline comments)

John, this looks great.  A bunch of small fixes inline.

I was kind of hoping we could do all of the mapping for id -> uuid for instances, volumes, snapshot, images in one table.  I was going to suggest that we do that and modify the images table and make it more general.  But there is one issue with that: upgrading will change the ec2 id of existing objects.  That seems a little bit bad, so I'm willing to put up with a separate table for volumes.

I would however like to keep the ids in the migration.  I think that means modifying the migrations a bit to add the mapping table first, and then during the migration, add a row to the mapping table with the old integer id and the new uuid. Does that seem feasible?"}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-13 14:08:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

Will work on fixing up the things Vish pointed out this morning.

WRT the separate table; I would LOVE to eliminate the need for this but I just couldn't come up with a reliable way to do it such that it would work for MySQL as well SQlite.  Can't do composite keys in lite, counting rows, sorting and increment is not reliable etc etc. 

If anybody reviewing this has a suggestion on how I might be able to add an auto increment (or code auto increment functionality) that works across the board I would really appreciate it.  Then I could drop the EC2-Volume table and go back to plan 'A' and just use the ec2_id column in the Volume table."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-13 17:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

We absolutely need a separate table, because the table will ultimately belong to to the ec2_api mapping layer, whereas the volume table will belong to the volume service.  I was hoping that we could generalize the existing S3Image table which is doing exactly the same thing as the volume table you created -- just a mapping from an autoinc integer id to a uuid.

(Eventually we will need to do the same thing with compute and remove the extra field from the instances table)

But as I said in my earlier comment reusing the S3Image table would force us to adopt new ec2_ids for each instance during migration.  For example if the AutoInc key is already at 7 from the images then the first volume will be vol-00000008, when the old id might have been vol-00000001 for example.  That will be confusing for users.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-14 04:13:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-14 04:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-14 04:16:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Sorry for the delay, spent the day on some other things unfortunately.

I'd appreciate a close look at my idea of setting the auto-inc key.  It seems this works fine on mysql and sqlite but perhaps there's something dangerous here that I don't know about."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-14 04:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-24 21:35:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

2 things I've been considering

a) I think we should avoid dropping data from tables in migrations.  We may want to move to a model where we drop all of the extra data post upgrade.

b) usually we handle the separate sqlite migration with separate files.  See some of the other migrations for examples."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-30 20:57:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-30 21:26:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

3 issues:
a) Inline problem with alter table
b) there are lots of tabs in the sqlalchemy migrations, can you switch everything to spaces?
c) you will have to bump the migration version because 087 is taken and mikal's patch is in the queue which takes 088"}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-30 22:09:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-04-30 22:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-05-01 02:09:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-01 06:21:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Convert Volume and Snapshot IDs to use UUID

* Three migrations
  1. create id mappings
  2. convert volume_id and snapshot_id from int to string
  3. change volume/snapshot id's from int to uuid
* DB migration for Volume and Related tables
* Addition of new volume id mapping tables
* Added methods in ec2utils
* Minor tweaks to unit tests
* Other changes to migration to ensure consistency in id's
* Fixed bug in the block-device-mapping table (wasn't setting autoinc)

Change-Id: Ic6c3646e0f01c26467a4a3c20e13eebaa2baa97e

commit_message:
Limit hint/nic parsing to one split on '='

* Make sure we split a scheduler hint like 'a=b=c' into ('a', 'b=c') rather than ('a', 'b', 'c')
* Also apply fix to --nic argument
* Fixes bug 986213

Change-Id: Icbc6938ea332bd70a82890bf4dc0744b2471bc24

commit_message:
Remove unused import

Not only unused, but using webob exceptions from compute.api is bad
practice. That should happen in the OS API or EC2 API layers.

Change-Id: Ibfe20148608aaca0884fe123eb32c8957980ca56

commit_message:
Add some more basic structure to cinder project

* Add more of the dir structure and copy some basic files in
* Get a working test .venv setup
* Add a dumb test to excercise the test framework
* Add a few things to pull in from openstack-common

Change-Id: Ic008c6ef90de0e5143766ff6174bbe1b03a1f890

existant id property in Keypair.__repr__

subject: really output the description of an exception
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 24, 'name': 'Chuck Short', 'email': 'charles.short@windriver.com', 'username': 'zulcss'}, {'_account_id': 167, 'name': 'Christian Berendt', 'email': 'berendt@osism.tech', 'username': 'berendt'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:15:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

See question in-line.  Also note you don't seem to be listed in AUTHORS at present"}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:21:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kevin, I don't understand it, too. I'm using Python 2.6.0 and maybe that's the difference.

The format string is not working there this way, I never can see the description of the exception. With the patch it's possible.

I don't see a reason why not committing it, it makes the output working for me and doesn't affect the output for other users."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:23:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If you prefer using format strings it's also possible to use e.message instead of only e. That's working for me, too.

But the HTTP status code is not part of message.

example: "ERROR: Flavor 12 could not be found." instead of "ERROR: Flavor 12 could not be found. (HTTP 404)".'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:37:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Well, the problem with using e.message is that that particular attribute turns up as deprecated.  Anyway, here's what I see:

    [klmitch@einstein ~]$ python
    Python 2.7 (r27:82500, Sep 16 2010, 18:02:00) 
    [GCC 4.5.1 20100907 (Red Hat 4.5.1-3)] on linux2
    Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
    >>> e = Exception("you've got a bug")
    >>> import sys
    >>> print >> sys.stderr, "ERROR: %s" % e
    ERROR: you've got a bug

And in 2.6:

    klmitch@devhost-klmitch:~/devel/src/nova$ python
    Python 2.6.6 (r266:84292, Dec 26 2010, 22:31:48) 
    [GCC 4.4.5] on linux2
    Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
    >>> e = Exception("you've got a bug")
    >>> import sys
    >>> print >> sys.stderr, "ERROR: %s" % e
    ERROR: you've got a bug

I suppose it could be a problem specific to the HTTP exceptions, but somehow that seems unlikely'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:38:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:46:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Your example is working here, too.

os0009:~ # python
Python 2.6 (r26:66714, Apr 13 2012, 16:31:55) 
[GCC 4.3.4 [gcc-4_3-branch revision 152973]] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> e = Exception("you've got a bug")
>>> import sys
>>> print >> sys.stderr, "ERROR: %s" % e
ERROR: you've got a bug

If I directly call e.__str__() (of the ClientException of Novaclient) it's working, too.

I think it's a nasty bug in Python 2.6.0 and I would really prefer if we could it here and I don't have to start debugging the Python interpreter again :)'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:48:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:52:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:58:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

str(e) is working fine, I forgot to test it first of all :( I think it looks good now. Thanks for the support.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:16:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

No problem :)'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-04-28 12:03:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-04-30 20:05:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-05-02 09:31:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

can somebody please approve this change request?'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:50:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-03 19:04:56.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-03 19:04:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-novaclient-merge/180/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3827/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-novaclient-unittests/195/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-novaclient-pep8/184/ : SUCCESS'}]

commit_message:
really output the description of an exception

example without patch:

nova [...] flavor-delete 123
ERROR:

example with this patch:

nova [...] flavor-delete 123
ERROR: Flavor 123 could not be found. (HTTP 404)

fixes bug 981286

Change-Id: I9c5cead521e48b4970850262fb9af279ec5a7753

subject: Split noauth context middleware into new class
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-01 23:12:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-01 23:22:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 11:56:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Have we sacrificed some test coverage by removing TestBinGlance.test_add/update_with_owner_non_admin?

Also one (non-blocking) suggestion, would "noauth-" as opposed to "unauthenticated-" be more concise and familiar naming for the new middleware?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:25:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:45:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Eoghan:

Yes, we are losing a bit of test coverage with the removal of those tests. I think it would actually be wise to revisit functional testing of authenticated requests in one fell swoop. These two tests were somewhat orthogonal to the existing framework and I would like to make it a bit more seamless.

As for the name, I *really* don't like 'noauth'. It doesn't mean anything without already having some context. I feel like 'unauthenticated' is much more obvious, no?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 17:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 17:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Whoops, missed some failing tests. Good to go now.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-02 17:18:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 23:05:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 23:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Dang, didn't mean to push another patchset. My dependent branch rebased automagically and ended updating this little guy. No changes of mine, here."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-02 23:55:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Heh :)  Yeah, that's one of the annoyances of gerrit"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-03 13:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Brian,

Fair enough on the "unauthenticated" versus "noauth".

On the test coverage question though, I wonder are we *unnecessarily* throwing away coverage, if the fakeauth middleware could simply be modified to set the auth-related request headers now expected by the modified context middleware (e.g. X-Identity-Status, X-Roles etc.).

The reason this could be worth doing is that there was some confusion a while back on image ownership setting by admin versus non-admin users, and these test cases were added at the time to provide clarity on the intent and actual behaviour.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-03 15:48:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-03 15:49:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I took the time to rewrite the tests in test_bin_glance that were deleted into a nice functional test. I should have done that in the first place.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-03 15:52:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-03 15:52:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

That was just a pep8 issue. Ready to review.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-03 16:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-03 16:00:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Added the test skipper'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-03 16:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks great, thanks for keeping the coverage on ownership logic.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:42:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-03 18:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-03 18:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified

Build Successful

commit_message:
Split noauth context middleware into new class

Use UnauthenticatedContextMiddleware in the case that you want to deploy
without an auth service. ContextMiddleware is now solely for authenticated
requests.

* Rewrite ownership tests for adding/updating images through the v1 API
* Fixes bug 992859

Change-Id: I608671aac8300c9195769542708708afda991e04

commit_message:
Ensure that the dom0 we're connected to is the right one

The XenAPI driver requires the compute domU be running on the same host
as specified by xenapi_connection_url. Check that we can find the compute
domU on the host connected to before going too far.

Change-Id: I2a56fa305b6379a7ea97f04240e627bb13223c9f

blank key name is tried to be set

Fixes bug 990015

subject: Pass context to notification drivers when we can.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1998, 'name': 'andrewbogott', 'username': 'andrewbogott', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-27 16:17:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

I love the idea of putting the context in a standard place, but currently it's part of the payload (in most cases). If we're going to move it, we should remove it from the payload.

Note: This will break existing Billing and Reporting systems (and StackTach), so there needs to be a major notice to the mailing list as soon as it lands!"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-27 18:27:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Andrew, could you explain why this change is necessary for plugin enhancements? Thanks!

-jay'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-04-27 18:37:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Jay --

The little picture is:  the feature I'm working on right now (which is just for live-documentation of instance info) needs to know information about images and tenants which is only available via subsequent calls to the DB and/or glance and/or keystone.

The big picture is:  Notifications will be used by the plugin framework as 'callbacks', and I want each callback to have the same auth as the event which prompted it.  Hence, context."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-27 18:43:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

OK, thx for the explanation Andrew. I guess I'm still a little confused as to why accessing the context via the payload is a bad idea, but I suppose decoupling the auth context from the message payload may allow more efficient routing of messages?"}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-04-27 19:45:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-04-27 19:48:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Patchset 2 should clarify the relationship between this context and the context that was previously present in some notification streams.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-27 20:06:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Some test failures:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/14096/

My other minor nit would be having context at the end of the parameter list when it's the first parameter for all other methods/functions."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-27 20:06:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

whoops"}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-04-27 20:11:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Grrrr, I hate not being able to run the test suite locally.

I will resubmit shortly.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-04-27 20:16:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Also... I can't move context to the beginning of the notify arg list without making it mandatory.  It seems more polite to have it optional, just in case."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-04-27 20:46:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-30 12:13:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Some small changes. 

(seems like context is never passed in optionally or left out, we can't make it mandatory and first?)"}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-04-30 14:10:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

Making context mandatory adds to the size of this patch a bit, but it's probably worth it.  Done."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-04-30 14:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-30 14:49:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Fair enough :)

Thanks for the tweaks.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:49:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:54:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Pass context to notification drivers when we can.

Note that previously several notification drivers
created an admin context and embedded it in their
messages.  Those drivers now use the passed-in
context instead if it's available.

For blueprint novaplugins.

Change-Id: Icb89030256022d0a68db4a147611fd37fe83316a

commit_message:
Regenerate tempest.conf every time

Select for active images

If we don't do this, repeat devstack installs won't be
able to use this script.

Change-Id: I95746ffebfa7163c80161d26de1e575c0fc5d39c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-03 10:24:04.000000000', 'message': "Allow wget to handle Non-English output

The stack.sh has a loop to wait for keystone to start. But the output of wget tool has been globalized which means it won't return the English word 'refused' on Non-English environment even the keystone is not up. So the script will assume the keystone has been started and continue. The command of keystone tenant-create always failed immediately after skipping this loop since it require keystone to be started to authenticate. That's why you can see authentication error in the log because the tenant information was not correctly set up.

Fix bug 978739

Change-Id: Ia4ebe6ad0f9b5a886de48a4bea7c2aebff420dad
"}, {'created': '2012-05-03 10:30:19.000000000', 'message': "Allow wget to handle Non-English output

The stack.sh has a loop to wait for keystone to start. But the output of wget tool has been globalized
which means it won't return the English word 'refused' on Non-English environment even the keystone is
not up. So the script will assume the keystone has been started and continue. The command of keystone
tenant-create always failed immediately after skipping this loop since it require keystone to be started
to authenticate. That's why you can see authentication error in the log because the tenant information
was not correctly set up.

Fix bug 978739

Change-Id: Ia4ebe6ad0f9b5a886de48a4bea7c2aebff420dad
"}]
commit_message:
Allow wget to handle Non-English output

The stack.sh has a loop to wait for keystone to start. But the output of wget tool has been globalized
which means it won't return the English word 'refused' on Non-English environment even the keystone is
not up. So the script will assume the keystone has been started and continue. The command of keystone
tenant-create always failed immediately after skipping this loop since it require keystone to be started
to authenticate. That's why you can see authentication error in the log because the tenant information
was not correctly set up.

Fix bug 978739

Change-Id: Ia4ebe6ad0f9b5a886de48a4bea7c2aebff420dad

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-03 15:30:41.000000000', 'message': "Partial Fix LP #992640 - Extend volume group

Tempest's volume list tests create a number of 1G
volumes, but devstack's default volume backing file
size is only 2G. If tempest is being executed, we
set VOLUME_BACKING_FILE_SIZE=4g in localrc, enabling
Tempest's volume tests to succeed without cryptic
error messages...

Change-Id: I3f9555095f2c6a86e7b5984cbc209d7e4235c567
"}]
commit_message:
Partial Fix LP #992640 - Extend volume group

Tempest's volume list tests create a number of 1G
volumes, but devstack's default volume backing file
size is only 2G. If tempest is being executed, we
set VOLUME_BACKING_FILE_SIZE=4g in localrc, enabling
Tempest's volume tests to succeed without cryptic
error messages...

Change-Id: I3f9555095f2c6a86e7b5984cbc209d7e4235c567

commit_message:
Add -c|--coverage option to run_tests.sh

A convenience for generating coverage metrics. Might make it
more likely that developers will review the coverage stats more
often, to identify pre-existing blackspots and avoid proposing
under-tested new code.

Change-Id: Iecd10ec529dd6e93d18a6763bf36667402640881

nova-manage should not execute iptables-save during "network create"
Fixes bug 977738

Removed call to l3driver.initialize_network() from create_networks()

commit_message:
Use additional task states during resize

Fixes bug lp990805

Adds 3 additional state changes to instance during resize. Specifially:
RESIZE_MIGRATING
RESIZE_MIGRATED
RESIZE_FINISH

Change-Id: I61a1c98c8b179c50747717525e1aaed01d372b4b

subject: Adding 'host' info to volume-compute connection information.
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-02 16:49:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This looks good, but I don't think the xenapi modification is right. I think target_host is the hostname of the nova-volumes service machine.  It seems like we want the hostname of the dom0.  Maybe renuka can tell us what it should be."}, {'account_id': 838, 'date': '2012-05-02 17:45:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 838, 'date': '2012-05-02 17:47:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Vish that's right, it's the ISCSI target host rather than the dom0 hostname. I've updated it to use the dom0 hostname from the host_stats."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-02 17:53:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

looks good nirmal.  I will switch my vote to +2 if we can get a comment from a xen expert if that looks correct.  Adding John Garbutt and Chris Behrens for review.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-02 18:23:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'll trust that moving the functionality from the ensure/create_export methods to initialize_connection() is correct. :)

The Xen thing is right, if you're wanting dom0 hostname."}, {'account_id': 838, 'date': '2012-05-02 18:27:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Chris. Yes I can guarantee that initialize/terminate is correct as opposed to doing the create/ensure export. We are running this in production right now :)'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-05-02 20:55:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Turns out the hostname that is returned by the xe command is not the fqdn. The only way to get that is probably running "hostname -f" locally (i.e. I don't see any param returned by XAPI that has the fqdn).'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-02 23:00:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3770/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-02 23:00:30.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-02 15:27:12.000000000', 'message': "Adding 'host' info to volume-compute connection information.

Added a new key 'host' for the initialize/terminate volume connection
information. Updated the HpSanISCSIDriver to use teh initialize and
terminate methods. Added missing unit tests for the HpSanISCSIDriver.

commit_message:
Adding 'host' info to volume-compute connection information.

Added a new key 'host' for the initialize/terminate volume connection
information. Updated the HpSanISCSIDriver to use teh initialize and
terminate methods. Added missing unit tests for the HpSanISCSIDriver.
Fixes bug 992729.

Change-Id: I09fad6b5328cbfb860ab2c7ae5d206010f3dd45d

commit_message:
Use save_and_reraise_exception() from common.

This patch common.excutils from openstack-common, which includes
save_and_reraise_exception().  The patch also converts the code
base to use it from there instead of nova.utils and then removes
it from nova.utils.

The initial motivation for this was removing another nova dependency
from nova.rpc so that it can eventually be moved to openstack-common.

Change-Id: I7354ca51a02aec9c709cf33f77d4abc46acc2742

commit_message:
Support for directory source of config files

Allow multiple config files to be pulled in from a config directory,
as opposed to individual config files being explicitly enumerated.

This logic is enabled using the --config-dir=/path/to/config CLI option,
causing config to be retrived from all matching /path/to/config/*.conf
files.

Sections may be re-opened across config files, and all config items
must reside in an explicitly specified section (i.e. it does not default
to [DEFAULT]). This behavior is unchanged.

The common elements of this patch (i.e. not specific to the
glance-specific location of paste.ini files) have landed in
to openstack-common as:

  https://github.com/openstack/openstack-common/commit/fd8c2e7c

Change-Id: I3b659f1837c082bd1a78fe860a468f9d68f0f132

commit_message:
Make kombu support optional for running unit tests.

Fix bug 838386.

Previously, the unit tests required kombu to be installed to run.  This
patch makes it so the unit tests will still complete successfully, even
if kombu is not installed.

Change-Id: I06831a37f8c857bbfd0bce1b1c3aeda7d341a589

commit_message:
Update common.importutils from openstack-common.

This patch updates common.importutils from openstack-common.  The change
was to remove the usage of common.exception.  The rest of the patch
includes the changes required in nova to no longer use common.exception,
as well.

Change-Id: Iacd186b2c466cba84248ae10589ffbb5a9cec0ba

commit_message:
Add save_and_reraise_exception().

This patch adds save_and_reraise_exception() to a new module,
openstack.common.excutils.  This is based on the function of the same
name from nova.utils.  It is used by nova.rpc, so something equivalent
is needed in openstack-common before nova.rpc can be moved here.

Change-Id: Icec574a081837e0f2d0548a5759d21b0352dbee6

commit_message:
Remove common.exception from common.importutils.

This patch removes the usage of common.exception from
common.importutils.  Instead of raising exception.NotFound() from
importutils.import_class(), just use the built-in ImportError.

Change-Id: I95e84908d1f80c5ca3bbac049eda8faa64212ae0

commit_message:
Switch to 1000 rounds during unit tests

Fixes bug 992918

a result, increase the rounds used during testing to the minimum

Change-Id: Ic0c635e92b4f13180a047904a6efa490ab599012

PS: IMHO changes to Cisco/NVP/Ryu plugins won't harm functionality at all. Maintainers of those plugins, please chime in!"}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I can guess at the collective reaction to this.  I'd rather gouge my eyes out than have to review a patch of this size, but there is one upside - it only has to be done this once.  :)"}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

The latest change addresses Salvatore's issues and rebases against master."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/269/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(6 inline comments)

phew, what a patch :) 

Great to have people contributing to the overall quality of the project.

A couple high level comments. 
- If we want to keep some of these formatting patterns consistent as the code base changes, I think we need automated checks to enforce them.  I've noticed that many of the comments you make in your reviews about tabs aren't called out by the automated pep8 runs included in the automated tests or gates.  If we care about enforcing something, we should have an automated check. 
- In general, a patch like this is probably best broken up into change sets that affect the "core" non-plugin code, and separate change-sets for each plugin.  Not only would this make the review more manageable, but it would also deal with the fact that one person is unlikely to be familiar with all plugin code, or be able to test all plugins.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (5 inline comments)

dan: 

- The pep8 checker doesn't catch everything, presumably since some checks are optional.  It's up to you as PTL if you want to relax rules that can't be automatically checked - I'm just following general practice in other core projects.  I would note, however, that not all style issues are amenable to automatic validation.  A good programmer take into account how things are done in surrounding code and a good code reviewer does the same.

- I made sure to manually execute the unit tests for every plugin that I modified.  Other core project ensures that code under their control can be modified by anyone without fear of breaking master by ensuring that all merges gate on useful testing.  If that's not the case here, I think we have a larger issue.  Having to segment project-wide changes or involve specialists from every plugin on a review does not seem like a reasonable solution."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful

commit_message:
Update codebase for HACKING compliance.

 * This is a massive patch that aims to clean up the codebase
   and bring it into compliance with HACKING.rst and PEP8 in one
   fell swoop.
 * Cleaned up use of gettext.
 * Updated log usage for consistency.
 * The tests run successfully against all plugins except
   cisco and nicira (due to dependency issues with these plugins).
 * Addresses bug 981208

Change-Id: I4d8c7ab138d8f7bb906d18dc34f88f8bd0581c19
