commit_message:
Fix nova.tests.test_nova_rootwrap on Fedora 17.

Fix bug 992916

This patch resolves a unit test failure on Fedora 17.  The root cause is
that 'sleep' is '/usr/bin/sleep' instead of '/bin/sleep'.  Update the
test to allow that.

Change-Id: I5c8e04baec7159a8c10c9beb96cff58fd383e71c

subject: New ConfigOpts.find_file() for locating conf files
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

New patchset is just a rebase.

As for policy.json, I wouldn't expect that we allow that to be fragmented. We'd have to write a custom smusher for it as it can't be joined by just appending."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm having trouble incorporating/understanding your proposed diff. You reference 'self' from what appears to be a top-level function (find_config_files). Am I missing something?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Reading back over this, I'm not sure how exactly to proceed. Can one of you spell this out for me?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think this idea could be useful, but it's not solving the issue at hand. In my devstack setup, I've got my glance-api.conf in /etc/glance, which is specified on the command line. My policy.json is at /opt/stack/glance/etc/policy.json. I run the glance-api executable from /opt/stack/glance. Your proposed patch looks in the standard places for policy.json (~/.glance/, ~/, /etc/glance/, and /etc). Once it doesn't find policy.json, it falls back to looking in the dir that the glance-api.conf was found, /etc/glance/. This makes me think that we just need to look in a local etc dir."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Something like this?

A ConfigOpts::find_config_file API? Would iterate over the base directories of all supplied config-files?

Split out search_dirs() into a toplevel search_config_dirs() module function, then do:

  class ConfigOpts:

      def find_config_file(self, basename):
          dirs = [os.dirname(cf) for cf in self.config_files]
          return search_config_dirs(dirs, basename)'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure we'd include config-dir in this since I'd expect config-dir to load all files in the dir, also for the files we're talking about we're not supporting multiple ones. If we did, I'd do:

  /etc/glance/policy.json
  /etc/glance/policy.json.d/01-foo
  /etc/glance/policy.json.d/01-bar"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm always slightly nervous of these kind of things - e.g. if root ran the service in a world-writable directory

Also, I don't think this does what you want - surely 'etc' should take priority over all others, e.g. in case you had glance installed on this machine

Nova's approach to this is to have state_path default to being relative to where the python code is running and distributors overwrite this in their packaged nova.conf

Hmm. This needs some thought."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Brian - I think we should fix devstack to copy policy.json into /etc/glance like it already does for the paste config and keystone's policy.json

I think the patch set I just pushed should be workable for pretty much all cases"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Just a comment inline. Not a requirement.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-common-merge/56/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This looks good, Mark. I deployed it on devstack and it will work for Glance once we copy policy.json to /etc/glance'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yep, makes sense. 

That goes a bit further than what we currently do to locate the paste-ini, where we only look in the dir containing the *last* config file (should probably search them all).

It might be more logical to reverse the sense of that dir search, so that directories containing the higher precedence config files are searched first.

One future change is that we would need to accommodate --config-dir also once patch #6733 lands, e.g.

  dirs = dirs + [self.config_dir] if self.config_dir else dirs

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Brian,

I tripped over the unfound policy.json issue also when adding --config-dir support to glance, and a different approach occurred to me at the time. Here's the gist ...

When the location of the glance-*-paste.ini isn't explicitly specified in glance-*.conf:paste_deploy.flavor, we infer its location assuming its in the same directory as the "last" (i.e. most significant) glance-*.conf file, e.g.

  glance-api --config-file /a/1.conf
    => load /a/glance-api-paste.ini

  glance-api --config-file /a/1.conf --config-file /b/2.conf
    => load /b/glance-api-paste.ini

  glance-api --config-dir /a --config-file /b/2.conf
    => load /a/glance-api-paste.ini

Could we apply the same inference to policy.json? (if not found in one of the standard places)'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@markmc

I was thinking that the policy.json would remain a single file for the moment at least, just as we expect the *-paste.ini to be unfragmented currently.

Also currently we only load config files from the --config-dir that match '*.conf', so we could put other individual files with a different extension in that directory also, e.g:

  /etc/glance/glance-api.d:
     00-core.conf
     01-ssl.conf
     02-s3.conf
     policy.json
     glance-api-paste.ini

I'm not sure there's a specific usecase for going further and supporting split policy.json or glance-api-paste.ini files."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@bcwaldon

Sorry, my bad - I conflated the ConfigOpts class with a module-level method.

So I think you would need some new logic in the module-level method and a new method on ConfigOpts, something like:

  def find_config_files(project=None, prog=None, filetype="conf", fallback_dirs=None):
    ...
    if not config_files and fallback_dirs:
      config_files.append(search_config_dirs(fallback_dirs, '%s.%s' % (prog, filetype)))

    return filter(bool, config_files)
  ...

  class ConfigOpts:
    ...
  
    def find_config_file(project=None, prog=None, filetype="conf"):
      dirs = [os.dirname(cf) for cf in reversed(self.config_file)]
      return find_config_files(project, prog, filetype, fallback_dirs)'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@bcwaldon

Don't worry about the config_dir aspect, as #6733 hasn't landed yet. We can retrofit the logic when it does.

So what's needed now I think for the alternative approach discussed is simply to walk the dirs containing the *.conf files, when the searched-for file is not already found in one of the standard locations. For instance something like:

  cfg.py:
  class ConfigOpts:

  def find_config_files(self, basename):

    ...

    config_files.append(search_dirs(cfg_dirs, '%s.%s' % (prog, filetype)))

 +   if not config_files and self.config_file:
 +     dirs = [os.dirname(cf) for cf in reversed(self.config_file)]
 +     config_files.append(search_config_dirs(dirs,
 +                                            '%s.%s' % (prog, filetype)))

    return filter(bool, config_files)"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

@markmc

Looks good in general, one search order nit-pick inline though.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Nice one, definitely neater.

One last nit-pick, the comment on lines 1102-1104 just needs to be updated to reflect the latest search ordering.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good to go!

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-02 14:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
New ConfigOpts.find_file() for locating conf files

Most services have the need to locate files like api-paste.ini or
policy.json.

This new method attempts to find these files by looking alongside
the config files already parsed by ConfigOpts and, failing that,
falls back to a standard set of directories.

Change-Id: I95897816485b88f78854df194cab7872d7c5452a

subject: use an info box in the dashboards "nova/images_and_snapshots" and "nova/instances_and_volumes" if no service "volume" is available in the service catalog of keystone
messages:
[{'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:28:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:14:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

This is fine, but I have a few nits which i commented on inline."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:40:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Jake, if I use "exceptions.handle" I'm not able to use the dashboards anymore because I only see the stacktrace in the webinterface.

I want that Horizon doesn't require an entry "volume" on the Keystone and that the dashboards are usable without this service entry.

An information that no volumes can be use because of a missing service entry is ok. Maybe it's even better to fully disable the usage of volumes if there is no service entry volume on the keystone.

I don't think that it's an error if no service entry volume is available on keystone, because maybe you don't use nova-volume and so you have no service entry for it.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-04-30 16:54:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

What is the actual exception that is raised in the case that the nova-volume service isn't in the keystone catalog?"}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-05-02 09:53:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

should be handled by this blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/nova-volume-optional'}]

subject: Assert options to be defined or have default value
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I believe, options should be required by default and raise error if accessed with no value. The shiny example is that bug in Keystone. Developer can forget to mark an option as required and leave a cruel error message. Or even make some security issue (e.g. with if cfg.encrypt_password: ...).

As I understand, almost every option is required to have non-None value, so why don't turn it on by default?

And if so, it's easier to give default values to optional parameters."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Ok, so I actually intended for default=None to be the default behaviour

The problem in keystone is that the defaults are in the config file, not the code - I'll elaborate in the bug

What your patch more-or-less implements is the notion of "required options" - i.e. options which you must specify a value for. I was going to do that with e.g.

  StrOpt('foo', required=True)

I'll file a blueprint on that'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Please continue the discussion in the bug report

If you try out https://github.com/markmc/keystone/tree/cfg-cleanup-v6 you'll see how keystone's issues can easily be fixed"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

one suggestion, you can rewrite your changelog to include the keyword 'bug 982602' so gerrit can automatically associate this patchset to the bug report, that way it'll automatically close or update the bug report according to the progress of this patchset

not sure why it wouldn't do that with url link though"}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-04-23 17:37:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

One fix:

Please use user.authorized_tenants (instead of the keystone API call) as it is properly cached to avoid making multiple calls and always returns the right set of tenants."}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-04-24 15:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Gabriel,

On top of my patch I added:

diff --git a/horizon/dashboards/settings/ec2/forms.py b/horizon/dashboards/setti

-            token = request.session.get("unscoped_token")
-            tenant_list = api.tenant_list_for_token(request, token,
-                                                    endpoint_type="publicURL")
+            tenant_list = request.user.authorized_tenants
         except:
             tenant_list = []
             exceptions.handle(request, _("Unable to retrieve tenant list."))
diff --git a/horizon/dashboards/settings/project/forms.py b/horizon/dashboards/s
index c185fa5..69babc8 100644
--- a/horizon/dashboards/settings/project/forms.py
+++ b/horizon/dashboards/settings/project/forms.py
@@ -46,9 +46,7 @@ class DownloadOpenRCForm(forms.SelfHandlingForm):
         # Populate tenant choices
         tenant_choices = []
         try:
-            token = request.session.get("unscoped_token")
-            tenant_list = api.tenant_list_for_token(request, token,
-                                                    endpoint_type="publicURL")
+            tenant_list = request.user.authorized_tenants
         except:
             tenant_list = []
             exceptions.handle(request, _("Unable to retrieve tenant list."))

But with admin user I'm seeing an error:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/nishome/crobinso/src/openstack/horizon.git/horizon/users.py", line 155, in authorized_tenants
    authd = api.tenant_list_for_token(self._request, token)

    return c.tenants.list()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/keystoneclient/v2_0/tenants.py", line 90, in list

  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/keystoneclient/base.py", line 65, in _list
    resp, body = self.api.get(url)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/keystoneclient/client.py", line 165, in get
    return self._cs_request(url, 'GET', **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/keystoneclient/client.py", line 157, in _cs_request
    method, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/keystoneclient/client.py", line 129, in request
    raise exceptions.from_response(resp, body)
Unauthorized: The request you have made requires authentication. (HTTP 401)'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Only list the tenants associated with the current logged in user.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/982602

While we are in here, sync __init__ between the two forms, since they
are doing the exact same thing, and the ec2 variant is more robust.

commit_message:
Don't list every tenant in ec2/project form

Only list the tenants associated with the current logged in user.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/982602

While we are in here, sync __init__ between the two forms, since they
are doing the exact same thing, and the ec2 variant is more robust.

Change-Id: I04cf975d9b8fecb23e86981814406659d2176ae2

subject: Changes vm state to FAILED_RESIZE on resize fail
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-10 11:48:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

I have mixed feelings about this bug fix. I feel like we are missing something to track instance exceptions properly and this solution will sweep a failed RESIZE attempt "under the rug".

We talked about using the task_state to indicate failure on IRC. This would also involve changes to the compute API such that the check_instance_state decorator works in all cases with failed resize states.

Seems like what we really need is proper exception tracking so that users can query instance exceptions which may occur in this type of  async action.

Couple of inline comments as well.'}, {'account_id': 2924, 'date': '2012-04-10 13:23:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Dan,

With regard to the patch review comments given, I would like to have few clarifications.

1. Is it that the instance should be in the "error" or "resizing" state if the resize operation fails and should not go back to "active" state?

2. Are the task_states of the respective failures to be added to the decorator function "check_instance_state"?

3. Do we just need to raise exceptions and leave the states of the instances in "error" or "resizing" if the resize fails?'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-10 14:47:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 2924, 'date': '2012-04-16 11:28:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2924, 'date': '2012-04-16 12:35:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2924, 'date': '2012-04-17 08:41:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-02 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Changes vm state to FAILED_RESIZE on resize fail

Fixes bug 898311

The bug fix resolves the error raised during
resize failure. When the resize fails the
state of the vm is set to a state "RESIZE
FAILED" and the task state is also changed
such that the user knows that there is a
failure in resize. the same state is added
to all the operations. If the resize is to
be done on the same host the flag
"allow_resize_to_same_host" is to be set
"true" in "nova.conf" file.

Change-Id: Id89081ddd49ec17e2e7e89c2bcb790a3553f0cdc

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-01 23:31:04.000000000', 'message': "Auto generate AUTHORS for python-openstackclient.

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

* AUTHORS
  Remove this file.

* tests/test_authors.py
  Remove this test case.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* openstackclient/openstack/common/setup.py
  generate_authors(): New method to create AUTHORS file. If
  AUTHORS.in file exists, append it's content to AUTHORS file.

* setup.py
  Import the new method.
  Generate AUTHORS file before creating the package.

Change-Id: Ia5488a43f88e13a0fb1f7a5d8d10a576b9034dc8
"}]
commit_message:
Auto generate AUTHORS for python-openstackclient.

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

* AUTHORS
  Remove this file.

* tests/test_authors.py
  Remove this test case.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* openstackclient/openstack/common/setup.py
  generate_authors(): New method to create AUTHORS file. If
  AUTHORS.in file exists, append it's content to AUTHORS file.

* setup.py
  Import the new method.
  Generate AUTHORS file before creating the package.

Change-Id: Ia5488a43f88e13a0fb1f7a5d8d10a576b9034dc8

commit_message:
Adds dash/panel app templates, mgmt commands, template loader.

Implements blueprint scaffolding.

Using custom management commands you can now create the majority
of the boilerplate code for a new dashboard or panel from a
set of basic templates with a single command. See the docs
for more info.

Additionally, in support of the new commands (and inherent
codified directory structure) there's a new template loader
included which can load templates from "templates" directories
in any registered panel.

Change-Id: I1df5eb152cb18694dc89d562799c8d3e8950ca6f

commit_message:
Fix test_launcher_app to ensure service actually got started

The test was not allowing the new spawned thread to execute before
(incorrectly) checking if the port had been assigned.

Change-Id: Ibc5c6eb7ecd78d3f8bbf934346c7b91ea6369d34

commit_message:
Reset project version to 0.1

Using a 2012.x version format commits us to the OpenStack release schedule.
The project is young and not core, we want to work independant of that at
least for a while.

Change-Id: I43569630cbfd94d45dfc490cba26991f9238e475

commit_message:
Make sample quantum.conf compliant with docs

The module quantum_auth_token does not exist. Also, the documentation uses
authtoken instead of authN.

The docs, for reference: http://docs.openstack.org/incubation/openstack-network/admin/content/configuring-keystone-with-quantum.html

Change-Id: I5a225dd740bb654a0b27937ebfa68f0ef6bff4f8

Add changelog to nova tarballs (v2)

Ubuntu uses a tarball to generate packages for Nova and
other openstack projects. This allows the user to find out
what is included in the tarball.

Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Return a BadRequest on bad flavors param values.

This changes the api to return a 400 bad request when a minRam or minDisk param with a non-integer value is provided when listing flavors.

Fixes bug 992662

Change-Id: I78bd32d0cde842547cb96767e4eb41f546aedbdf

commit_message:
A previous patch decoupled the RPC drivers from the nova.flags, breaking instance audit usage in the process.
This configures the instance audit usage to configure the RPC drivers properly with FLAGS so that the job can run.

Change-Id: Ia189d18d7b25a839de67439ccd363103c5af2f8f

subject: Enable InnoDB checking
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1, 'name': 'James E. Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 6, 'name': 'Joe Heck', 'email': 'heckj@mac.com', 'username': 'heckj'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2325, 'name': 'Andrew Hutchings', 'email': 'andrew@linuxjedi.co.uk', 'username': 'linuxjedi'}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-04-25 17:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-25 18:12:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

no, that was a mistake that didn't fully get cleaned out"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-25 18:14:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:08:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So just looking at the CI bit, I see:

We provide a mysql install with grants for the openstack_citest user on the openstack_citest database.  That seems straightforward.

There is a test to make sure that the check as to whether that database is accessible fails gracefully, that should help prevent breakage for test setups (like developer workstations) that don't use mysql, since that particular code path won't normally be tested by jenkins.  That's good.

Would it be a good idea to have an out-of-band (environment variable?) way to communicate to the test that we expect there to be a database, and if it can't connect to it, that the test should fail?  I'm thinking of the case where the CI system bit-rots and suddenly mysql is no longer available to the unit tests.  In that case, we would want to be notified of that, and if the tests just get skipped, we might not.

Did we decide that MySQL-python is the way we want to go for client libs?"}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:09:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

One more thing -- I think we should provide the mysql installation on the jenkins builders before merging this change, that way this change gets fully tested as part of the gate.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:27:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I agree with Jim about a way to set an env var or something which indicates that we expect a db to exist so fail if it doesn't work.

I would prefer it if we could use myconnpy (pure python) - but perhaps that could be a subsequent patch? (we should probably make sure that running nova with that instead of MySQLdb works properly- and maybe even convince devstack to use it instead - you know bless it as the way we think talking to mysql should work?)"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just so I'm clear, the proposed environment variable will basically say "it's not ok to gracefully fail, because we've said we expect the database to be there and running", right? Are there suggestions for what that would be called, namespace wise?

On the mysql driver front, lets handle that in a different patch, as I think there might be slightly more work to make our stack be able to completely change out mysql drivers.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-26 18:36:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sean, your understanding is correct.

It looks like migration tests are set up to use a test_migrations.conf file that specifies test database urls, with the possibility of providing a custom file on test servers with an environment variable.  We can support that on the Jenkins slaves if that approach is more desirable (though actually the discoverable database using predefined credentials has less moving parts).'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:03:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:46:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-28 00:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-30 19:55:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-05-01 17:23:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-01 17:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/2022/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3755/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-01 17:50:17.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Auto generate AUTHORS file for keystone component.

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

* AUTHORS
  Remove this file.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* keystone/openstack/common/setup.py
  generate_authors(): New method to create AUTHORS file. If
  AUTHORS.in file exists, append it's content to AUTHORS file.

* setup.py
  Import the new method.
  local_sdist.run(): Generate AUTHORS file before creating the
  package.

* tests/test_authors.py
  Remove this test case.

Change-Id: Id3ca59382e417d054d14f7735f30595bfbe2df48

commit_message:
Create name_label local variable for logging message

The missing local variable will end up logging an exception instead of
the intended message, however the code will continue functioning fine.

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/logging/__init__.py", line 776, in emit
    msg = self.format(record)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/logging/__init__.py", line 654, in format
    return fmt.format(record)
  File "/home/johannes/openstack/nova/trunk/nova/log.py", line 257, in format
    return logging.Formatter.format(self, record)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/logging/__init__.py", line 436, in format
    record.message = record.getMessage()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/logging/__init__.py", line 306, in getMessage
    msg = msg % self.args
KeyError: u'name_label'

Change-Id: I80bd91a8df51d5411e63ba6a44f227251baf2ab2

unnecessarily listen on all IPs.

commit_message:
Auto generate AUTHORS file for glance.

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

* Authors
  Remove this file. To be consistent with other projects,
  the new file AUTHORS is generated automatically.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* glance/common/setup.py
  generate_authors(): New method to create AUTHORS file. If
  AUTHORS.in file exists, append it's content to AUTHORS file.

* setup.py
  Import the new method.
  local_sdist.run(): Generate AUTHORS file before creating the
  package.

* MANIFEST.in
  s/Authors/AUTHORS

* glance/tests/unit/test_misc.py
  AuthorsTestCase: Remove this class that test an entry in
  Authors file.
  parse_mailmap(), str_dict_replace(): Remove these methods.

Change-Id: If83c3fe9b2142342ac11cc019bc24926f52ee753

[{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

These comments are duplicates of what I put on the related glance merge prop. I'm not sure the issues I raised are really blockers, though :-)"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Looks good to me, but you're missing a typo in the docstring"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not convinced that this is such a great thing for Puppet to use (i.e. why can't it write a single config file?) but I do like the feature

There's no need for it to be mutually exclusive with --config-file, though - I'd just make the contents of config-dir come after the config-files

That's especially important because we probably want make distros run nova by default with e.g.

  --config-file=/etc/nova/nova.conf --config-dir=/etc/nova/nova.conf.d

Otherwise puppet/chef would need to modify the systemd/upstart files

I don't understand this part of your commit message:

  all config items must reside in an explicitly specified section (i.e. it does not default to [DEFAULT])

Or maybe I do - your just explicitly calling out that the behaviour of nova.conf is the same as nova.conf.d/foo?

Process for the sake of process, I know, but please add a blueprint e.g. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-common/+spec/cfg-required-options"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

Thanks for the reviews folks, responses inline in patch set 1 and addressed in patch set 2.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Looks good to me. Thanks Eoghan

I wouldn't call the config files in --config-dir "fragments" - they're full blow config files, just like those specified by --config-file'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@markmc

Blueprint raised as requested:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-common/+spec/cfg-config-dir

The last sentence in the commit message is just a warning that the [DEFAULT] section must be explicitly re-opened in each config file containing options intended for that section, in order to avoid:

  ConfigFileParseError: Failed to parse foo.conf: at foo.conf:1, Section must be started before assignment: None'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Thanks for the review Mark,

Response inline to yout comment on the '.conf' tempfile suffix.

Good shout on the fragments versus, latest patch set is sanitized of the fragments terminology.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-common-merge/52/ : This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hmm, do we really want to limit it to .conf files

If I was using this, I'd expect to be able to do

  /etc/nova/nova.conf
  /etc/nova/nova.conf.d/00-foo
  /etc/nova/nova.conf.d/01-bar

I guess you're going for:

  /etc/nova/nova.conf
  /etc/nova/nova.d/00-foo.conf
  /etc/nova/nova.d/01-bar.conf

?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Approved

Ok, I can live with that. Looking at other conf.d type dirs, at least apache http requires the .conf extension on files in the dir'}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@markmc

Yep, the idea was to constrain the files considered config by expecting the .conf extension, so that the *-paste.ini file could also live in the same directory if necessary.

Otherwise we'd have no way of inferring the location of the paste config, if --config-dir was used but not --config-file, and the paste.config_file option wasn't configured anywhere."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (2 inline comments)

Thanks for the feedback Doug, responses inline and addressed in the latest patch set.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-01 15:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Support for directory source of config files

Implements bp cfg-config-dir

Allow multiple config files to be pulled in from a config directory,
as opposed to individual config files being explicitly enumerated.

This logic is enabled using the --config-dir=/path/to/config CLI option,
causing config to be retrived from all matching /path/to/config/*.conf
files.

Sections may be re-opened across config files, and all config items
must reside in an explicitly specified section (i.e. it does not default
to [DEFAULT]). This behavior is unchanged.

Change-Id: Ia29dffe82dfb4742dcf3e8d36b376d906a2492cf

commit_message:
Support conf from URL's with versions.

Adjusts our version match regex so that it detects URL's
which already have version's in them that start with
a '/'.

For example: '/v1'

Fixes LP Bug #992600.

Change-Id: I331e945c46757a01a4dd939b2098e68334b27530

commit_message:
Fix timeout in EC2 CloudController.create_image()

Fixes bug 989764

The timeout bounding the wait for the instance to stop is intended
to be 1 hour, but the code incorrectly specifies 60 hours instead
(no practical client is going to wait that long for a response).

Change-Id: I7aa4b539393df15f3b2c950cf7aeca4691ed3d73

commit_message:
Updates the cache

fixes bug 939122

Following are the changes done:
1. in compute/api.py to display the
   floating ip in nova list command upon
   its association with an instance.
2. in network/api.py to solve the similar
   issue upon the floating ip disasocaition

Change-Id: I247bedb5f8a3dee1d0df92ab29fce8758c3bdacb

commit_message:
Make KillFilter to handle 'deleted' w/o rstrip.

The initial code for this fixed used rstrip incorrectly.
This implementation uses endswith and rindex instead
and should read a bit more easily.

Also added a unit test to test that 'deleted' exe's are
filtered correctly.

Fixes LP Bug #967931.

Change-Id: I1783a8e2d59edd35734673b23e295f5a0b80b988

commit_message:
Fixes LP #992096 - Ensure version in URL

* Documents the configure_via_auth parameter
* Ensures that if configure_via_auth is used (the default), that
  if the management_url that is returned does not contain a version
  identifier, the client class' DEFAULT_DOC_ROOT is appended
  appropriately.
* Adds some log debugging statements into the base client class so
  that the URL being configured/constructed is more easily identifiable

Change-Id: I307a24231b59f7a183ed669f679976cc3f8ec21c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-30 19:58:12.000000000', 'message': 'Add host/port/api_version to tempest.conf

* Something exposed by LP #992096 was that the image
  tests were broken because the URL returned from the
  service catalog was no longer including a version
  identifier. The fix in Tempest was to pass the configure_via_auth=False
  parameter to the glance.client.Client constructor. However, in order
  for this to work, the host/port in the [image] section of the
  Tempest configuration file needs to be set

Change-Id: I9f661a02270a1ad52c10f2233baf899e5f706c82
'}]
commit_message:
Add host/port/api_version to tempest.conf

* Something exposed by LP #992096 was that the image
  tests were broken because the URL returned from the
  service catalog was no longer including a version
  identifier. The fix in Tempest was to pass the configure_via_auth=False
  parameter to the glance.client.Client constructor. However, in order
  for this to work, the host/port in the [image] section of the
  Tempest configuration file needs to be set

Change-Id: I9f661a02270a1ad52c10f2233baf899e5f706c82

commit_message:
Migrate block_device_mapping to use instance uuids.

This started out as wanting cleanup_volumes to take a UUID instead
of an instance ID, and ended up as a wander through the joys of
schema updates. I am assuming that we actually want to transition
these tables across to using the instance UUID instead of just the
ID.

This is my first attempt at a schema update, so please review this
patch with skepticism. Resolves bug 977975. Partially resolves
blueprint finish-uuid-conversion.

Change-Id: Ib5a6f8a872ea0530e201c70e9ac01cd14f82c557

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-30 04:57:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix InnoDB migration bug in migrate script 86.

Fixes bug 991672

Only change tables that aren't already InnoDB.  Attempting to migrate
an InnoDB table to InnoDB will causes an obscure "Error on rename"
error if the table has foreign key relationships.

Change-Id: I7bd5c964da851a8dd9cc0a6af3f93c07786b6781
'}]
commit_message:
Fix InnoDB migration bug in migrate script 86.

Fixes bug 991672

Only change tables that aren't already InnoDB.  Attempting to migrate
an InnoDB table to InnoDB will causes an obscure "Error on rename"
error if the table has foreign key relationships.

Change-Id: I7bd5c964da851a8dd9cc0a6af3f93c07786b6781

commit_message:
Use openstack.common.importutils.

Use import_class(), import_object(), and import_module() from
openstack-common's importutils module.  The equivalent functions have
been removed from nova.utils.  A few modules had import order cleaned up
in passing, as well.

My initial motivation for this was to remove some more usage of nova
bits from nova.rpc as another step towards being able to move nova.rpc
import openstack-common.  Since I was pulling importutils into nova, I
went ahead and converted the whole thing.

Change-Id: I7c7786cf0001bcd06db52b9a99ff4284a3f6c6fa

commit_message:
Port types and extra specs to volume api

 * Fixes bug 979089
 * Adds pollicy for new extensions
 * Fixes __init__ in testing directories
 * Cleans up existing volume types tests
 * Adds tests for type management
 * Adds tests for extra specs management
 * Removed unused Quota handling
 * Fixed typo in db volume_type_get

Change-Id: Ic80190ecf1d6d6ad0229e5af642a50c7c53bbbf9

commit_message:
Fixes LP #992096 - Add configure_via_auth=False

We now need to pass configure_via_auth=False to the glance
client constructor to signal that we don't want to have the
endpoint returned by the Keystone service catalog to override
the URL we are already passing in (the [image][host] configuration
option...)

Change-Id: Ie2ef15bfe03efe4b83e687d19283dfa66c25289e

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary return statements

If they're at the end of a function/method and don't return a value,
then it's superfluous

commit_message:
support a configurable libvirt injection partition

This is useful if all guest images have the same structure,
and the root partition is not the first partition.

This is also handy to enable inspection in libguestfs,
which can handle disparate and complicated image layouts.

In future we may change to a StrOpt to support
searching by partition label.

Change-Id: Ie94d61bec8fe4b41d6d2d6d3efa9a4364cf027fe

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-12 14:30:19.000000000', 'message': "Remove instance from 'Attach volume'
form if the instance is already attached
to that volume.

Fixes bug 970673.

Note: This fix only hides the attached instance
from the dropdown. As far as I understand,
There is another problem here, which should
be cleared out with Nova team.
Currently it is only possible to attach
single volume to a single instance. Multiple
volume <-> instance attachments should be
possible in next release(hopefully), when there
are implemented other volume adapters than iscsi
(e.g. NFS, Samba etc.) So Nova should send details
if the current volume supports multi-attachments
so that the whole attachment form should be hidden
for certain volume type. Also, for certain volume
types it might be possible to attach a single volume
to a single instance at different mount points...
So the whole attach behavior here might need some
refactoring one day...

Change-Id: I1bc02e7f18d48d7d5559516c022b522a9e95d2b3
"}]
commit_message:
Remove instance from 'Attach volume'
form if the instance is already attached
to that volume.

Fixes bug 970673.

Note: This fix only hides the attached instance
from the dropdown. As far as I understand,
There is another problem here, which should
be cleared out with Nova team.
Currently it is only possible to attach
single volume to a single instance. Multiple
volume <-> instance attachments should be
possible in next release(hopefully), when there
are implemented other volume adapters than iscsi
(e.g. NFS, Samba etc.) So Nova should send details
if the current volume supports multi-attachments
so that the whole attachment form should be hidden
for certain volume type. Also, for certain volume
types it might be possible to attach a single volume
to a single instance at different mount points...
So the whole attach behavior here might need some
refactoring one day...

Change-Id: I1bc02e7f18d48d7d5559516c022b522a9e95d2b3

[{'created': '2012-04-02 23:21:12.000000000', 'message': "You should be able to associate a token with 0 or more tenants.

The way in which the XSD is written today, a token after you log in
must be associated with a single tenant. This doesn't even match the
exmple here:

http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity-service/2.0/content/POST_authenticate_v2.0_tokens_Service_API_Client_Operations.html

Instead the token should be associated with 0 or more tenants.

Change-Id: I48fa41fa45943f2848483c1c9f56402f49cf00af
"}]
commit_message:
You should be able to associate a token with 0 or more tenants.

The way in which the XSD is written today, a token after you log in
must be associated with a single tenant. This doesn't even match the
exmple here:

http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity-service/2.0/content/POST_authenticate_v2.0_tokens_Service_API_Client_Operations.html

Instead the token should be associated with 0 or more tenants.

Change-Id: I48fa41fa45943f2848483c1c9f56402f49cf00af

commit_message:
Addresses lp#948243 - Tempest handles misconfig better

* Added Tempest base test class with test data
* Added logic to base test to reconfigure Tempest
  if the flavor/image sections are missing or if
  the provided values do not exist

Change-Id: I0c1bb16a65e36a99e6e49493325451c9a3eadaad

Update the message included in the exception from
importutils.import_class() to include what the inner exception was.
This is quite helpful as the real error may not have been that the class
was not found.  It may have failed to import the module that contains
that class, and it's nice to know that and why that happened.

Change-Id: I085864d230b46adce8921e362f058f9421a5a674
"}]
commit_message:
Update exception from importutils.import_class().

Update the message included in the exception from
importutils.import_class() to include what the inner exception was.
This is quite helpful as the real error may not have been that the class
was not found.  It may have failed to import the module that contains
that class, and it's nice to know that and why that happened.

Change-Id: I085864d230b46adce8921e362f058f9421a5a674

commit_message:
Handle authors existed before VCS was around.

Bug: 976267

The list of such authors are stored in AUTHORS.in file. When
auto generating AUTHORS file, include them as well.

* openstack/common/setup.py
  __doc__: For all methods, remove space and include period.
  generate_authors(): If AUTHORS.in file exist, append the
  content to AUTHORS file.

Change-Id: I05da1e561383cc151e7ef34e75a4600e3afdda6e

commit_message:
Omit Content-Length on chunked transfer

Content-Length and Transfer-Encoding conflict according to the HTTP
spec. This fixes bug 981332.

This also adds the ability to test both the sendfile-present and
sendfile-absent codepaths; the sendfile-present test will be skipped on
sendfile-absent platforms.

[ This is backported from 223fbee49a55691504623fa691bbb3e48048d5f3 ]

Change-Id: I20856eb51ff66fe4b7145f796a540a832c3aa4d8

subject: Support running tests against multiple Python versions.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2284, 'name': 'Eoghan Glynn', 'email': 'eglynn@redhat.com', 'username': 'eglynn'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-27 21:18:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-27 21:43:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Does tox not solve this problem for us?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-27 22:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

bcwaldon:

Maybe. Do people typically use tox in there dev environments? I thought it was just being used in the CI servers (could be completely wrong here).

The idea here was to make it dead simple to test multiple versions, if tox does that for us, then no need to reinvent the wheel :).'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-27 22:17:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think we're moving towards tox for what you're trying to get. See this review in python-glanceclient: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/6840/"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-30 15:37:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Just a point of information on the tox usage ...

In the run-up to the Essex RCs, I reverted from tox to run_tests.sh for the glance Jenkins build (with the agreement of the CI team) because the latter allowed us to use the glancelogcapture nose plugin to display service logs in-line for failed tests. 

This was kinda invaluable in getting to the bottom of the pesky intermittent S3 failures we had at the time, so if we were to go back to tox on the CI builds, I would like to figure some way of working in logcapture.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-04-30 17:28:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Hi!

I appreciate the work here, but we really need to get this working with tox. In the next month or so I want to delete all copies of install_venv.py and run_tests.py from all projects. If we can't figure out how to get glancelogcapture (or the things that it's doing) working with tox, then we will need to re-think the entire project's usage of it, because having two different methods of doing this long term is unworkable.

There are a couple of ways forward:

1) make a tiny project with the glancelogcapture plugin in it, release that to pypi and add it to test-requires. This feels slightly odd, but is also very easy compared to the other options. (this could be done in probably 15 minutes)

2) figure out how to get nose to consume the plugin using nothing but env vars and command line options.

3) Figure out how to make it a module that can be installed in to the tox venv by tox.

4) Figure out how to get glance to be able to do its dump logs function in a way that would be generally consumable by the standard nose logcapture plugin. First thoughts there are that rather than a dump_logs() call, we could put something it the tearDown() call which just does the stuff - preferably if we can only do it on test failure."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-30 17:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Consensus is to use tox.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-27 21:08:34.000000000', 'message': "Support running tests against multiple Python versions.

The goal of this patch is to make it easier to run the test suite under
mutiple Python versions. virtualenv already supports this using the `-p`
option, so all we're doing here is exposng that in `run_tests.sh`.

The `.venv` virtualenv containing the default version of Python will be
used by default. Specific versions will use directories named
`.venv_python2.X` and can be used by passing the VENV environment
variable to `with_venv.sh` like:

  VENV=.venv_python2.7 tools/with_env.sh my_command

Change-Id: I3b62a82fee5c31f2f29e051f421144f207089bf5
"}]
commit_message:
Support running tests against multiple Python versions.

The goal of this patch is to make it easier to run the test suite under
mutiple Python versions. virtualenv already supports this using the `-p`
option, so all we're doing here is exposng that in `run_tests.sh`.

The `.venv` virtualenv containing the default version of Python will be
used by default. Specific versions will use directories named
`.venv_python2.X` and can be used by passing the VENV environment
variable to `with_venv.sh` like:

  VENV=.venv_python2.7 tools/with_env.sh my_command

Change-Id: I3b62a82fee5c31f2f29e051f421144f207089bf5

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary references to resize_confirm_window flag

The value of the resize_confirm_window flag is passed into the
poll_unconfirmed_resizes() method so there is no need to reference
FLAGS.resize_confirm_window directly for logging.

Change-Id: Ia9729cda4bf4408c2f5fce19709e9bdb474ad721

Remove the unused novaclient dependency.

Change the keystoneclient dependency to a git URL.

Add test-requires, and move some pip-requires dependencies
into it.

Remove the test_utils unit test which wasn't testing anything
that is actually present in the project.

Add the test_authors unit test.

Use tox for running tests locally.

See: http://wiki.openstack.org/ProjectTestingInterface

Tox can manage virtualenvs, and is currently doing so for running
tests in Jenkins. It's just as, or more, useful for running tests
locally, so this starts the migration from the run_tests system to
tox. The goal is to reduce duplicate testing infrastructure, and
get what's running locally on developer workstations as close to
what is run by Jenkins as possible.

Run_tests.sh will now call tox to facilitate the transition for
developers used to typing "run_tests.sh".

Developers will need tox installed on their workstations. It can
be installed from PyPI with "pip install tox". run_tests.sh outputs
those instructions if tox is not present.

New facilities are available using tox directly, including:

tox -e py26 # run tests under python 2.6
tox -e py27 # run tests under python 2.7
tox -e pep8 # run pep8 tests
tox # run all of the above
tox -e venv foo # run the command "foo" inside a virtualenv

The OpenStack nose plugin is used when running tox from the
command line, so the enhanced, colorized output is visible to
developers running the test suite locally. However, when Jenkins
runs tox, xunit output will be used instead, which is natively
understood by jenkins and much more readable in that context.

Change-Id: Ib627be3b37b5a09d3795006d412ddcc35f8c6c1e
'}]
commit_message:
Add openstack-common and test infrastructure.

Fix pep8 errors (project is pep8 clean now).

Update setup.py to use openstack-common style dependencies.

Remove the unused novaclient dependency.

Change the keystoneclient dependency to a git URL.

Add test-requires, and move some pip-requires dependencies
into it.

Remove the test_utils unit test which wasn't testing anything
that is actually present in the project.

Add the test_authors unit test.

Use tox for running tests locally.

See: http://wiki.openstack.org/ProjectTestingInterface

Tox can manage virtualenvs, and is currently doing so for running
tests in Jenkins. It's just as, or more, useful for running tests
locally, so this starts the migration from the run_tests system to
tox. The goal is to reduce duplicate testing infrastructure, and
get what's running locally on developer workstations as close to
what is run by Jenkins as possible.

Run_tests.sh will now call tox to facilitate the transition for
developers used to typing "run_tests.sh".

Developers will need tox installed on their workstations. It can
be installed from PyPI with "pip install tox". run_tests.sh outputs
those instructions if tox is not present.

New facilities are available using tox directly, including:

tox -e py26 # run tests under python 2.6
tox -e py27 # run tests under python 2.7
tox -e pep8 # run pep8 tests
tox # run all of the above
tox -e venv foo # run the command "foo" inside a virtualenv

The OpenStack nose plugin is used when running tox from the
command line, so the enhanced, colorized output is visible to
developers running the test suite locally. However, when Jenkins
runs tox, xunit output will be used instead, which is natively
understood by jenkins and much more readable in that context.

Change-Id: Ib627be3b37b5a09d3795006d412ddcc35f8c6c1e

messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-25 06:17:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Thanks for this fix.  I noticed the issue the other day during a hackathon but didn't get around to filing the bug.

I think this needs a little bit before merging

a) a bug report and a reference in the commit message

b) a test

Optionally:

c) if one or more address is specified, it probably makes more sense to get the ips individually (see how we do it in describe_volumes for example). of recent changes with glanceclient, but at least
this patch gets the tools/configure_tempest working
again.

[{'created': '2012-04-27 14:22:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fix timeout in EC2 CloudController.create_image()

Fixes bug 989764

The timeout bounding the wait for the instance to stop is intended
to be 1 hour, but the code incorrectly specifies 60 hours instead
(no practical client is going to wait that long for a response).

Change-Id: I7aa4b539393df15f3b2c950cf7aeca4691ed3d73
'}]
commit_message:
Fix timeout in EC2 CloudController.create_image()

Fixes bug 989764

The timeout bounding the wait for the instance to stop is intended
to be 1 hour, but the code incorrectly specifies 60 hours instead
(no practical client is going to wait that long for a response).

Change-Id: I7aa4b539393df15f3b2c950cf7aeca4691ed3d73

commit_message:
Fixes steps 2 and 3 of identity image. Fixes bug 911892.
Step 2 is a get tenants request and has a response with it. Added the response.
Step 3 assumes a scoped token to a tenant so added a call to get the scoped token.

Change-Id: I457c08d56e95b9fc953f4298ce7d23cf91277692

commit_message:
Added img metadata validation. Fixes bug 962117.

1. Added validation for image metadata.
2. Renamed the method 'check_img_metadata_quota_limit' to
'check_img_metadata_quota_limit' since it also validates the image metadata.
3. Added unit test cases.

Change-Id: Iabb01d1848d7770abd68bf7d52491ddb92c0bca7

Also, you need to format according to the hacking guidelines."}, {'account_id': 2264, 'date': '2012-03-30 22:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-04-02 17:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hey Ben - you also need to restore the original commit message here.'}, {'account_id': 2264, 'date': '2012-04-02 18:58:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-04-02 19:35:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

See inline comments.'}, {'account_id': 2264, 'date': '2012-04-02 20:06:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-04-13 15:22:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not submit

(2 inline comments)

errexit does not cause the script to exit when a command returns non-zero exit code when the command is in a sub-shell, such as in backticks.  You need to do something like this to test for command failure:

    MEMBER_ID=`keystone role-list | grep Member | cut -d '|' -f2 | tr -d ' '`
    die_if_not_set MEMBER_ID "failure getting member id"

This fails immediately because keystone requires admin privs for almost everything and the default in openrc is to set up the demo account.  The die_if_not_set function is in 'functions':

    source ./functions

To get admin privs:

    source ./openrc admin admin'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-28 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-28 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
change the default value of the flag "host" from socket.gethostname() to socket.getfqdn()

"In case no fully qualified domain name is available, the hostname as
returned by gethostname() is returned."

http://docs.python.org/library/socket.html

fixes bug 981294

Change-Id: I182af87572b84f19338de53b2765d6f41770dbbd

subject: Use tox for running tests locally.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-04-26 16:56:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

This looks mostly great - I'm not sure that the tox.ini is fully correct..."}, {'account_id': 3099, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:04:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I, too, question the [tox:hudson] section. Purpose of that?'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:41:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:44:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Good points.  I've reinstated with_venv.sh as a compatability layer (but still think it should be removed when run_tests.sh is removed).

I fixed the tox:jenkins section, which was wrong in the original file, and changed the method of selecting the nose plugins to environment variables, that way we're not copying the nosetests command everywhere which runs a higher risk of bit-rot."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:44:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Shrews pointed out that nosexunit is not required, as the xunit functionality is in core nose, so that dependency is removed.'}, {'account_id': 3099, 'date': '2012-04-26 18:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

All looks good by me now.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-04-26 21:55:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Hmm, run_tests.sh doesn't work for me now:

./run_tests.sh: line 42: syntax error near unexpected token `&'
./run_tests.sh: line 42: `tox -e py27 $toxargs |& tee run_tests.err.log  || exit'"}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-27 18:47:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-27 18:49:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

The script specifies /bin/bash, and that should be understood by bash, and works for me on oneiric with:

GNU bash, version 4.2.10(1)-release (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu)

I've uploaded a new patchset that does the pipeline tee slightly differently."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-27 19:12:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

[{'created': '2012-04-26 16:38:09.000000000', 'message': 'Use tox for running tests locally.

See: http://wiki.openstack.org/ProjectTestingInterface

Tox can manage virtualenvs, and is currently doing so for running
tests in Jenkins.  It's just as, or more, useful for running tests
locally, so this starts the migration from the run_tests system to
tox.  The goal is to reduce duplicate testing infrastructure, and
get what's running locally on developer workstations as close to
what is run by Jenkins as possible.

This patch removes run_tests.py, and the scripts that manage .venv.
It makes run_tests.sh call tox to facilitate the transition for
developers used to typing "run_tests.sh".

  tox -e py27  # run tests under python 2.7

  tox -e venv foo  # run the command "foo" inside a virtualenv

locally.  However, when Jenkins runs tox, the xunit plugin will be
used instead, providing output natively understood by jenkins which
is much more readable in that context.

commit_message:
Use tox for running tests locally.

See: http://wiki.openstack.org/ProjectTestingInterface

Tox can manage virtualenvs, and is currently doing so for running
tests in Jenkins.  It's just as, or more, useful for running tests
locally, so this starts the migration from the run_tests system to
tox.  The goal is to reduce duplicate testing infrastructure, and
get what's running locally on developer workstations as close to
what is run by Jenkins as possible.

This patch removes run_tests.py, and the scripts that manage .venv.
It makes run_tests.sh call tox to facilitate the transition for
developers used to typing "run_tests.sh".

Developers will need tox installed on their workstations.  It can
be installed from PyPI with "pip install tox".  run_tests.sh outputs
those instructions if tox is not present.

New facilities are available using tox directly, including:

  tox -e py26  # run tests under python 2.6
  tox -e py27  # run tests under python 2.7
  tox -e pep8  # run pep8 tests
  tox          # run all of the above
  tox -e venv foo  # run the command "foo" inside a virtualenv

The configuration of the openstack nose plugin is removed from
setup.cfg and added to the nosetests command line arguments in tox.
It is used when running tox from the command line, so the enhanced,
colorized output is visible to developers running the test suite
locally.  However, when Jenkins runs tox, the xunit plugin will be
used instead, providing output natively understood by jenkins which
is much more readable in that context.

Change-Id: Id678c2fb8a5a7d79c680d3d1f2f12141f73dc8a6

[{'created': '2012-04-27 21:40:19.000000000', 'message': "Use sqlalchemy sessions correctly so locking works

Fixes bug 990118

When using with_lockmode, it's necessary to use the same session for both
the select and the subsequent update/delete. Since a new session was
being used for each part, the lock was becoming an effective noop and
two requests could race with each other. Make sure we use one session
to prevent this from happening.

Change-Id: I6765c97266d13b795f1153b440cfc556df065787
"}]
commit_message:
Use sqlalchemy sessions correctly so locking works

Fixes bug 990118

When using with_lockmode, it's necessary to use the same session for both
the select and the subsequent update/delete. Since a new session was
being used for each part, the lock was becoming an effective noop and
two requests could race with each other. Make sure we use one session
to prevent this from happening.

Change-Id: I6765c97266d13b795f1153b440cfc556df065787

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-24 16:46:22.000000000', 'message': "Fix content type for qpid notifier.

Fix bug 980872.

This patch fixes a regression I introduced in
2d36facf14f4eb2742ba46274e04a73b5231aece.  In that patch, I adjusted the
content_type for messages sent with the qpid notifier to be
'application/json' to match a change that went into the kombu notifier.
Unfortunately, it's wrong.

I assumed based on the kombu change that notifications were being json
encoded before being passed into the notification driver.  That's not
the case.  The message is a dict.  So, just revert the change to set the
content_type and let Qpid encode the notification as 'amqp/map'.

(cherry picked from commit 5bed23cbc962d3c6503f0ff93e6d1e326efbd49d)

Change-Id: I8ba039612d9603377028ba72cb80ae89d675c741
"}]
commit_message:
Fix content type for qpid notifier.

Fix bug 980872.

This patch fixes a regression I introduced in
2d36facf14f4eb2742ba46274e04a73b5231aece.  In that patch, I adjusted the
content_type for messages sent with the qpid notifier to be
'application/json' to match a change that went into the kombu notifier.
Unfortunately, it's wrong.

I assumed based on the kombu change that notifications were being json
encoded before being passed into the notification driver.  That's not
the case.  The message is a dict.  So, just revert the change to set the
content_type and let Qpid encode the notification as 'amqp/map'.

(cherry picked from commit 5bed23cbc962d3c6503f0ff93e6d1e326efbd49d)

Change-Id: I8ba039612d9603377028ba72cb80ae89d675c741

Remove server-specific functionality.

 * Moved server-specific functionality found in quantum.common to
   the quantum repo.
 * Renamed primary package from quantum -> quantumclient.
 * Addresses bug 977711 and bug 921933

Fix instance delete notifications.

Remove extra exists event horking uptime calculations.
Fix broken deleted_at time in notifications (was blank due to being
pulled from the wrong field on the instance)

commit_message:
Updating the Compute Admin guide to bring the XML into compliance with the documentation conventions.

Other files will be committed as they're updated.
Fix bug 967297
Fixed merge on admin, configure, networking, and scheduler.
Fixed missing para tag.
Update pom.xml files for Quantum and API site.
Minor validation fixes for Quantum admin manual.

Change-Id: Idf77e2ed3d0cce61b01f3ca2ef8844beb65c77be

Updating more files in the compute admin guide. bug 967297

Change-Id: Iaa7649af928f4c794c1d014b713340e7b1e3b565

subject: Disconnect stale instance VDIs when starting nova-compute
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-04-27 08:44:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Good idea.  However, I'm concerned about the fact that exceptions in init_host() make nova-compute die on startup and I see potential for exceptions here.

One case could be that 'resize2fs' is still running on a device and it didn't get killed when nova-compute was killed.  The vbd unplug would fail, I'd think... though I guess it's possible it may just block.

I'm not sure I have any good suggestions, though."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-27 14:46:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-27 14:49:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's unlikely since unplug_vbd() will wait for a while until it can unplug the VBD.

However, it's easy enough to add an exception handle to init_host and log what happened.

Failure to cleanup at startup isn't fatal so we should continue."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-04-27 15:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-27 16:22:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Nice.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-27 16:39:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3691/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2329/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1988/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3722/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-27 16:39:16.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-27 05:49:36.000000000', 'message': 'Disconnect stale instance VDIs when starting nova-compute

Fixes bug 989306

If nova-compute is killed, or the compute domU is shutdown uncleanly,
instance VDIs can remain attached to the compute domU. This complicates
cleaning up unused VDIs, but can also result in reaching a limit on
the number of VBDs for the compute domU, preventing new instances
from being built.

Change-Id: Ie56e0561aa02178d6718b74a87bbb591fa869007

If nova-compute is killed, or the compute domU is shutdown uncleanly,
instance VDIs can remain attached to the compute domU. This complicates

Change-Id: Ie56e0561aa02178d6718b74a87bbb591fa869007
'}]
commit_message:
Disconnect stale instance VDIs when starting nova-compute

Fixes bug 989306

If nova-compute is killed, or the compute domU is shutdown uncleanly,
instance VDIs can remain attached to the compute domU. This complicates
cleaning up unused VDIs, but can also result in reaching a limit on
the number of VBDs for the compute domU, preventing new instances
from being built.

Change-Id: Ie56e0561aa02178d6718b74a87bbb591fa869007

subject: Add additional capabilities for computes

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-24 15:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-24 16:20:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Correct me if I'm wrong: this is a brand new capability, that isn't yet used anywhere?

That's great!  But, rather than define each new capability one-by-one, how about we support one flag for compute overrides?

e.g. --capabilities="allowed_vm_type=kvm, gpu=nvidia9600, storage=ssd, power=redundant, supports_migration=yes"

Either parsing a string, or using a multi-valued option (if that is supported).'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-04-24 16:43:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Doesn't nova already support this through host aggregates?

If not, some tests are needed for this new feature."}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-04-25 19:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Joe: No, aggregates is more about subdividing availability zones, and hosts cannot be in more than one. This is a capability, i.e. "can this host run HVM vm's or not?"

I can throw a unittest on it.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-04-25 19:51:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

justinsb: It's sortof new. We have some custom schedulers using it. The list idea is interesting, but how would you set the defaults on that?"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-04-25 21:39:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

At the Folsom Summit there was talk of making multi-membership aggregate work.

http://etherpad.openstack.org/FolsomNovaHostAggregates-v2

Once multi-membership aggregates is implemented, IMHO you should be able to do  "can this host run HVM vm's or not?" using aggregates.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-25 21:52:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

agreed that this should be done with host aggregates, but this seems like a decent interim solution since we are still using capabilities for filtering at the moment.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-25 22:53:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Re defaults: good point.  I think that a default value simply shouldn't be in the dictionary; effectively we default to None.

Does vm_type=all achieve anything special that I'm missing vs. assuming that if it's not specified we don't care?

I'm trying to avoid an explosion of flags & capabilities here!"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-04-26 18:17:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with Justin, I am concerned about an explosion of flags & capabilities.

I am afraid that an interim solution will become the de-facto solution.  Since there is still plenty of time to work on Folsom, why not work skip the interim solution and go straight to the long term solution?

If this interim solution does go through, at the very least it should contain some tests and clear documentation about being an interim solution.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-04-27 06:10:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-04-27 06:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Changed implementation to a more general lost of additional capabilities, added unittests, including missing _report_driver_status unittest (our periodic tasks need more tests) 

This should tide us over (we are deploying schedulers needing this kind of functionality within days) until the improved HostAggregates code lands.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-04-27 06:15:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

er, thats a _list_ of capabilities :P'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-27 14:25:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Code-wise, looks good, but there's some nits in a docstring to take care of"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-04-27 15:16:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Kevin's changes aside, lgtm"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-04-27 15:24:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think the interim solution is necessary for the time being, the list has solved the flag explosion, and I don't care about capitalization."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-27 16:02:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Vek had a couple of legit femtonits, but nothing that needs to hold back the patch.

Always welcome to clean them up in a follow-on patch :D.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-27 16:14:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

commit_message:
Add additional capabilities for computes

This allows compute hosts to advertise additional capabilities
for use by custom schedulers. This is an interim solution to
provide this functionality until it is replaced by more general
HostAggregate functionality later in Folsom.

Change-Id: Ia288146fa92aec61f50641c2e4f7a3580ab03a32

[{'created': '2012-04-10 15:39:30.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor nova.rpc config handling.

This patch does a couple of things:

1) Remove the dependency of nova.rpc on nova.flags.  This is a step
toward decoupling nova.rpc from the rest of nova so that it can be moved
to openstack-common.

2) Refactor nova.rpc so that a configuration object is passed around as
needed instead of depending on nova.flags.FLAGS.

This was done by avoiding changing the nova.rpc API as much as possible
so that existing usage of nova.rpc would not have to be touched.  So,
instead, a config object gets registered, cached, and then passed into
the rpc implementations as needed.  Getting rid of this global config
reference in nova.rpc will require changing the public API and I wanted
to avoid doing that until there was a better reason than this.

Change-Id: I9a7fa67bd12ced877c83e48e31f5ef7263be6815
