commit_message:
Refactor nova.rpc config handling.

This patch does a couple of things:

1) Remove the dependency of nova.rpc on nova.flags.  This is a step
toward decoupling nova.rpc from the rest of nova so that it can be moved
to openstack-common.

2) Refactor nova.rpc so that a configuration object is passed around as
needed instead of depending on nova.flags.FLAGS.

This was done by avoiding changing the nova.rpc API as much as possible
so that existing usage of nova.rpc would not have to be touched.  So,
instead, a config object gets registered, cached, and then passed into
the rpc implementations as needed.  Getting rid of this global config
reference in nova.rpc will require changing the public API and I wanted
to avoid doing that until there was a better reason than this.

Change-Id: I9a7fa67bd12ced877c83e48e31f5ef7263be6815

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-26 13:14:32.000000000', 'message': 'Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working

Fixes bug 975043

Since Essex, all instances will have an eth0 MAC address in the range
of FA:16:3E, which is near the end of the MAC address space.

When openvpn is started, a TAP interface is created with a random
generated MAC address. Chances are high the generated MAC address is
lower in value than the eth0 MAC address. Once the tap interface is
added to the bridge interface, the bridge interface will no longer have
the eth0 MAC address, but take over the TAP MAC address. This is a
feature of the linux kernel, whereby a bridge interface will take the
MAC address with the lowest value amongst its interfaces. After the ARP
entries expire, this will result in the cloudpipe instance being no
longer reachable.

This fix, randomly generates a MAC address starting with FA:17:3E, which
is greater than FA, and will thus ensure the brige will keep the eth0 MAC
address.

Change-Id: I0bd994b6dc7a92738ed23cd62ee42a021fd394e2
'}]
commit_message:
Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working

Fixes bug 975043

Since Essex, all instances will have an eth0 MAC address in the range
of FA:16:3E, which is near the end of the MAC address space.

When openvpn is started, a TAP interface is created with a random
generated MAC address. Chances are high the generated MAC address is
lower in value than the eth0 MAC address. Once the tap interface is
added to the bridge interface, the bridge interface will no longer have
the eth0 MAC address, but take over the TAP MAC address. This is a
feature of the linux kernel, whereby a bridge interface will take the
MAC address with the lowest value amongst its interfaces. After the ARP
entries expire, this will result in the cloudpipe instance being no
longer reachable.

This fix, randomly generates a MAC address starting with FA:17:3E, which
is greater than FA, and will thus ensure the brige will keep the eth0 MAC
address.

Change-Id: I0bd994b6dc7a92738ed23cd62ee42a021fd394e2

commit_message:
Added instance name for volume attachment

Fixes bug 974916.

The instance is displayed in the same way
as it is in volume detail page.

Patch 2: Instances are read from self._data,
as it is expected that this data is already
available during table construction.

Change-Id: I27186463c20793283b3d083235fbf7818d5a4082

OK - I've fixed the pep8 line-too-long and I think I'm finally happy with the naming etc.  Sorry for the multiple iterations!"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-04-26 14:35:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Are there tests for this change in a different changeset?'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-26 14:47:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

No tests; I don't see how a unit test can do anything useful here.  I tested it by hand instead."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-04-26 15:17:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Yeah, I was looking at _get_config_drive_info(). I guess it's simple enough to not need tests, but I wasn't sure what the "policy" was.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-26 15:26:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

It's a good (broader) point Doug.  Would we want a policy that demanded that this have a unit test?  I personally feel that our testing effort is already too heavily weighted to unit tests vs integration tests.  A manual "integration" test caught a real bug in this patch: originally I missed the 'second' usage of config_drive (when building the libvirt XML).

The real answer here is good software engineering practice; other languages - for example - encourage us to wrap field access in functions, so that this simply couldn't happen.  We can do a refactor to extract and encapsulate the config drive logic, but every time I do something like that I'm told it's unpythonic.

I could write a unit test which covers the _get_config_drive_info function, but it would simply be a restatement of the code, and wouldn't really achieve anything beyond what eyeballs achieve in a code review.

I don't know what the answer is here.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-26 18:44:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-04-27 01:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-27 02:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3683/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2321/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1980/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3714/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-27 02:48:48.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Add a force_config_drive flag

Config drive can currently only be requested via the API.  That
doesn't play nice with horizon, and requires the caller to know
what the image expects.

Currently, only None or 'always' are documented (although any
value is treated as 'always').  I expect we'll want 'never',
'byimage' etc in future.

Bug #988556

Change-Id: I895a6a9fd3e6395bb00f54f26531b6faf0c9f4f1

commit_message:
Make the filename that image hashes are written to configurable.

This is a baby step towards storing more than just a checksum in
these files. The specific use case is I need to store whether or
not the image was prefetched in here as well.

Change-Id: Ia1d67ac1ac766f22c6ecb814182150a789c91095

subject: Make it easy to have VNC without scrollbars
messages:
[{'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-04-24 10:39:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The <a> text should be used with {% trans %}. Also, I think it would be better to have target="_blank", and a text saying something like "Open VNC console in a new window"...'}, {'account_id': 1446, 'date': '2012-04-24 11:44:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think, that target=_blank is not useful there, as you often do not want to keep open the existing page with the iframe'd VNC. And if users really want a new tab/window, they can ctrl-click or middle-click the link in most browsers (tried firefox, chromium and opera) while it is not as easy to prevent such a new window when you don't want it."}, {'account_id': 1446, 'date': '2012-04-24 12:07:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-04-25 18:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Remove dependency on python-quantumclient

 * quantum previously depended on python-quantumclient for the
   functionality in quantum/common.  This change migrates
   the required modules to the quantum repo and removes that
   dependency.
 * Addresses bug 977711

Change-Id: Ia17a486859eb1aa993900a5f3b582b258c6a6d78

commit_message:
Merge registry context with common context

Pull the extra methods defined in glance.registry.context:RequestContext into
glance.common.context:RequestContext. This is necessary as the new v2 API
implementation talks directly to the database.

* Partially implements bp api-2

Change-Id: Ia8c1fde511bdca69be0dcf61ce12976ace5f7dc3

commit_message:
Improvements to flavor details in the launch instance dialog. The
relevant pieces of the flavor are now shown in a table above the auota
usage and update dynamically when a flavor is selected.

Fixes bug 988560

Change-Id: I688347054ad17732eb96d6580a68b39d5cf9a809

subject: make all mysql tables explicitly innodb
messages:
[{'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-25 20:30:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There is a separate patch coming in through draft with the CI team to actually test and ensure that no new mysql tables get added which aren't InnoDB."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-25 22:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

block device mapping line is too long. Otherwise looks good. If the pep8 error is fixed, consider it a +2 from me. If another core member approves, feel free to fix the pep8 and push it through.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-04-25 22:51:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So why is MyISAM often the default if it's worse?
If changing for pep8 you might as well change the bug reference in the commit message to one that's recognized and linked by Gerrit.

cheers."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:47:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm Okay with doing this as an upgrade mechanism but I really hate that we have to use this code in our migrations to begin with.

In the future when we should just set these correctly in the initial migrations. For example when adding a table we'd just need to add to the Table constructors:

        mysql_engine='InnoDB',
        mysql_charset='utf8'

One pep8 error too:

nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/086_set_engine_mysql_innodb.py:30:80: E501 line too long (80 characters)"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:50:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dan, I agree that this should be on default table creation, but it isn't right now, so this is needed to get us there. There is an associated unit testing approach that is going to check that no new tables come in that aren't InnoDB to prevent us from getting here.

pep8 fixed in new revision coming now"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-26 17:51:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-04-26 18:36:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I can appreciate Dan's frustration. One question regarding foreign key constraints...

It seems that converting a existing tables like this will change the storage engine, but does not create the FK constraints that would have been created if the database server was configured to use InnoDB by default during the initial migrations.  I'm wondering if, in addition to just changing the engine, we should also be creating any missing constraints to ensure that the models in nova accurately reflect the schema.  
This has been problematic in the past when new migrations are added that overlook FK constraints because they simply do not exist."}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-04-26 18:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Also, a  bit outdated but you can get a sense of the number of relationships that we model in nova that end up missing when initial migrations are run without InnoDB: 

http://people.canonical.com/~agandelman/schema/innodb/relationships.html'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:07:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Looks like the new quota table got missed?  Also it needs to be converted to utf8 as well.  I like dans request that new tables add the params as well."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Migration #77 looks like it set the charset for the whole database to utf8, so that should already be covered (which you can do, unlike engine type).'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:44:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-26 20:12:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

ah, i didn't realize that utf8 was set in the db my the migration.  looks good then.

I guess dan's request to explicitly set utf8 when new tables are created isn't needed then?  We just need to explicitly set innodb."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-26 22:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Vish: Correct. My example was just a general example suggesting that we should always add InnoDB and Utf8 to our new MySQL table creation migrations. For this migration just the InnoDB is fine I think.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-26 22:45:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-26 23:04:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3672/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2315/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1974/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3708/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-26 23:19:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Approved

Dan: As mentioned in an earlier comment, migration 077 does:

54         sql += "ALTER DATABASE %s DEFAULT CHARACTER SET utf8;" \
55             % migrate_engine.url.database

so i don't think we need to explicitly set utf8 on new tables.

(also, rekicking)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-26 23:38:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3673/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2316/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1975/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3709/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-26 23:38:22.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-20 23:05:06.000000000', 'message': 'Restore the syntax -U tenant:user

On a relatively recent build of swift, all my scripts blew up with
"No tenant specified". It was caused by the patch by Chmouel Boudjnah
that added --os_tenant_name, commit ID:
 208b8e85a80e46ddb49dc2035cb292570a20c7db

This patch restores the old behavior. Note that the incompatibility
was gratious, as the patch provides a perfect compatibility. Any scripts
should work: those using -U as before, those using --os_tenant_name and
written before this patch, and those using the new style in the future,
even if they insert a literal colon into the user or tenant name.

Change-Id: I7785e6981a9d6281d0421c43875ee19d61d5ff43
'}, {'created': '2012-04-24 23:49:42.000000000', 'message': 'Restore the syntax -U tenant:user

On a relatively recent build of swift, all my scripts blew up with
"No tenant specified". It was caused by the fix to add --os_tenant_name,
commit ID:  208b8e85a80e46ddb49dc2035cb292570a20c7db

This patch restores the old behavior. I tested it to work with old
swauth-based Swift, new Keystone-based Swift, in the latter case using
both -U and --os_tenant_name arguments.

Note that this patch permits to use a literal colon in the user name
with the new syntax, as long as tenant is specified. Not quite sure
what Chmouel's intent was about it, but this should be safe.

Change-Id: I7785e6981a9d6281d0421c43875ee19d61d5ff43
Bug: 982909
'}, {'created': '2012-04-26 17:00:58.000000000', 'message': 'Restore the syntax -U tenant:user

On a relatively recent build of swift, all my scripts blew up with
"No tenant specified". It was caused by the fix to add --os_tenant_name,
commit ID:  208b8e85a80e46ddb49dc2035cb292570a20c7db

This patch restores the old behavior. I tested it to work with old
swauth-based Swift, new Keystone-based Swift, in the latter case using
both -U and --os_tenant_name arguments.

Note that this patch permits to use a literal colon in the user name
with the new syntax, as long as tenant is specified. Empty tenant
names are not allowed with either syntax.

Change-Id: I7785e6981a9d6281d0421c43875ee19d61d5ff43
Bug: 982909
'}]
commit_message:
Restore the syntax -U tenant:user

On a relatively recent build of swift, all my scripts blew up with
"No tenant specified". It was caused by the fix to add --os_tenant_name,
commit ID:  208b8e85a80e46ddb49dc2035cb292570a20c7db

This patch restores the old behavior. I tested it to work with old
swauth-based Swift, new Keystone-based Swift, in the latter case using
both -U and --os_tenant_name arguments.

Note that this patch permits to use a literal colon in the user name
with the new syntax, as long as tenant is specified. Empty tenant
names are not allowed with either syntax.

Change-Id: I7785e6981a9d6281d0421c43875ee19d61d5ff43
Bug: 982909

commit_message:
Clients subclass the RestClient to allow attributes to be
overrided by each client and allow better code reuse.

Changes the RestClient to set the token and base_url when
it is needed for a request. Also allows for it to be cleared
so that it can be renewed.

Fixes lp#977594

Change-Id: I040d1c171a4018326a5b700e303652c95a3b3542

subject: return the full response from FakeAppObject
messages:
[{'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-24 17:53:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ionut,

I upgraded my webob to the most recent version and ran the unit tests for Swift.

I got scores of failures:

FAILED (SKIP=8, errors=86, failures=8)

Do you see similar errors when you run swift's unit tests with the latest webob?"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-25 11:32:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Greg,

I get the exact same output as you do on 1.2b2. However all the tests in test/unit/common/middleware/test_swift3.py run fine with this patch.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-25 11:36:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Actually I get a bit less failed tests, but I have python-webob from an rpm which might have some patches applied already.

Ran 848 tests in 25.098s

FAILED (SKIP=8, errors=85, failures=6)'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-25 19:10:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ionut,

I'm trying to understand the purpose of your submission.

1)  The test passes with the version of webob that swift uses.

2)  A bunch of tests besides this test fail with the latest version of webob.

Why is it important to make just this test pass with the latest webob?

I might be misunderstanding something.  Please help me out.  = )"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-26 07:47:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ok, I'll try to be more clear.

First of all this patch is primarily intended for the stable/essex branch, where the test fails with newer versions of python-webob. I also sent the fix to master, so that we would hopefully have the same code in the two branches. Right now we're using 1.1.1, but I tested it against the newest version (1.2b2), just to make sure that it's a future-proof fix (this is what I reported in launchpad).

As per your comments:

> 1) The test passes with the version of webob that swift uses.

Yes, but some Linux distributions (including SUSE) package their own version of python-webob. So in our case, swift "uses" webob 1.1.1.

> 2) A bunch of tests besides this test fail with the latest version of webob.

But that is not in any way related to this fix, the same number of other tests fail with and without this fix. So I don't see how that's relevant.

> Why is it important to make just this test pass with the latest webob?

Because for us (webob 1.1.1) this is the only test which fails _on stable/essex_.

Btw, https://review.openstack.org/#/c/6619/ is not a duplicate of this. That one is meant for the stable/essex branch. Or maybe I got the backporting procedure wrong?'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:16:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ionut, thanks for the answers.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:56:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/69/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/69/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/184/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-26 19:57:59.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

'}, {'account_id': 1475, 'date': '2012-04-09 14:09:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-09 14:31:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

A couple of nits and a question I'd like you to address; please see in-line"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-09 14:45:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Agree with Kevin's comments."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-09 14:51:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Mandar!

Nothing wrong with making the client do some pre-checking of the label length, but shouldn't the server side be validating this kind of thing before it gets to the SQLAlchemy warning (which only warns with MySQL, since PostgreSQL will give an error and SQLite will ignore it, IIRC)

Thoughts?
-jay"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-09 15:09:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Jay: This is a patch against nova-manage, which isn't, strictly speaking, a client."}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-12 09:33:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Kevin : Made changes suggested by you.

Jay : As Kevin already mentioned, this is patch against nova-manage. 

create_networks() doesn't seem to be called from any place other than nova-manage. 

All the validations for params passed to create_networks are done in nova-manage itself. 

I also confirmed that NetworkManager.create_networks() and QuantumManager.create_networks() do not perform any validation on the params. BTW, these are library calls not RPC calls (in context of your mention of server-side validation)

Either we move ALL the validations to respective create_networks calls or add this additional validation in nova-manage. I chose the later to be consistent with rest of the code."}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-12 09:57:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-04-13 00:38:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-17 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Brian is OK with Patch Set 3 changes.

Others : Please review this change. Otherwise it will be auto-abandoned(?) by Gerrit after 7 (?) days of inactivity.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-17 06:04:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

Hmmm, I drafted these some time ago, but apparently neglected to actually publish the comments'}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-18 08:05:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-18 08:06:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-18 14:44:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-04-22 14:04:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-04-22 17:50:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm not generally a fan of hard-coding magic numbers like this. Is there a nicer way of encoding the max length here so that if the max length were ever to change in the DB schema, it would be easier to find and update this check?

I won't hold this up though, since nova-manage should hopefully be gone by Folsom, so long-term maintenance issues here are less important."}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-04-25 16:43:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Disallow network creation when label > 255. Fixes bug 965008

Added length check for label. Without length check,
label is truncated. Warning is shown by sqlalchemy layer.

Raise an InvalidInput exception when validation fails (like
rest of the surroudning code)

Change-Id: Iae517e03099e36f1c00f4742049834a9231a2fff

commit_message:
Introduced _atomic_restart_dhcp() Fixes Bug 977875

Introduced a new method which executes update_dhcp_text_file
and restart_dhcp as one atomic unit - to avoid race between these
steps.

Change-Id: I6fda9fbfcaf59fa6a4859b361574d98e16331882

subject: Make updating hostId raises BadRequest.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-09 14:09:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Please remove the code snippet from your commit message. Additionally, the top line of your message should be a 50 char summary of the change, followed by a blank line. You need to replace 'Bug I'd:' with 'bug ' so gerrit will recognize it, too."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-09 17:36:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

also if you just use 'bug 944028' it will autolink to the bug for you.

Commit message should be something like:

Make updating hostId raise BadRequest.

fixes bug 944028

Updating the server hostId to another name not raising a Bad Request.I have written a piece of code in such a way that if we try to update the hostId it will raise the bad Request exception, HostId cannot be updated."}, {'account_id': 3016, 'date': '2012-04-11 03:56:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-04-11 19:38:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I uploaded three patches from "one vm" with branch (bug-944028), that vm is not working now. I want to upload another patch for the same branch(bug-944028) from "another vm" . How can i do it.


Can you please suggest me in this.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-25 14:59:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

you can do the following:

sudo pip install -U git-review

git review -d 6360 # will download this review into a branch

<make changes>

git commit --amend -a

git review'}, {'account_id': 3016, 'date': '2012-04-26 04:40:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-26 15:49:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-26 15:23:09.000000000', 'message': "Use nova_uuid attribute instead of trying to parse out name_label

The name_label parsing code is out-of-date since key support was
added to the format string, but it's not needed anymore since
the internal uuid was added to other-config for a while now.

Change-Id: I2902320ae7118e42cd3d18f2d6d0fab0fcbec687
"}]
commit_message:
Use nova_uuid attribute instead of trying to parse out name_label

The name_label parsing code is out-of-date since key support was
added to the format string, but it's not needed anymore since
the internal uuid was added to other-config for a while now.

Change-Id: I2902320ae7118e42cd3d18f2d6d0fab0fcbec687

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-23 17:28:44.000000000', 'message': "Add distribute to test-requires.

Currently glance (which is required for testing by keystone because
there is no python-glanceclient yet) requires distribute>=0.6.24,
but it can't be installed as a dependency of a dependency.  Requiring
it explicitly here should help.

Install test-requires first, otherwise distribute doesn't get properly set.

Install distribute manually until we can re-address venv creation.

Align webob version to the other projects due to version conflicts.

Change-Id: Iac0b6860c600fbf230cf4f602ce1b76c68fcb7cd
"}]
commit_message:
Add distribute to test-requires.

Currently glance (which is required for testing by keystone because
there is no python-glanceclient yet) requires distribute>=0.6.24,
but it can't be installed as a dependency of a dependency.  Requiring
it explicitly here should help.

Install test-requires first, otherwise distribute doesn't get properly set.

Install distribute manually until we can re-address venv creation.

Align webob version to the other projects due to version conflicts.

Change-Id: Iac0b6860c600fbf230cf4f602ce1b76c68fcb7cd

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-26 09:49:38.000000000', 'message': 'Support for directory source of config files

Implements bp cfg-config-dir

Allow multiple config files to be pulled in from a config directory,
as opposed to individual config files being explicitly enumerated.

This logic is enabled using the --config-dir=/path/to/config CLI option,
causing config to be retrived from all matching /path/to/config/*.conf
files.

Sections may be re-opened across config files, and all config items
must reside in an explicitly specified section (i.e. it does not default
to [DEFAULT]). This behavior is unchanged.

Change-Id: Ia29dffe82dfb4742dcf3e8d36b376d906a2492cf

sq

Change-Id: Ic29283bea4de9a8308c4002131f5e0687aaf06b4
'}]
commit_message:
Support for directory source of config files

Implements bp cfg-config-dir

Allow multiple config files to be pulled in from a config directory,
as opposed to individual config files being explicitly enumerated.

This logic is enabled using the --config-dir=/path/to/config CLI option,
causing config to be retrived from all matching /path/to/config/*.conf
files.

Sections may be re-opened across config files, and all config items
must reside in an explicitly specified section (i.e. it does not default
to [DEFAULT]). This behavior is unchanged.

Change-Id: Ia29dffe82dfb4742dcf3e8d36b376d906a2492cf

sq

Change-Id: Ic29283bea4de9a8308c4002131f5e0687aaf06b4

commit_message:
Fix Modified Error message when AMQP Server is unreachable

To PING the AMQP Server using socket calls
When AMQP Server is Unreachable display error message
If PING is success,login to the Server
If the credentials are invalid then display error message

Fixes bug 918238

commit_message:
Refactor sql options avoid using CONF

Pass a conf instance to many of the sql functions so that CONF can
be completely removed in subsequent commits.

Move the option definitions into a sql.opts module since both sql.core
and sql.migration rely on the same options. In theory, this could make
it easier for someone to copy and re-use either of those modules
individually.

Also remove sql.min_pool_size, sql.max_pool_size and sql.pool_timeout
since they are unused.

Change-Id: I51b1b13f66d6e13e3bc56bc96c0fdd224773d53c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-26 11:15:22.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor password utils into separate module

The code is so self-contained, it seems a shame to have it lumped into
a generic utils module.

We make hash_password() use a supplied conf instance rather than CONF
to help us remove CONF completely in subsequent commits where the conf
instance will be an attribute of the identity drivers.

A default value for crypt_strength is also added to keystone.conf.

Change-Id: I143f9a582354e9c8bb3ee1e12e7f2862ed63dd13

commit_message:
Refactor password utils into separate module

The code is so self-contained, it seems a shame to have it lumped into
a generic utils module.

We make hash_password() use a supplied conf instance rather than CONF
to help us remove CONF completely in subsequent commits where the conf
instance will be an attribute of the identity drivers.

A default value for crypt_strength is also added to keystone.conf.

Change-Id: I143f9a582354e9c8bb3ee1e12e7f2862ed63dd13

I might be mistaken in reading this, but doesn't this change mean that all backends have to share a common configuration set, based on the manager? 

That seems an odd middle ground to not having a global config. If you want to have it segregated, then wouldn't it make sense to have the configuration options needed by the individual backends defined and loaded from those backends, not the managers?

Am I missing something? Doesn't seem to match the pattern..."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-16 13:48:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Unless I'm missing something, then yeah I think you missed something :-)

The only config option managed by managers is the driver option

I basically haven't changed anything in terms of whether options need to be shared between drivers or which group they need to be registered under

The token driver's expiration option is shared between all token backends and is in the [token] group

The templated catalog backend has configuration specific to it under the [catalog] group

The ldap identity backend has a bunch of configuration under the [ldap] group

The memcache token backend has configuration under the [memcache] group

The rules policy backend has a couple of config options under the [DEFAULT] group"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-16 14:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-19 16:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Re-factor how service driver options are handled

Define the {catalog,ec2,identity,policy,token}.driver options in
the manager class which use them. The base manager class registers
them.

Also supply a conf instance to the constructor of each of these
manager classes so that the global CONF variable can be removed in
a subsequent commit.

Change-Id: Ica37e8ba31063ba7f33d92d31a57ad728d72de8c

commit_message:
memcache token backend refactoring

A trivial refactoring to isolate the memcache.servers option in the
memcache.Token class.

In a subsequent commit, the conf instance will be an attribute of
token.Driver and the lameness of using using config.CONF will be
removed.

Also add a default value for it in keystone.conf.

Change-Id: I092a8feca069751692ef279858bd7dae115872c2

commit_message:
Refactor port options

The admin_port and public_port options are only used in the tests and
in keystone-all. Move their definitions to the wsgi module and add
a helper method for registering them.

The compute port option is only used in the templated catalog backend,
so move its definition there.

Change-Id: I947cebf789f929eea768b24b8cbf7b50950047fb

commit_message:
Refactor admin_token handling

Move the admin_token option definition to the AdminTokenAuthMiddleware
class where it is used.

Also, explicitly set the admin_token value in the tests to make things
more clear.

Change-Id: I2c13e3bf7cab5cc306936e3115877fe3e51df7a2

So that we can remove all CONF references from our WSGI apps, pass a
conf instance to their constructors. We need to make sure that e.g.
add_routes() is only called on a router app after its base class
constructor has been called and its conf attribute set.

Change-Id: I77cd0d3b95c8448b76856fb0492871811399534f

commit_message:
Pass conf instance to WSGI app constructors

So that we can remove all CONF references from our WSGI apps, pass a
conf instance to their constructors. We need to make sure that e.g.
add_routes() is only called on a router app after its base class
constructor has been called and its conf attribute set.

Change-Id: I77cd0d3b95c8448b76856fb0492871811399534f

commit_message:
Remove use of global CONF in service drivers

Make each of the service drivers take a conf instance paramater to its
constructor and use that instead of CONF.

The use of super(..., self).__init__() is avoided because of the mess
it causes with multiple inheritance in e.g. kvs.Identity where you
want identity.Driver to be supplied a conf instance from the preceeding
constructor in the MRO (i.e. kvs.Base).

Change-Id: Ia217628b9603ea906586b551f0ef7ef53e697b75

[{'created': '2012-02-26 11:15:26.000000000', 'message': 'Add generic PasteDeploy factories from glance

PasteDeploy has no way of passing parameters to an app or filter
factory constructor except through options in the config file.

We want to pass a conf instance to these constructors, so we do a
lame trick where we stuff a conf instance into a global variable
before the factory is run and have the factory pass it on to the
constructor. Rather than duplicate the lame hack in a bunch of
places we have a single generic set of factories and do it there.

This code is copied straight from glance. It should eventually live
in openstack-common.

Change-Id: I0886c3e923483a8b319d2e3d07b9c59e5fad3e0d

commit_message:
Add generic PasteDeploy factories from openstack-common

PasteDeploy has no way of passing parameters to an app or filter
factory constructor except through options in the config file.

We want to pass a conf instance to these constructors, so we do a
lame trick where we stuff a conf instance into a thread local storage
before the factory is run and have the factory pass it on to the
constructor. Rather than duplicate the lame hack in a bunch of
places we have a single generic set of factories and do it there.

Change-Id: I0886c3e923483a8b319d2e3d07b9c59e5fad3e0d

There is only one Melange service, no need for the prefixed service name for
grouping that is used by Glance, Nova and Quantum.  Just use 'melange' in
ENABLED_SERVICES.

There is a DEPRICATED message displayed at the end of stack.sh as a reminder

Fixes bug 968537

Change-Id: Id93546ef73db875854aff55a09c212badb5ce7c9
"}]
commit_message:
Depricate 'm-svc', use 'melange'

There is only one Melange service, no need for the prefixed service name for
grouping that is used by Glance, Nova and Quantum.  Just use 'melange' in
ENABLED_SERVICES.

There is a DEPRICATED message displayed at the end of stack.sh as a reminder
for users to update their configurations.

Fixes bug 968537

Change-Id: Id93546ef73db875854aff55a09c212badb5ce7c9

subject: rpc call/cast declares queue.
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-10 21:03:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Invalid docstring.  Also, please reformat the commit message as per http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritWorkflow; it's currently showing up as a single absurdly long line, which makes it difficult to tell what the change is for.  Also, can you point me to where create_empty_queue() is actually used?"}, {'account_id': 2968, 'date': '2012-04-11 06:14:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2968, 'date': '2012-04-11 06:31:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-11 15:28:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Still some nits to fix up on your docstring.  Make sure you've read HACKING.rst"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-04-11 17:26:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not submit

The creating of the empty queue should, I believe, be within the Publisher class, not within each cast/call implementation.

That allows you to use the same TCP connection for creating the queue that you use for publishing.  Your patch in current form, creates a brand new TCP connection for each cast/call.  If the implementation needed to be done in the cast/call methods for some reason, you should at least use the connection pool.

Ideally, I'd like to avoid having to create the queue on every single message, but I'm not sure there is a way around that..

So, can you see about creating the queue within the Publisher class...  Publisher.reconnect()?"}, {'account_id': 2968, 'date': '2012-04-12 06:50:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-04-25 17:49:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

You probably want to abandon this review, since you've created a new review for this bug."}, {'account_id': 2968, 'date': '2012-04-26 04:18:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

Added a new Review page https://review.openstack.org/6478 for this bug.'}]

[{'created': '2012-04-05 10:03:33.000000000', 'message': 'Bug - 919835. Fixed creating an empty queue while calling the rpc call/cast methods. Added "create_empty_queue" method in Connection class. Invoked this method in the call and cast methods for creating an empty queue for the topic.

Change-Id: I64fd21fcf9aba58836f0a96fb715393b235f7c0c
'}, {'created': '2012-04-11 06:14:10.000000000', 'message': 'Bug - 919835. Fixed creating an empty queue while calling the rpc call/cast methods. Added "create_empty_queue" method in Connection class. Invoked this method in the call and cast methods for creating an empty queue for the topic.

Change-Id: I64fd21fcf9aba58836f0a96fb715393b235f7c0c
'}, {'created': '2012-04-11 06:31:52.000000000', 'message': 'rpc call/cast declares queue.

Fixes Bug 919835.

Created a new method "create_empty_queue" in Connection class of rpc module. rpc call/cast methods will invoke this method to create the queue.

When there is no queue for a service in Rabbit MQ
list-queues and a rpc call/cast method is called
for that service, the message will be dropped.
In order to not to drop that message, the
create_empty_queue method is used.

I have tested this in following scenario:
When the scheduler is down and Rabbit MQ is
restarted, there will be no queue for scheduler.
So when a user tries to create an instance, the
vm state will go to BUILD state and hangs for
ever even if we restart the scheduler. If we
create a empty queue before the call/cast method
then the message will be dropped in to the queue.
When the scheduler is up again, it picks the
message and process the request and brings the
vm state to ACTIVE.

Change-Id: I64fd21fcf9aba58836f0a96fb715393b235f7c0c
'}, {'created': '2012-04-12 06:50:43.000000000', 'message': 'rpc call/cast declares queue.

Fixes Bug 919835.

Created a new method "create_empty_queue" in Connection class of rpc module. rpc call/cast methods will invoke this method to create the queue.

When there is no queue for a service in Rabbit MQ
list-queues and a rpc call/cast method is called
for that service, the message will be dropped.
In order to not to drop that message, the
create_empty_queue method is used.

I have tested this in following scenario:
When the scheduler is down and Rabbit MQ is
restarted, there will be no queue for scheduler.
So when a user tries to create an instance, the
vm state will go to BUILD state and hangs for
ever even if we restart the scheduler. If we
create a empty queue before the call/cast method
then the message will be dropped in to the queue.
When the scheduler is up again, it picks the
message and process the request and brings the
vm state to ACTIVE.

Change-Id: I64fd21fcf9aba58836f0a96fb715393b235f7c0c
'}]
commit_message:
rpc call/cast declares queue.

Fixes Bug 919835.

Created a new method "create_empty_queue" in Connection class of rpc module. rpc call/cast methods will invoke this method to create the queue.

When there is no queue for a service in Rabbit MQ
list-queues and a rpc call/cast method is called
for that service, the message will be dropped.
In order to not to drop that message, the
create_empty_queue method is used.

I have tested this in following scenario:
When the scheduler is down and Rabbit MQ is
restarted, there will be no queue for scheduler.
So when a user tries to create an instance, the
vm state will go to BUILD state and hangs for
ever even if we restart the scheduler. If we
create a empty queue before the call/cast method
then the message will be dropped in to the queue.
When the scheduler is up again, it picks the
message and process the request and brings the
vm state to ACTIVE.

Change-Id: I64fd21fcf9aba58836f0a96fb715393b235f7c0c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-10 13:59:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix expired token tests

The expiration timestamps are expressed in UTC time, so ensure:

 1) The timestamp of the token created by the test is UTC time (i.e.
    utcnow() vs now())

 2) The expiration check in the dummy memcache client properly
    accounts for UTC (i.e. utctimetuple() vs timetuple())

Change-Id: Ie7356456f79ab5a8070a79771bb7d210b1cedd47
'}, {'created': '2012-04-23 18:53:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix expired token tests

Fixes bug #983800

The expiration timestamps are expressed in UTC time, so ensure:

 1) The timestamp of the token created by the test is UTC time (i.e.
    utcnow() vs now())

 2) The expiration check in the dummy memcache client properly
    accounts for UTC (i.e. utctimetuple() vs timetuple())

Change-Id: Ie7356456f79ab5a8070a79771bb7d210b1cedd47
'}]
commit_message:
Fix expired token tests

Fixes bug #983800

The expiration timestamps are expressed in UTC time, so ensure:

 1) The timestamp of the token created by the test is UTC time (i.e.
    utcnow() vs now())

 2) The expiration check in the dummy memcache client properly
    accounts for UTC (i.e. utctimetuple() vs timetuple())

Change-Id: Ie7356456f79ab5a8070a79771bb7d210b1cedd47

commit_message:
Fixes connection leak in rpc connection pool.

Put connection back to the pool when exception occurs in iterconsume.
Fixes bug 968843.

Change-Id: Ica6ff1b5dfd293f71141e2d41be0658ceac8f243

[{'created': '2012-04-06 02:32:32.000000000', 'message': 'Stub out swift log configuration during testing

 * s3_token and swift_auth depend on swift.common.utils.get_logger,
   which configures a syslog handler in an OS X-incompatible way.

commit_message:
Stub out swift log configuration during testing

 * s3_token and swift_auth depend on swift.common.utils.get_logger,
   which configures a syslog handler in an OS X-incompatible way.
   This change ensures that get_logger is stubbed out for the
   swift middleware tests to allow the Keystone test suite to execute
   successfully under OS X.
 * Addresses bug 974583

Change-Id: Ibdb665d1ea65c13ef792767ad66251857629a702

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-25 15:09:35.000000000', 'message': 'Some refactoring of the cfg cache

A fairly misc bunch of changes:

 - init cache before registering config-file and just let
   register_cli_opt() clear the empty cache

 - use @__clear_cache on set_default() and set_override() since
   these are just used by the unit tests and doing so allows us
   to kill _remove_from_cache()

 - use @__clear_cache on reset() too

 - remove recursion from _get() and the substitute param

 - just use (group_name, opt_name) as the cache key

Change-Id: I66934e748eca9ec03e44d7f80a7e10d96a77d8eb
'}]
commit_message:
Some refactoring of the cfg cache

A fairly misc bunch of changes:

 - init cache before registering config-file and just let
   register_cli_opt() clear the empty cache

 - use @__clear_cache on set_default() and set_override() since
   these are just used by the unit tests and doing so allows us
   to kill _remove_from_cache()

 - use @__clear_cache on reset() too

 - remove recursion from _get() and the substitute param

 - just use (group_name, opt_name) as the cache key

Change-Id: I66934e748eca9ec03e44d7f80a7e10d96a77d8eb

commit_message:
Do not assume network names

It might be anything else than "public" or "private". This fixes bug #978958.

Change-Id: Id15d5416b6e437750d352e38873880fef286cfc0
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

[{'created': '2012-04-14 03:08:07.000000000', 'message': 'Omit Content-Length on chunked transfer

Content-Length and Transfer-Encoding conflict according to the HTTP
spec. This fixes bug 981332.

This also adds the ability to test both the sendfile-present and
sendfile-absent codepaths; the sendfile-present test will be skipped on
sendfile-absent platforms.

[ This is backported from ecae6abeb57ed0680f0230a953df3e9ce1efe759 ]

Change-Id: Ibb017b4a43d89ffdb6b868648296603cfec7780d
'}]
commit_message:
Omit Content-Length on chunked transfer

Content-Length and Transfer-Encoding conflict according to the HTTP
spec. This fixes bug 981332.

This also adds the ability to test both the sendfile-present and
sendfile-absent codepaths; the sendfile-present test will be skipped on
sendfile-absent platforms.

[ This is backported from ecae6abeb57ed0680f0230a953df3e9ce1efe759 ]

Change-Id: Ibb017b4a43d89ffdb6b868648296603cfec7780d

subject: Introduced flag base_dir_name. Fixes bug 973194
messages:
[{'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-05 09:34:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-04-05 11:19:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hmm, I guess this would fix the problem, but perhaps it would be possible to share the _base dir between hosts?

I wonder could you just define --lock_path to a shared nfs directory, and use external=True for the locks?

This suggests it (lockfile) might work with that:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Computing/2009_April_2#Atomic_operations_on_NFS
Note utils.cleanup_file_locks() only does so for each host,
so it should work as long as each hostname is unique.

Though a shared scheme could introduce large latencies
between systems, especially as we're dealing with the
processing of large files. So it would be safer and
less invasive to use _base_$HOSTNAME/"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-04-05 11:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

You'll also have to at least update nova/virt/libvirt/imagecache.py too.

cheers"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-05 18:30:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I don't particularly like this solution as you will end up with many copies of the same base image.  If you have a shared filesystem, you should use a file lock to ensure that the two hosts are not downloading concurrently.

The easiest way to do this would be to add external=True to the utils.synchronized decorators below and to make sure the lock_path is on a shared filesystem as well.  If you want to make sure that only these particular locks are shared, perhaps you could modify utils.synchronized to take an optional lock_path argument to override the location for the file locks and pass in: @utils.synchronized(..., external=True, lock_path=FLAGS.instances_path).

Unfortunately these locks wouldn't be automatically cleaned up by the lock cleanup script so perhaps there is a better solution."}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-11 04:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Vish :
I understand and agree to both of your comments, but as both of you mentioned, there isn't a better solution to this problem.

So I suggest that I make my solution conditional - to be invoked only when a config param - say "separate_image_cache_per_computehost"

Default this will be set to False - so default we'll have current behavior. 

For user running into the problem scenario mentioned in the bug (NFS mounted shared instance_path) they can set this flag to True and work-around the problem.

Comments ? Thoughts ?'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-04-11 08:04:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

Well adding config isn't needed I think.
You either need per host _base or you don't.
I.E. If you can't make a shared _base work,
then we would need per host _base.

Did you try our suggestions for a shared _base?
Are you worried about the latencies of a shared NFS dir?
Did you hit other issues?

BTW, you missed the comment about updating imagecache.py.
It would probably need to handle both _base and _base_<...>

cheers."}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-13 10:42:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Pdraig,
Config is better because the problem described is a corner case - This issue may be caused only when cache image folder is empty AND two instances on two different VMs are spawned at the same time AND both nova-compute try to download the images to cache on shared nfs path.
If there the cache already has an image, then subsequently spawning concurrent VMs may not run into this issue.

As you mentioned in your previous comment, latencies when dealing with large image files could be problem.

I'm submitting a new patch, where instead of flag - I'm introducing config param to define the name of base folder. Currently it is hardcoded to "_base" - Which will still be the default. To enable "per-host" image cache if-and-when-needed, user needs to set "base_dir_name=_base_$my_ip" in their nova.conf. 
This makes the code much more cleaner than Patch Set 2, as well as other solutin I proposed, where I was planning to use "if per_host_cache - then .." style of coding.

I've modified imagecache.py too (and some test cases using hardcoded "_base" )'}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-13 10:49:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-13 17:25:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Good thought. This is much simpler and handles your use case well without modifying default behavior.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-04-14 12:00:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

thanks for the cleanups'}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-17 05:46:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Both Vish and Padraig are OK with changes, Can someone approve ? Otherwise it will be auto-abandoned(?) by Gerrit after 7 (?) days of inactivity.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-24 15:57:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I'm not a libvirt expert, but Smokestack and Vish are happy and I see no reason for this to die on the vine."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-24 16:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3666/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-25 06:31:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-04-25 06:42:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Patch Set 3 was uploaded on Apr 13th. 

Patch set 3 was approved on April 24th -  - there were a few commits in master since Patch set 3 .

As per Jenkins, merge was successful : https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2273/


But then "Gerrit Code Review" said :
"Your change requires a recursive merge to resolve. Please merge (or rebase) the change locally and upload the resolution for review."

So I have rebased and resubmitted patch set 4 - There were no conflicts.

Code is same as Patch Set 3 - Please approve.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-25 07:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Introduced flag base_dir_name. Fixes bug 973194

rebased from master.

If user faces locking related problem when two nova-compute hosts
sharing same disk area via nfs, try to download same image into
cache concurrently - Then base_dir_name can be set to "_base_$my_ip" in
nova.conf

Default value for base_dir_name is "_base" thus retaining existing
behavior.

Change-Id: Icff10ed75ba83f7256731614dc9e01e578b347a4

[{'created': '2012-04-24 11:58:40.000000000', 'message': 'Scope coverage report generation to nova module.

Coverage report generation was not using --include filters.
This resulted in generating a report that included all external
dependencies. Some of these may include problematic characters for
utf8 decoding. In the odd case this was found, coverage would fail
with a UnicodeDecodeError.

Fixes bug #987077.

Change-Id: I276698e65ac1037972209a406058168433cd826b
'}]
commit_message:
Scope coverage report generation to nova module.

Coverage report generation was not using --include filters.
This resulted in generating a report that included all external
dependencies. Some of these may include problematic characters for
utf8 decoding. In the odd case this was found, coverage would fail
with a UnicodeDecodeError.

Fixes bug #987077.

Change-Id: I276698e65ac1037972209a406058168433cd826b

commit_message:
Fixed metadata validation err. Fixes bug 965102.

1. Fixed the error message on specifying invalid server metadata key/value.
2. Added check to disallow specifying blank metadata key.
3. Added unit test coverage.

Addressed review comments.

Change-Id: I1f0002971dc236045d6e622641f46a4a30249d54

commit_message:
Remove last few uses of CONF

Only a few refernences to CONF exist at this point in the cli code
and tests.

Also, the need for ConfigMixin is pretty much eliminated at this
point since we can just pass the default config files list to the
ConfigOpts constructor.

Change-Id: Id041b83692c9b1f6bb12cb2b8cbf3233c5366f6a

Mark:

I'm showing a conflict in keystone/config.py when I merge this patch series with keystone master."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-02-28 16:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-02-28 16:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Dan, rebased now'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-02-29 03:11:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Guess I may as well start here (maybe I should have let you keep your giant patch since I'll be asking a lot of generic questions here).

1. What do you see as the problems with having a global shared config?
2. What do you see as the benefit of creating separate getters for config options?
3. Wdysat benefit of providing configuration through paste as well as through global config?
4. What do you think of the changes I made to prevent automatic config/commandline parsing in config? They were done to allow me to pass in nose params to tests.


Some statements from me to get you started on how I think:

1. I'd prefer that the passwd file be named password, but I also don't see the point in separating it out in the first place as I think that needlessly creates a new file when utils already serves as a "misc" file (everything in there could be its own file).
2. I like moving the option definitions closer to their usage, that was always the intention but leaving them in that one spot made it easier to newcomers to figure out how to use configuration.
3. I do think it is much nicer to use shortcuts for option registration, it is significantly less verbose than the alternative and is what I'd consider an obvious step. Additionally I think groups should automatically be created when referenced by a new option.'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-02-29 03:12:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not submit

dear lord, formatting, also this should be a -2 :p


Guess I may as well start here (maybe I should have let you keep your giant patch since I'll be asking a lot of generic questions here).

1. What do you see as the problems with having a global shared config?

2. What do you see as the benefit of creating separate getters for config options?

3. Wdysat benefit of providing configuration through paste as well as through global config?

4. What do you think of the changes I made to prevent automatic config/commandline parsing in config? They were done to allow me to pass in nose params to tests.


Some statements from me to get you started on how I think:

1. I'd prefer that the passwd file be named password, but I also don't see the point in separating it out in the first place as I think that needlessly creates a new file when utils already serves as a "misc" file (everything in there could be its own file).

2. I like moving the option definitions closer to their usage, that was always the intention but leaving them in that one spot made it easier to newcomers to figure out how to use configuration.

3. I do think it is much nicer to use shortcuts for option registration, it is significantly less verbose than the alternative and is what I'd consider an obvious step. Additionally I think groups should automatically be created when referenced by a new option.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-02-29 03:49:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think the big point to make here is consistency. Having a consistent cfg module between the projects is a good thing, and having one project doing things differently makes long-term maintenance more challenging.

I'll let Mark answer the specifics on paste vs regular config, but from my perspective having a global CONF variable is neither an elegant solution nor particularly useful -- it just gets annoying when trying to use different configurations during testing and requires a bunch of hacks.

I'm actually not a fan of defining options close to where they are used -- I'm more of a fan of a single place to see options. However, I compromised in Glance on this particular point because I recognize the greater value in consistency across projects and saw that a number of developers preferred the GFlags way of defining options near usage."}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-02-29 19:06:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Well, just for the record you haven't answered any of my questions Jay, so I hope Mark tackles them all.

Re: project consistency, we don't have that right now and I would prefer it goes my way."}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-03-05 21:09:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is great Mark.

@termie, Enriching common utils within a project really serves  no useful process for the entire project.  Whilst the features you have outlined sound useful, it sounds like something which should be made common amongst openstack tools, rather than special-casing one... That way leads dragons.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-06 10:04:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It's a little hard to have a conversation like this in gerrit, so I've posted to the mailing list on what is probably the biggest points worth discussing i.e.

# "problems with having a global shared config?"
# "nicer to use shortcuts for option registration"

On some of the other points:

- "creating separate getters": looking over the keystone patches again, I agree that some of the places where I've done this are a bit lame. It's just a side effect of removing the global CONF object in most cases. I think I can cook up something better for those cases.
- "benefit of providing configuration through paste as well as through global config?" - not sure I understand the question
- "changes I made to prevent automatic config/commandline parsing in config?" - not sure I understand what you mean here either. Do you mean the default value for args in ConfigMixin.__call__? If so, it looks like a hack needed because you're using a global object. In glance, I added a TestConfigOpts class which was only used in the tests to override ConfigOpts.__call__. I looks like the command line options for keystone-all are broken at the moment because of this mixin code?
- "don't see the point in separating [passwd] out in the first place" - I think it's a nice modularity win and that a "misc" file should be a last resort. A module which contains the 4 password related utility functions makes perfect sense to me. But, in any case, it's not critical - I can easily undo that if you like.
- "easier to newcomers to figure out how to use configuration" - I think a good default config file containing documentation and defaults for all of the options is the best approach here'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-06 10:09:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Oh and re:

"Re: project consistency, we don't have that right now and I would prefer it goes my way."

I don't agree with that at all. If keystone uses divergent patterns from other projects, those patterns will become ingrained over time.

I'm perfectly willing to work through figuring out a set of patterns that all projects are happy with, so bear with me.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-06 10:13:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I missed this:

"Additionally I think groups should automatically be created when referenced by a new option."

Yeah, that should be doable - you should probably only need to define a group explicitly if you want to set some help text/title for the group'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-06 10:17:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Filed https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-common/+bug/947861 for the groups thing'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-06 13:31:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

For reference, the thread on the list is: https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg08329.html'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-03-06 22:53:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

i've responded to the large issues in your mailing list post, I don't think we're very far off on the other ones so we can hash those out quickly once we come to some sort of resolution on the larger issues."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-12 06:32:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The debate at this point is mostly around the use of a global object

https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg08450.html'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-13 14:27:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-13 14:37:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok, given Joe's mail, I re-based the series.

commit_message:
Remove cfg wrappers from keystone.config

The idea with the cfg module is that we can have all projects using not
only the same code for config, but using similar idioms that will be
familiar to anyone working on OpenStack.

The register_*() wrappers don't add much in the way of convenience, but
if we really want them, we can add them to cfg itself.

Subsequent commits in this series remove the global CONF object and
move option definitions closer to where the option is used. The end
result is worth considering as well as this initial baby step.

Change-Id: Ia8e11592417fa67cf3682e494653b8e6ba166244

commit_message:
Refactor policy rules driver to avoid global CONF

Move the options related to this driver into the driver class and only
use them within the class.

Add a new class to encapsulate the logic of the policy cache and use
helper methods to interact with the global instance of that cache.

This refactoring has a nice side-effect of cleaning up the unit tests
fairly significantly. No need for teardown methods to reset state and
more easily disable loading the policy file by stubbing out the
load_policy function.

Change-Id: I6f843f245cef3a99a03dba398e3d02c7cc356525

commit_message:
Refactor ldap identity backend options

Move the options definitions closer to where they are used, add default
values to the option definitions and rely on them, reconcile defaults
in the code with defaults in the config file.

Change-Id: I663a4d1d7a332171cb4ca130a6ec23d646859f12

commit_message:
Instance in state "error" after resize is solved

Fixes bug 907921

Resize works when the instance in the SUSPENDED state,
and it throws an exception if instance is in ACTIVE state.

In nova.conf file, add this flag --allow_resize_to_same_host=true

Change-Id: I9db11bb10c211323279b6a5b3e5e524db09404ae

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-23 22:04:51.000000000', 'message': 'Strip version from service catalog endpoint

This client includes the API version in the URL directly where the
former practice was to include it in the service catalog endpoint.
This change removes the version from the last component of the
SC endpoint (if present) for transition purposes.

Note that this does not generalize to the other APIs
where the version is not the last component of the SC endpoint.

Change-Id: Ie04c38d80b17a171482e195aa1c633b6b6974042
'}]
commit_message:
Strip version from service catalog endpoint

This client includes the API version in the URL directly where the
former practice was to include it in the service catalog endpoint.
This change removes the version from the last component of the
SC endpoint (if present) for transition purposes.

Note that this does not generalize to the other APIs
where the version is not the last component of the SC endpoint.

Change-Id: Ie04c38d80b17a171482e195aa1c633b6b6974042

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-25 02:56:49.000000000', 'message': 'Set a more reasonable default RPC thread pool size

No service should be doing over 1000 different tasks at once. It can
only possibly end up overloading other dependent services. 64 should
be a more reasonable starting point.

Change-Id: I7690ad4a9cfc5ee11e1990d5cecdf23522f11f72
'}]
commit_message:
Set a more reasonable default RPC thread pool size

No service should be doing over 1000 different tasks at once. It can
only possibly end up overloading other dependent services. 64 should
be a more reasonable starting point.

Change-Id: I7690ad4a9cfc5ee11e1990d5cecdf23522f11f72

subject: Removes unnecessary code in _run_instance.
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-23 13:52:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Have you seen this deadlock occur or is this just theoretical? I'm trying to figure out a scenario where InstanceNotFound would be raised with the locking the currently exists.

Either way, I agree the code should be removed."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-23 14:18:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

It wouldn't be the first time I was wrong, but I don't think the build and delete are sufficiently synchronized yet for us to completely ignore the case the removed code was intended to handle.

For example, imagine if a delete comes in while an instance's build request has not yet made it through the scheduler. Then the instance won't have a "host" attribute set, and the compute api will just perform the delete in the database without ever sending a message to the compute manager.

Perhaps depending on a race condition, this situation will result in an InstanceNotFound exception during the instance_get_by_uuid call in _run_instance. We should probably still handle that in a way that doesn't just set the instance to ERROR and potentially leak resources.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-23 14:26:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I considered that and looked at the code path, but I can't see how it will end up in ERROR. The call to _set_instance_error_state will end up raising InstanceNotFound since the instance is already deleted. So while you end up with extra exceptions in the logs, the instance should remain deleted, right?

Also, what resources would be leaked? And if some do get leaked, isn't that a bug in the scheduler for marking the instance as deleted but assuming that compute will clean it up when it loses the race?"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:57:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Johannes-

Looking further though the code, I agree with you. But we shouldn't be spitting out false error messages to the log, so my -1 stands.

However, isn't it possible (albeit unlikely) that the host check in the compute api delete function starts before the host is assigned, but finishes some time during the execution of manager _run_instance? This scenario could potentially leak resources with the code in this patch. But perhaps this case is too unlikely to consider."}, {'account_id': 2140, 'date': '2012-04-24 00:27:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Johannes,
this deadlock could occur in the following sequense:
after _spawn (task_state=None) -> delete from api (task_state=deleting) -> _is_instance_terminated (task_state=deleting) -> raise InstanceNotFound -> deadlock.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-24 00:32:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I already saw the deadlock path, which is why I gave this a +2.'}, {'account_id': 2140, 'date': '2012-04-24 04:56:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-24 14:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

I must apologize--I've given this a bit more thought and come to the conclusion that the compute api delete code is a good bit more race-condition-dependent than I previously thought. See attached comments."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-24 15:17:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-24 15:31:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

I believe this patch substantially widens the window for race conditions with compute_api.delete. However, the code here by itself cannot completely close that window, so I'm inclined to accept it anyway.

See comments for more (attempted) explanation of the race condition I'm seeing."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-24 15:37:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

It probably does widen the race, but the race is so small now as it is, that it probably doesn't matter much.

I'm still curious to know if MotoKen saw this deadlock happen. I think the deadlock can only happen if there is a race. I guess the difference is if it fails early (like I suspect) or later on."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-24 15:53:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I guess the only real way to fix the race condition is to fix the compute api code. So I won't let that get in the way of the deadlock fix. A few leaked resources aren't the end of the world."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-25 01:02:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-25 01:26:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3617/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2281/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1941/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3674/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-25 01:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-23 11:40:36.000000000', 'message': 'Removes unnecessary code in _run_instance.

* Remove _is_instance_terminated and _shutdown_instance_even_if_deleted
  since run/terminate instance is synchronized.
* Avoid potential deadlock

commit_message:
Removes unnecessary code in _run_instance.

* Remove _is_instance_terminated and _shutdown_instance_even_if_deleted
  since run/terminate instance is synchronized.
* Avoid potential deadlock.
* Fixes bug 981316.

Change-Id: I4fe7e2ea00b85d9e0802fe93655e67db3909e86b

subject: bug 985867: remove conf_from_devstack in favor of             devstack.git/tools/configure_tempest.sh
messages:
[{'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-23 15:54:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-23 15:58:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Armando,

Unfortunately, tools/conf_from_devstack has kind of whithered on the proverbial vine :( It produces an invalid tempest.conf (even before your changes).

It needs some major work to instead use the (up-to-date) etc/tempest.conf.tpl template configuration instead. You can see how devstack is creating the tempest.conf file from this template in this patch here:

https://review.openstack.org/gitweb?p=openstack-dev/devstack.git;a=blob;f=tools/configure_tempest.sh;h=5ae252cf84b2fd25f335964514890ae7a79d1548;hb=9d5c7a0cf683e9a7493eda71f0202d21263ce03f

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:06:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Jay,

thanks for the heads-up. Am I correct in thinking that configure_tempest.sh is going to be the right tool for generating tempest.conf and that conf_from_devstack will be deprecated?

If so, I can turn this bug fix into: 'remove conf_from_devstack from tempest'. Otherwise, I'll just abandon it.

Thanks,
Armando"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-23 17:29:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yeah, I think it would be best to just stick with the one in devstack... it has the greater chance of being updated I think.

So feel free to remove -- also check to see if conf_from_devstack is in the README and remove mention of it if it is...

Best,
-jay'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-23 17:52:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

agreed.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-24 20:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-24 20:33:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

excellent. this will remove the confusion hopefully.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-24 20:34:04.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-24 20:34:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-pep8/116/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-merge/156/ : SUCCESS'}]

FWIW, tested this locally and it is properly producing the tempest.conf and all tests are passing on my local devstack...'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-04-23 15:25:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Jay,

why does tempest currently support only AMI images? I am missing something... 

I wonder if it's useful to make the script future proof and use an IMAGE_TYPE variable when grabbing the image uuid.

Then, you could move the TODO notice on the IMAGE_TYPE definition; just a thought."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:31:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Armando, that's a bit of a typo on my part. It's *devstack* that only uses AMI images right now... Tempest actually doesn't care what image type is used.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:40:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I am using VHDs with devstack and they work fine by the look of things...'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:43:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

what I meant is that if I specify  DEFAULT_IMAGE_NAME=vhd in my localrc, devstack's exercise tests will pick up the right image and everything is good. 

I would like that tempest did the same."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-23 17:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

OK, I can do that in a future patch.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-23 17:51:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
Tempest - Remove Kong support and fix images

* Removes (non-working) Kong config.ini support
* Replaces copy/paste code from stack.sh that was not
  properly grabbing image UUIDs with a call to glance
  index
* Grabs any non-kernel non-ramdisk images and properly populates
  the IMAGE_UUID_ALT variable if more than 1 image is
  available

Change-Id: Ieaf892b8b3fb4ef4fe2e6168f7a53bbe42dd684c

commit_message:
Omit Content-Length on chunked transfer

Content-Length and Transfer-Encoding conflict according to the HTTP
spec. This fixes bug 981332.

This also adds the ability to test both the sendfile-present and
sendfile-absent codepaths; the sendfile-present test will be skipped on
sendfile-absent platforms.

Change-Id: Ibb017b4a43d89ffdb6b868648296603cfec7780d
